PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 9 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forests, Victoria: Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate of Australia.

The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that there has been clear demonstration of public dissatisfaction with the mismanagement of the Victorian Otway forests, and we pray that: The Constitution of Australia be reformed to recognise significant expressions of public concern, e.g. petitions, by the formation of a committee to represent public requests.

PETITION.TITLE: Central Intelligence Agency: Role in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
We feel a deep concern about Christopher Boyce's allegations of intrusions into Australia's domestic affairs by the Central Intelligence Agency of America.
We feel disturbed by the knowledge that the U.S. base at Pine Gap is a C.I.A. operation.
We deplore the secrecy surrounding the functions of the U.S. bases in Australia.
We therefore pray that the Australian Government will authorize a full, impartial public inquiry into all and any roles the Central Intelligence Agency of America has undertaken in Australia.
We pray that this inquiry will allow the Australian public to make an informed decision about the future of the U.S. bases in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that:*
Uranium mining and processing is dangerous to the health and well-being and ecology of the Earth and its citizens.
By-products of uranium are toxic for periods of up to 500,000 years, and are an intrinsic part of the production of nuclear weapons.
Existing safeguards are inadequate, and are not properly monitored.
The policy of the Australian Government permits the entry into Australian territory of vessels and aircraft without the assurance that they are not nuclear powered or armed.
Such vessels pose a threat to both the security and well-being of Australia and its citizens.
The presence of foreign military and communication bases on Australian soil seriously endangers the health and well-being of Australia and its citizens.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable Senators will take cognisance of the above and take immediate action to remove the above dangers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that: whereas the Federal Government is spending increasing amounts to alleviate damage done to human lives by family break-up, desertion by spouses, divorce, children in ``latch-key'' situations, juvenile crime and drug addition, it is most inconsistent for that Government to lessen in any way the support that Australian families need to help them to survive.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. reject any proposed cuts to the support now provided to families by way of family allowance;
2. reject any proposal to introduce a ``flat-rate'' allowance, but rather keep family allowance fully proportional to family size; and
3. reject any proposal to abolish or diminish the dependent spouse tax rebate.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That certain Trade Unions are currently forcing employers and employees to join union-controlled Superannuation schemes through industrial blackmail, thereby extending the Unions' economic power and at the same time infringing individual rights.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
(i) Guarantee that Occupational Superannuation is a matter of individual choice.
(ii) Declare illegal industrial standover tactics which force people to join superannuation schemes controlled by, or sponsored by trade unions.
(iii) Protect those companies and their employees who establish their own superannuation arrangements at the enterprise level.
(iv) Ensure that union or industry-based schemes are not disguised pay rises by providing that employees must also make contributions.
(v) Provide that control of the funds of such schemes is vested in the elected representative of the contributors to those schemes.
(vi) Oppose any backdoor attempts at achieving compulsory unionism.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

(1) The Agreement between the United States of America and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap may be terminated by either Government on one year's notice from 19 October 1986.
(2) In the event of war between the United States and the Soviet Union, access by the United States to Pine Gap's facilities makes it a probable nuclear target.
(3) Access by all nations to Pine Gap's capacity to monitor and verify compliance with existing and future nuclear limitations treaties could contribute to world peace and security.
(4) The people of Australia are entitled to be consulted, through their representatives in Parliament, on any extension or modification of the Agreement affecting their lives, security and welfare.
And your petitioners humbly pray that:
(1) The Agreement between the United States and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap be terminated one year from October 1986.

(2) Public discussion and inquiry be instituted into the feasibility of negotiating a new agreement with the United Nations during the International Year of Peace offering the verification facilities of the Pine Gap base to all nations.
(3) Any agreement concerning the future use of Pine Gap be referred to Parliament for ratification.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That human embryos deserve legal protection to enable the development of their full human potential.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Pass Senator Harradine's Bill to prohibit experiments involving the use of human embryos created by in vitro fertilization.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Bill of Rights is a harmful, dangerous, divisive and unnecessary proposal, the provisions of which are dictatorial, harmful and against the true interest of the people of Australia.
Your petitioners pray: The Senate reject the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we oppose utterly the proposed Bill of Rights because the Bill will
Restrict our rights to those listed in the Bill
Transfer to government powers not given nor intended to be given by the Constitution
Threaten our rights by making them subject to the will of this or any future Government
Turn the Human Rights Commission into a political Star Chamber with unjustifiable power
Abrogate Common Law and common liberty
Set the State above the individual
We the undersigned believe in democracy and freedom and earnestly entreat you to recognise that this Bill will undermine the fundamental basis of these.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject the Bill of Rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oil Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
Your petitioners most humbly pray:
(i) that the Hawke Labor Government pass on the full benefits of lower international oil prices on March 1st, 1986; and
(ii) that the Hawke Labor Government does not increase or extend fuel taxes;
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that WHEREAS:
(1) Identification cards and numbers severely threaten our freedom to live unfettered by excessive bureaucratic surveillance;
(2) the Government has been unable to present any realistic justification for the introduction of ID cards and numbers;
We humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should reject any proposal to inflict ID cards and numbers on the freedom loving people of Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
that the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural and small business sectors, which will severely affect their long term viability.

that the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament, full details of which still had not been revealed after it had legally been in operation for more than six months, has caused confusion and hindered farmers and small business people in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax Legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament Assembled, will reject the proposed Bill of Rights as Australian's rights are already protected by the traditional system of common law and urge that any proposal for a Bill of Rights should be put to the Australian people through a referendum.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights Bill because-
We get no legally enforceable rights under the Bill

The Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as the right not to be belong to a trade union, the right to own private property and not be deprived of it without just compensation and the right of choice between Government and non-Government schools.
The Bill gives Canberra extra powers to change our Federal system by the back door without a constitutional referendum.
The Bill gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should vote against the Bill of Rights, support Opposition amendments and seek a genuine public debate and a referendum on the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Durack (from 322 citizens) and Newman (from 81 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: South African Students: Annual Scholarships
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

the abhorrent, racist system of Apartheid prevents non-white children and youth in South Africa and Namibia from equal participation in education (official statistics given in the South African Parliament for 1980-81 showed the annual expenditure on education to be 1,000 rand per capita for whites as against less than 200 rand per capita for blacks);

education inside South Africa and Namibia is so imbued with the ideology of apartheid that non-white students have rebelled against the `Bantu' Education system, leading to many students being imprisoned, beaten and harassed by police; many children and youth have fled apartheid in South Africa and Namibia to refugee camps run by the African National Congress of South Africa (ANC) and the South West African People's Organisation (SWAPO) of Namibia. In these refugee camps international aid provides primary and secondary education, but tertiary education in such circumstances is impractical;

the Australian Parliament has a bipartisan policy of opposition to Apartheid; the provision of scholarships for tertiary study in Australia for students from these refugee camps is one of the most positive steps Australia can take towards a non-racist future for South Africa;
community contributions to the Jim Gale Memorial African Scholarship Fund have reached over $13,000 in eight months, demonstrating the strong concern among Australians about this issue.
Your petitioners therefore pray and urge the Parliament of Australia to-
provide one hundred scholarships annually for South African students to be selected from ANC refugee camps, to enable them to undertake tertiary studies in Australia
provide one hundred scholarships annually for Namibian students to be selected from SWAPO refugee camps, to enable them to undertake tertiary studies in Australia
join with the Jim Gale Memorial African Scholarship Fund to provide at least one scholarship each year in memory of Jim Gale
waive any visa charges which might otherwise attach to these students as overseas students.
Your humble petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and senators in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, believing
that Australia should not host nuclear weapons in its territory or in Australian waters; and
that the presence of nuclear-armed warships makes a priority nuclear target of ports being visited; and
that the safety precautions for handling and deployment of nuclear weapons are inadequate to guarantee safety from accidents; and

that the following warships, all capable of launching nuclear weapons deployed in the British or United States navies, will be visiting Sydney between 29 September to 13 October-HMS Illustrious, HMS Beaver, HMS Fort Grange, HMS Manchester, HMS Amazon, HMS Olmeda, USS Missouri, USS Paul F. Foster, USS Oldendorf; and
that these warships capable of carrying nuclear weapons will be participating in the 75th Anniversary of the Royal Australian Navy
We therefore call upon the Australian Government to:
prohibit the entry of nuclear weapons to Australia; and to
deny access to Australian ports of foreign warships unless an assurance is received that they are not carrying nuclear weapons; and to
require that foreign warships participating in the anniversary of the Royal Australian Navy not be carrying nuclear weapons in Australian territorial waters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Gold Mining Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the welfare of many employees and their families depends upon a healthy, expanding gold mining industry
that the success of many small businesses in gold mining towns also depends upon the continued profitability of gold mining and prospecting operations

that the Federal Government's proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining and prospecting represents a threat to the profitability of these industries and therefore will cause widespread unemployment and depression throughout the whole gold mining industry.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Federal Government to reject any proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining or prospecting thereby ensuring that the spectacular growth of the industry over recent years is continued.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmania: Industry and Employment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned citizens of Australia humbly pray that the Federal Government join with the Tasmanian Government and institute an independent review of the Callaghan Report into the Structure of Industry and the Employment Situation in Tasmania.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Industrial Relations Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That some unions of employees are holding up to contempt statute laws and decisions of courts of law and sections of the International Labour Organisation Agreement which is ratified by Australia. Specific actions by unions of employees and the ACTU have led to the destruction of a number of sole trader and small family business enterprises and a denial of natural justice to the parents and the children in the small businesses concerned.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should totally reject all moves that may be made by the ALP Federal Government to deem any small business entrepreneur be he or she a truck owner driver, a farmer, a building contractor, a plumber, a carpenter or any other unspecified class of self employed, contractor or subcontractor, to be employees.
Your petitioners also humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should introduce legislation to provide basic rights of individuals into industrial relations.
1. The unqualified right to work.
2. The right to work hard in a chosen profession.
3. The right to pay one's way in all matters.
4. The right to provide for one's family.
5. The right to provide a secure job or enterprise for the future of one's children.
6. The right to freedom, democracy and dignity.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the following Special Reports by the Commonwealth Ombudsman be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for consideration and, if necessary, report thereon-
(a) the Cotton Case Involving the Australian Broadcasting Corporation; and
(b) the Industrial Sugar Mills Case involving the Department of Defence.

(2) That, unless otherwise ordered, all reports presented by the Commonwealth Ombudsman pursuant to section 17 of the Ombudsman Act 1976 stand referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, without any Question being put, for consideration and, if necessary, report thereon.

Under section 17 of the Ombudsman Act 1976, the Ombudsman is empowered to present to the Parliament copies of his special reports upon investigations into alleged misconduct by a department or a prescribed authority. The Ombudsman has exercised this power only twice. In September of last year he presented Special Report No. 1, the Cotton case involving the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. In May of this year, he presented his second special report concerning the Industrial Sugar Mills case involving the Department of Defence.

Thus far the Parliament has not responded to either of these reports. The only parliamentary deliberations which have occurred, did so at the instigation of one of the members of this Committee-Senator Puplick. The Committee is concerned at the lack of parliamentary response to these special reports.

The Ombudsman transmits a special report to the Presiding Officers of the Parliament only in very exceptional circumstances. Under the Ombudsman Act, he reports to the Parliament only after adequate and appropriate measures have not been taken by the relevant department or prescribed authority within a reasonable time, and he has reported to the Prime Minister. The Ombudsman's ability to present a special report to the Parliament under section 17 is his ultimate sanction. If the Parliament does not pay sufficient heed to his special reports one may well question his devotion of resources to taking such an exceptional step.

The Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee considers that the Ombudsman's first two special reports have languished on the table for too long. Special Report Number One was presented 11 months ago. Special Report Number Two was presented three months ago. Accordingly, we seek this reference in order to provide the Ombudsman with an opportunity to speak to his reports, to provide him with a forum. Additionally, the Committee is concerned that-I say this in deference to some inquiries made by honourable senators last night-without in any way derogating from the right of the Parliament to debate a special report of the Ombudsman, quite independently of its consideration by the Committee, there should be some procedure whereby such reports are automatically directed to the Committee for its consideration.

The terminology adopted is the same as that under which the President automatically sends annual reports to the appropriate committee, and this motion, if passed, will do no more than ensure that the report is put into the hands of one of the committees of the Senate. It does not take the report out of the possession of the Senate. Of course, any honourable senator is entitled to take it up in this chamber. Overall, we believe that the carrying of this motion will lead to a better appreciation by the Parliament of the considerations which have led the Ombudsman to take the exceptional step of presenting special reports to the Presiding Officers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to take up all the time available to me as I realise that we have a long speakers list and it is important that the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986 be passed as soon as possible. I do not intend to cover the legislation in any comprehensive way, because that has already been done very effectively by my colleagues Senator Coates and Senator Crowley, but I do want to highlight some of the points which have been raised with me in the community in the lengthy period in which the subject matter of this Bill has been open to public comment.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I would like to speak very briefly about the need for the legislation, because some speakers opposite have denied that there is a need for affirmative action. In spite of the improved position of women, following the passage of the sex discrimination legislation, women are still much over-represented in the lower paid occupations and under-represented in higher paid occupations, particularly those which have traditionally been male preserves. Even in the areas where women predominate, such as retailing, the better paid decision making positions are mainly held by men. I ask honourable senators to look around the first class compartment of an aircraft next time they fly; to look at the proportion of women the next time they address a meeting of, say, engineers, architects or lawyers; to look at who are the forepersons the next time they visit a factory; and to look around this chamber-even when there are more people here.

Of course, it would be very simplistic to suggest that the attitudes of employers, personnel officers and others who make decisions regarding employment, promotion or opportunities for training are the only reasons for this imbalance. The attitudes of parents who want their daughters to be nurses rather than carpenters or their sons to be engineers rather than kindergarten teachers, the attitudes in some schools and employment agencies and the sexist attitudes in the wider community all play a part, of course. But this legislation addresses what is perhaps the major bar to equal opportunity in the work force. This legislation is the logical extension of the sex discrimination legislation which became law early last year without, I must say, any of the dire consequences that were predicted then and are now predicted again by some for this legislation.

The Bill seeks to break down sex stereotyping in the world of work and to provide equal opportunity for women in work, in training, in promotion-that is, in privately owned work places; it already exists in the Public Service-and in higher education. I stress that this Bill is about equality, not about giving something more to women than is available to men or is at the expense of men. Affirmative action will mean that women will know that they can apply for a job or a promotion on equal terms with men, that they will succeed on their merits, and not be rejected because of prejudice or ignorance about the ability of women to perform the job, assumptions about women's role in society and where they should be at different stages of their lives, or conditions of employment which automatically exclude women. Some speakers opposing the Bill have claimed that it will help only middle class or professional women. This is not so. It will help the factory hand to become a foreperson in the same way as it will provide opportunities for women with professional qualifications. In many work places there are unseen or unacknowledged barriers to promotion for women, such as those occurring in some retail stores, where male school leavers become trainee storemen or even trainee managers while female school leavers become counter hands regardless of their ability.

Under this legislation males and females will have equal rights to jobs and to training so that promotion will depend on merit, not on the plumbing that one is born with. Affirmative action also will lift the self-esteem of women, who will now know it is worth while to apply for the job for which they are qualified with the same chance of success as a male would have. This increased confidence will in turn make them more valuable workers, secure in the confidence of their ability to do the job. The whole community in turn benefits when the skills of both sexes can be fully utilised. More job satisfaction for women also is likely to mean more stability of staffing because frustrated workers often move on. So employers benefit too from affirmative action, as does the whole community.

Some opponents of the Bill, here and elsewhere, have raised the issue of child care as being more important than affirmative action in enabling women to enter or re-enter the work force. Child care is really a totally separate issue and one which this Government is tackling simultaneously with equal opportunity legislation. In fact, this Government has a proud record in the provision of child care and is expanding the number of places available in child care as rapidly and equitably as possible. In the three years to June 1988 we will have provided 20,000 more child care places. I think it was Senator Hill who said the other day that if the Opposition won government it would favour the provision of child care through taxation rebates. I remember that that proposal, which would be of no benefit to low income earners or single parents, to whom he referred, because they are not liable for tax anyway, or else very little tax, was given a lot of publicity by the Liberal Party in the 1983 election campaign. Undoubtedly, it was one of the factors which led to a record vote by women for the Australian Labor Party in the subsequent election.

I commend the companies and tertiary institutions which took part in the pilot affirmative action program. I hope that they will publicise the provisions of this legislation, as I am sure the Government will. During the pilot program I found that women in country areas in particular were often unaware that the company they worked for was part of the program. I know that there have been similar difficulties in some Government departments. The best will at senior levels does not always percolate down to the branches. There needs to be a major effort to inform all women about affirmative action-particularly those women who work for large organisations and who will therefore be in the first group to benefit. Unions and professional organisations should also make sure that their members are aware of the benefits that may become available to them when the legislation is implemented. Companies must ensure that the whole organisation is aware of affirmative action and must be prepared to make sure that it is implemented at every level. Senator Hill correctly pointed to the need for women to be, as he put it, `in the know' if they are to benefit from the legislation. However, that is not a valid argument against the Bill, as he seemed to imply. We must ensure that all women are in the know. We in this chamber can do a great deal to make sure that that happens.

The only real concern about this legislation that has been expressed to me by women is the belief that it should go further and that it should be implemented more quickly. Women have waited a long time for the reforms which this Bill seeks to bring about. Their impatience is understandable. However, we have to face the realities of the situation. Introducing affirmative action by stages, after the operation of the pilot scheme, will help to ensure that the process is educative and entered into in a co-operative manner with the minimum of real opposition. It can be seen that this Labor Government has achieved an amazing advance in the status of women over the last 3 1/2 years when we consider the long history of male dominance in the work place as well as in the power structures of society. This achievement is partly due to the fact that we have hastened slowly; we have consulted widely, we have been prepared to discuss the issues out in the community and we have carried out an educative process along the way. It has been interesting to hear some of those people who vehemently opposed the sex discrimination legislation two years ago saying now that they are all for equal opportunity but that affirmative action is going too far. I am sure that in another two years they will accept affirmative action, too, as have the companies and institutions that took part in the pilot program.

Therefore, I believe that phasing in the legislation will be successful. I hope that it will be so successful that those who will not be covered by this legislation, that is the companies employing fewer than 100 people, will see the benefits of affirmative action and become affirmative action employers themselves. I certainly very much hope that this eventuates, as some of the most exploited women workers are those in the small work places, particularly those in areas of work which traditionally are regarded as male.

I was pleased to note in the Budget Papers that the Government intends to legislate for equal opportunity in Commonwealth statutory authorities, as is already taking place in the Public Service. This legislation will not bring a rapid end to policies and practices in the workplace which have denied to women the right to realise their potential on the same terms as men, but it is certainly a major step towards equity in employment and towards the day when employers will no longer regard the gender of the applicant as relevant to the appointment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other day I mentioned the enormous costs that could be incurred by both business and individuals under the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill. I had gone into quite extensive detail of what the Bill would cost in terms of the Budget, and I asked whether we should continue to allow $1.2m to be spent on such a project.

SPEECH.PARA: Further to my remarks about the undesirable regulation of business being the only major defect in this legislation, of far greater concern is the fact that, through the use of numerical forward estimates, the potential has been created for the downgrading of merit and excellence in employment in both tertiary institutions and the private sector. Just as I would champion the principle of equality of opportunity, I am totally opposed to any project that aims for equality of opportunity and equality of outcomes. I am amazed that the provisions of this legislation are directed towards the final achievement of equality of outcomes.

Equality of outcomes is an objective that can be achieved in the long run only by discrimination. Belief in equality of outcomes is underpinned by an anti-individualist view that looks to the distribution of goods or jobs on the basis not of individual merit but of group entitlement. It is a crude aspect of collectivism or socialism that depends on a false reading of human nature, for it relies on the assumption that were there no discrimination of any kind, all groups in society would enjoy a proportional distribution of society's rewards, as though talents were uniformly distributed throughout the human race. Such thinking would never admit the possibility that some occupations will always attract a higher proportion of men, just as other jobs continue to appeal to women. Equality of outcomes can never be an indication as to whether there is a genuine equality of opportunity in employment or in any aspect of life. To produce equality of outcomes, merit must be sacrificed, and genuine equality of opportunity thus disappears.

I do not say that this Bill seeks to enforce equality of outcomes through the imposition of employment quotas. Mind you, I think if it could, it would. If the Government thought it could get away with it, it would do so. I am saying that a so-called forward estimate, which may be expressed in numerical terms, according to clause 8 (3), is the thin end of a wedge whereby the effectiveness of affirmative action programs will be judged through a statistical examination of employment outcomes. Only two days ago, Senator Coates-a Government senator-said that if this did not work out, obviously in the future things would have to be toughened up. That is exactly where the concern about the thin end of the wedge arises.

Once any stress is given to numerical outcomes, there will be pressure on an employer to modify selection procedure, not simply to ensure equal opportunity but to produce the desired outcome. I find such pressure absolutely and utterly deplorable. The way would be open to the relaxation of standards to fulfil the desired goal and hence the diminution of the merit principle. It is not good enough to say, although Australian Labor Party and Australian Democrat senators say it, that because quotas are not contained in the Bill and because goals, targets and forward estimates-call them what you will-are not the same as quotas, there can be no risk of the injustice that we associate with quotas. Quotas simply involve the reservation of a set number of jobs for a favoured group, regardless of qualifications, sex, age or anything else. With goals, applicants must be qualified and the employer need fill only as many vacancies as there are qualified members of the favoured group available. While I agree that targets or goals are less damaging than quotas, to a degree they still require the selection of people on criteria other than individual excellence and suitability for the job in hand. It comes back to my earlier point that the modifications to selection procedure to secure the target will entail modification of the merit principle.

If one believes, as I do, that our universities require the best possible teachers and researchers and that private enterprise is entitled to have the best possible executives, no weakening of this principle can ever be acceptable or even entertained. For this reason equal employment opportunity should be divorced from the numerical targets for which this Bill provides. Of course, I recognise that sub-clause (4) of clause 3 declares:
Nothing in this Act shall be taken to require a relevant employer to take any action incompatible with the principle that employment matters should be dealt with on the basis of merit.

However, the fact that employers are not compelled to act against the merit principle does not constitute a sure defence against its weakening through the insidious pressure of numerical targets. Employers will tend to relax the merit principle should the Director of Affirmative Action lay stress on the fulfilment of targets. It is most pertinent to recall that in the United States, where quotas have now attracted just condemnation, they were not originally imposed by law in this form. Rather, they developed as a convenient short-cut by employers under pressure from zealous bureaucrats administering what were initially voluntary affirmative action plans. Therein lies the danger for Australia. We could be more convinced that this Government intended to stand by the merit principle if it had inserted in this Bill a clause prohibiting any recourse to quotas by an employer as part of affirmative action policy. As it is, the door is left open to the possibility of equal employment opportunity degenerating into reverse discrimination, which is another threat that should be avoided at all costs.

It is very relevant to this debate to consider the operation of affirmative action in New South Wales, where in 1980 an affirmative action handbook was issued under the Anti-Discrimination Act of 1977. This document shows a clear bias towards a collectivist equality of result. It argues the dubious principle that past discrimination requires remedial programs for affected groups, a concept that is irrelevant to the notion of individual justice and that is used to justify the idea that two wrongs make a right. It is stated that improvements in equality of opportunity should be visible in outcomes and the redistribution of minority groups and women in personnel statistics. Also, programs must have goals and targets evaluated in terms of their redistributive effects. This terminology makes it obvious that collectivist outcomes should override the stated principle of equality of opportunity. Clearly, merit has to be sacrificed when a government agency, through this handbook, declares that in the end the success or failure of affirmative action depends on statistical results. How will the Government assess the success of that legislation? Confronted with this demand, an employer who has to explain why a numerical target has not been met is in a situation of reverse onus of proof. We should be under no illusion that requirements of this kind will result in de facto quota systems, with qualifications being lowered, if need be, to ensure that women and minority groups are reflected in final numbers.

In short, we are confronted by an ominous precedent in the New South Wales experience, and I must emphasise the hard fact that nothing in this legislation will prevent the same kind of enforcement procedure in the future. While this kind of hard affirmative action is a threat to the freedom of choice of private employers, it can have an equally serious effect on tertiary institutions where governments have far greater direct leverage. We already have a precedent for this in New South Wales, where in September 1983 the former Premier announced that tertiary bodies would have to comply with Part IXa of the 1977 Act that covers equal opportunity in the public sector. Applying the unfair criteria of the numerical representation of women or minorities in teaching positions, universities will come under pressure to modify qualifications to achieve some arbitrary statistic. Inevitably this in turn results in the appointment of people who may not be unqualified, but who are less well qualified than other applicants. Not only is this harmful for senior teaching positions, but neither should it be applied to such positions as research assistants where it is essential that an applicant should fit in well with an existing team. I make no substitute for the ideal that universities are responsible for the extension of knowledge, not to initiate what the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) calls `corporate social action'. If the Minister wants universities to become instruments of social engineering, we cannot be confident that she will support the merit principle against numerical requirements of affirmative action.

No doubt because of the greater control that governments can exercise over universities and colleges of advanced education, this Bill insists that they should be the first to develop affirmative action programs, commencing next August. I warn the Senate that the merit principle is already being eroded by numerical requirements in our tertiary institutions. We have the example of the South Australian College of Advanced Education where, through affirmative action, the staffing committee must examine the percentage of male and female staff on contract when considering tenure. There can be no question that by stressing outcomes in this way, people will gain tenure on the basis of their sex rather than their qualifications or proven teaching ability. Nothing in this Bill will preclude this insidious development, that will threaten both academic excellence and genuine equality of employment.

Certainly we should be aware that influential elements within society and within the government sector are anxious to promote a far harder concept of affirmative action than we have seen in the pilot program. This attitude appears in a paper delivered in June 1984 by Dr Peter Wilenski, Chairman of the Public Service Board. He noted that `few organisations can claim to be multicultural in any sense though we are expected to regard Australia as a multicultural society'. We should question the attitude that organisations, both public and private, should somehow reflect the composition of society rather than fulfil their functions as effectively as possible. It is one thing to ask that organisations allow genuine equal employment opportunity, and another to wish to reshape them according to some desired objective of social engineering.

We must take warning from the statement made by Canberra law lecturer Margaret Wallace, in the Australian Quarterly, when she defined discrimination as `requiring unnecessary academic or other achievements women in general are unlikely to possess'. The moral is clear: Standards must be lowered if necessary to fulfil the desired end results of affirmative action. We owe it to the women of Australia not to lower qualifications in order to give them positions they would not gain through merit, but rather to give them the training they need in order to compete on equal terms. While this may take a bit longer, it is surely the fairest means of securing true equal employment opportunity.

Because we in the Liberal Party may be critical of this Bill for its unnecessary regulation of business, and for its future implications, we will be accused of opposition to the advancement of women. I make no apology for reiterating that weakening the merit principle for the short term promotion of women is demeaning and harmful for the prospect of long term equality. To reject the notion of equality of outcomes is to safeguard the principle of true equality of opportunity. While voluntary programs of equal employment opportunity can benefit employer and employee alike, bureaucratic social engineering can only be damaging. Women should be given the greatest employment opportunities confronting them today without the need for such legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The trouble with this Government when it attempts to deal with equality for women is that it really does not have the foggiest idea of what true equality means. If we look at the Government's history we find that it introduced a Sex Discrimination Bill. How many amendments had to be made to that Bill? Finally, the Government had to re-write the whole Bill. It realised that, with Senator Ryan's interpretation of equality for the sexes, the Bill was a complete disaster. Now we have the `National Agenda for Women' which I think is positively degrading for women. I list the suggested topics for discussion that this Government believes women should be interested in-I stress `should be' interested in: Health, for example, contraception, stress, abortion, repetitive strain syndrome, arthritis; child care; sport and recreation; income, for example, wages, equal pay, pension, superannuation and maintenance; jobs, for example, part time work, non-traditional work, trades, self-employment, sexual harassment and trade union membership; welfare; domestic violence; special needs; and politics, for example, women in parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: What a narrow idea of what women in this country are really interested in! Where is the economy mentioned? Where is defence? Where is trade? I have never in all my life seen such a degrading list of suggestions-put forward by a group of people who have no idea of what true equality means. This was underlined by the agenda drawn up by Liberal women at Federal Council when they were talking about all the other issues that the people of Australia are interested in. The list of topics on the `National Agenda for Women' is indicative of the low esteem in which this Government holds women.

The Government thinks that there will not be true equality until there are equal numbers of women and men in the work force, until women are entitled and, indeed, expected to lift the same weights as men, until their little daughters are forced to compete athletically against boys of the same age. What a debacle was an amendment to that effect, put by Senator Haines, to the Sex Discrimination Bill. We now have the Human Rights Commission making special exemptions because it was found that little girls could not compete against boys in swimming races. They were not winning any races, and because they were not winning they were deciding not to swim. They were keeping out of the races. But, because a group of Labor women and Senator Haines think that little girls ought to be able to compete against boys, the amendment was passed and the Human Rights Commission had to make a special exemption so that girls could compete amongst themselves. That is just blind fanaticism; nothing else. It is not equality. It is just fanatical feminism.

True equality, put simply, gives every women the right to choose the type of life she wishes to live. She may choose the traditional role of wife and mother, she may choose to follow a wonderful career, she may choose the combination of a traditional role and a career or she may choose the traditional role and just another job, either full time or part time, to earn the extra money that she believes would be of great help to her family. She may chose to do some part time work just because she likes to accomplish something but wants to fit in with her family arrangements. Of course, the emphasis is on choice.

If we look at the research in the book Beyond the Stereotypes we find that overwhelmingly women if given the choice would choose part time work. By far the largest number of women, 31 per cent, would want part time work. If we add those women to the women who would choose paid work from home, we find that 43 per cent of women would want to do a little bit of work to fit in with their family responsibilities. The full time mothers, the women who want to run a home full time, and those doing unpaid voluntary work represent 31 per cent of women. Therefore, the majority of women by far, adding those two groups together, want to do work that fits in with their traditional family responsibilities.

But we have the continual rubbish coming from Government senators who say that women earn only 78 per cent of average male wages. What absolute rubbish! It is what women choose to do that is the important thing. It is what women want to do that is important, not what Labor women think they should do. Because women earn only 78 per cent of men's wages, the Labor women shout: `What discrimination!'. Is it any wonder that women flock to vote for the Liberal Party of Australia and keep away from the Australian Labor Party? One has only to look at the polls to point that out.

It never occurs to the Labor sisterhood that many women want to work part time and are not interested in being forced into the higher echelons of employment. We are told by the Labor sisterhood that women are forced into part time work-that they are forced there because they have such a dreadful burden in bringing up children. What a burden it is! I do not think anything makes my hackles rise more than being told that, and we are told that regularly by the Labor sisterhood. They simply do not understand that the majority of women would not miss for quids the opportunity to bring up our children, and that that is something that we enjoy doing. We would not miss it for the world. Indeed, we believe that men miss out on a lot in missing those early childhood years through having to be away from home so often.

We are told continually that women outnumber men in the part time work force and what a discrimination and a disgrace that is. We are told repeatedly that, as women represent over 50 per cent of the population, 50 per cent of the members of this place should be women. Again, how many women would find that this job, and the way of life involved with having to come to Canberra so often, would fit in with their family commitments? It is their choice that they do not stand in large numbers for selection to the Senate. I entered the Senate only when my children were grown up. That was my choice. Other women choose differently and they can arrange their family affairs to suit them perfectly. But the majority of women choose part time work. The majority of women would not choose to spend so many hours, days and months away from their families. The Labor sisterhood is not satisfied with that because it believes that it can tell women what they should do. The psychological pressure put on our young people which makes them feel guilty unless they are in the paid work force is a tremendous tragedy. What a tragedy it is that our young mothers should feel that they are not fulfilling the most important job in Australia-that of bringing up our future generations in a stable and loving atmosphere. Many young women try to do both jobs but they end up doing neither properly. They are just dog tired and frustrated because of the psychological pressure put on them to be in the work force.

Let us look at the name of the Bill-the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986. According to all English interpretations the words `affirmative action' mean to give preference to women. As Senator Peter Baume has already said, this Bill relies on merit. I will come to the word `merit' a little later when I move my amendment. To whom does this Bill apply? It applies to higher education institutions and employers who have 100 or more employees in Australia. It does not include the Commonwealth, State or Territory governments. This measure will be gradually phased in over a period. Supposedly this legislation will be effective from 1 August, though I gather that the Government will be moving an amendment to alter that date. Companies employing more than 1,000 employees will be required to commence their affirmative action programs by 1 February, companies employing over 500 but under 1,000 employees will be required to commence their programs by 1 February 1988 and companies with over 100 but under 500 employees will be required to commence theirs by 1 February 1989. So these programs will be phased in for those employers who have to write reports.

What will be the cost to the taxpayer of this measure? For starters-that is how the Government has put in its affirmative action explanatory memorandum-the legislation is expected to come into operation in the 1986-87 financial year and the first bids will be based on the staff numbers of 25 employers in Sydney whose expenditure is $1.5m. This is happening at a time when the Government says that we are in a crisis, that we are at war. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has said that we may become a banana republic, and this morning we had the news that indeed we are a banana republic because we are listed in a report as the very last country expected to have an economic upturn. Although we are in that situation the Government is willing to spend another $1.5m-for starters, based on first bids-on this rubbishy legislation when affirmative action can be achieved in a voluntary way. It is not the way the Liberal Party would go about it.

We have quotas. Indeed they are called forward estimates because they are voluntary. However, if a company does not fulfil the forward estimates it has to make a written explanation. The difference between voluntary forward estimates and quotas is just a sleight of hand. There is no doubt that a company which says that it will employ X number of women over the next 12 months has to make a written explanation if it does not fulfil that number. There is no doubt that these estimates are quotas.
The Bill also states that unions have to be consulted. Let us look at what the unions have said. A motion passed at the special union conferences on affirmative action in October 1984 states:

That in the event that a company involved in the Government's affirmative action pilot project fails to properly consult with the appropriate union on that company's program, the ACTU will assist those affiliates involved to mount a campaign to ensure that adequate consultation occurs.
It goes on to give priorities to unionisation of those work places covered by the project in which eligible employees are not members of the appropriate union. It says:
In their submission to the Working Party on Affirmative Action, the ACTU specifically indicated that they saw this as `an industrial relations issue' . . .
The Government is buoying up the unions for more industrial relations activity, creating additional problems in the work force.

The Bill allows for education and research; I shall be dealing with that at the appropriate time in Committee. Let me liken that to the human relations legislation. In that respect, too, there was the opportunity for education and research. I refer to what was said in one of the booklets put out by the Human Rights Commission. It refers to setting up a classroom and is a document given to teachers with suggestions as to how they should set up such classes. The document is headed `Teaching for human rights' and is by Ralph Pettman. It has been distributed to schools and teachers. He said:

In the first few weeks of the school year the teacher can challenge some of the learned behaviours that do not seem to encourage children's rights as individuals, and by careful selection, expose the children to a wide and varied range of positive thinking about themselves and others. Children come to school with some fairly set ideas. A lot of these are sex-role stereotypes. A lot of work has to be done with non-sexist education with the class to begin the Human Rights Integrated Approach. This should be done in the first four weeks of the school year.

So they grab the little kids at kindergarten, and a lot of work has to be done on those children in the first four weeks of the school year to change the thinking their parents may have taught them at home. This is how they go about it. It says that to stop these stereotype roles no one plays with cars from the play corner unless there are equal numbers of boys and girls willing to play with them. No one plays with the paper dolls; they are not allowed out unless there is at least one boy in the group. So the little girls cannot play with the paper dolls unless they can talk one boy into playing with the paper dolls with them. This is human rights; this is the education approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —From where is the honourable senator quoting? This is interesting.
—I hope that Senator Grimes is interested. If he would like a copy of it, I should be happy to give him one. It is entitled `Teaching for human rights', by Ralph Pettman.
—Who is he?

—I thought Senator Grimes would know. He is on the Human Rights Commission. He put out all this rubbish to be taught in the schools. I sincerely hope that the clause on education and research will not be taking similar lines to that indulged in by the Human Rights Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition believes, as I have already said, that we should implement an affirmative action program by way of a voluntary system. We had a 12-month pilot program. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) thought that the program was pretty good. Indeed, he stated:
The project is comprehensive, voluntary and it will in a very real way steer us towards the best way of permanently ensuring that women are given equal job opportunities with men in our society.

I agree entirely with the Prime Minister. It is the best way to go about it. If one goes about it voluntarily, if one is not forced to do something, the commitment is very much greater. Of course, it would save at least $1.5m of taxpayers' money, at a time when money is so precious, and, as the explanatory memorandum to the Bill has indicated, that is only for starters.

There would be a cost to the business community. Again, this Government is putting costs on business. Has it not learnt that it cannot keep adding costs to business and still expect business to be able to compete? If it has not learnt that, it will learn pretty soon. The Government has already said that it does not believe that the balance of payments figures will improve in the foreseeable future. Can anyone doubt that when the Government keeps putting on these additional costs? According to Mr Allen of the Business Council of Australia, the cost will be quite considerable. He said:
It will require specific appointments of staff. It will require a specific set of statistical collections and reportage.

He stated that a new government agency, staffed by public servants, will monitor what is going on. The threat of naming companies in Parliament is such that business will have to spend additional money on the appointment of staff and statistical collection. So the Government is once again adding to the costs of business. It is about time that it learnt that this is not possible, if it wants the balance of payments figures to be reduced. It is about time that the Government got off the backs of business and allowed it to get on with helping the Australian economy. We know what the Business Council sees as the effect of this legislation, because Mr Allen stated:
. . . regardless of its stated intent-
that is, the Affirmative Action Bill-

could have the effect of positive discrimination in favour of women, thus challenging the notion that all employees should be treated as individuals according to their skills, qualifications, aptitudes and potential, without regard to gender. Compliance with legislation and the requirement to justify performance in quantitative terms to a specialised agency can easily become a numbers game rather than promoting qualitative change through a genuine commitment to the ideals of equal employment opportunity for women.

Of course, that is the crux of the situation. We are told repeatedly by female government members that it is all to be done on merit. Indeed, some of the more radical women's organisations have objected very strongly to the fact that it should be done on merit. The Women's Electoral Lobby has stated that the legislation has no teeth. But the point is that once a business has given a commitment to employing a number of employees over the period of 12 months, whether one likes it or not, because the business must answer a `please explain' at the end of that time if it has not done so, women will be employed who do not have the same merit for the job as another employee who is applying for the job. At a time when the Budget says that we are in for a period of higher unemployment, less business investment, less housing investment and the continuation of our disastrous balance of payments problems, this is what the Government is doing to business. I cannot stress that too much. At a time when we are supposed to be at war, the Government says that we need more money spent by business on this rubbishy sort of legislation.
I should like to foreshadow an amendment which defines merit and to which the Government has agreed. The Concise Oxford Dictionary definition of the word `merit' is:
Quality of deserving well.

That is not what I always understood `merit' to mean. I do not think that it is the Bill's intention that, so long as someone is `deserving well', he or she should be employed under this legislation. I believe that `merit' should be what we all believe it to be and should apply to the person with the best qualifications for the job.

If only the Government would allow the pilot project-which we all have said is very successful and which the Prime Minister has said is the best way to go about this change-to go forward in a voluntary way, the longer term commitment by employers would lead to better results for women generally. It is a pity that the Government needs to expand its services and departments once more by adding yet another layer of bureaucracy through this silly Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the purpose of the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill, although I have a number of worries about it. I must emphasise that, although I have these worries, I have no quarrel with the concept of equal opportunity in employment. It is vital to the economic revival of this country that we make full use of our available talents, regardless of sex. It would be a gross breach of human rights if women who want to do particular jobs for which they are qualified by physique, intellect or training were denied them purely on the ground of sex.

SPEECH.PARA: We have made great progress in overcoming many of the disabilities that affected women in past years. There has been a gradual implementation of equal pay for equal work and the opening up of almost all kinds of work for women as well as men. This concept works not only for women but also for men-a point which is often overlooked. There are more women engaged in engineering and manual labour than in the past now that jobs are more readily available for women. But men have also gained access to new work areas, such as nursing and secretarial work. I should stress that it was not always employers who stood in the way of women getting jobs regarded as men's. For a long time, unions barred women working alongside male builders' labourers. The tramway union in Melbourne always allowed women conductors to shoulder their way through the rush-hour crowds at peak times on trams to collect fares, but, although one had to be a conductor before one could be a driver, only men conductors were considered for the perk job of being a driver-a comfortable seated job, sitting up in front of the tram-as though it required a penis to drive a tram. That sort of discrimination went on for many years. We are gradually and steadily changing that.
Perhaps the most important provision in the Bill is in clause 3 (4) which says:
Nothing in this Act shall be taken to require a relevant employer to take any action incompatible with the principle that employment matters should be dealt with on the basis of merit.
That is a vital provision. Anything less would be both unfair to individuals and very damaging to the efficiency of our national economy.

So far, so good. Now I must turn to my worries. My first problem is the title of the Bill-`Affirmative Action'-which is given a special definition in this Bill, a definition which is quite different from what most people usually understand affirmative action to mean. My second worry is that I do not understand the logical reason for the Bill to be so sexist. Why are we providing equal opportunity for women only? Why not for men too? My third problem is perhaps more fundamental. I do not understand why we have the Bill at all. To modify an old saying: There are things that are good, and things that are new; what is new is not good, and what is good is not new. My fourth worry is that the new procedures seem likely to be very expensive administratively-another heavy charge on industry at a time when we are trying to make our industry more competitive. The new procedures also hold the seeds of danger in converting what are beneficial targets into de facto quotas.

I would like to examine each of those concerns in turn. My first problem was the title of the Bill. The Bill defines an affirmative action program as `a program designed to ensure that appropriate action is taken to eliminate discrimination by the relevant employer against women in relation to employment matters; and that measures are taken by the relevant employer to promote equal opportunity for women in relation to employment matters'. That is fine. The problem is that that definition of affirmative action is not what is usually thought to be meant by affirmative action. In this Bill it appears to imply no more than the removal of discrimination. I think all of us would agree with that, but many people do not see affirmative action like that at all; they see it as a process going much further than prohibiting discrimination. They see it as involving the establishment of quotas in hiring to be filled exclusively by individuals from groups identified as victims of past discrimination practices. This is, of course, a negation of selection on merit, and everywhere it has been tried it has been a catastrophe. In order to cure one problem, people have imposed a much worse cure than the disease. We must resist this at all costs. We must not get locked into this disastrous idea of quotas. That being so, and with what most people understand by affirmative action, there is no need for the words, `Affirmative Action' in the title. In fact, they are misleading. I will be supporting the amendment to delete these words from the title of the Bill.

My second worry was the sexist terminology in the title of the Bill and, indeed, in the whole thrust of the Bill. Why the phrase `for Women' in the title of the Bill and the constant reference to `equal employment opportunity for women'? Surely equal employment opportunity is for everybody, not just for women. There have been well recorded cases of discrimination against men in certain jobs such as nursing, some office work, reception work, airline stewardship, and so on.

My third problem was why have the Bill at all. If the Bill is intended merely to remove discrimination, then legislation to achieve that is already in place. We already have a Sex Discrimination Act which quite adequately deals with all forms of discrimination against women and minority groups in the community in relation to employment. So what is the reason for the Bill, if the merit principle is to remain the sole foundation for employment? This Bill is really only about creating non-binding programs which employers may or may not carry out and about creating a new bureaucracy-the Director of Affirmative Action. If there is really nothing more behind it, the Government has indeed laboured mightily and brought forth a mouse.

That brings me to my fourth worry-the costs and the lurking dangers. There will be considerable costs as a result of this Bill. The cost to the bureaucracy has been estimated at $1.5m a year, and this at a time when the Government is supposed to be seeking to cut expenditure. To the employers the costs are much higher. In one company the cost of the voluntary affirmative action pilot program was $750,000. Overall the cost to participating companies in the voluntary affirmative action pilot program-the trial for this program-was between $5m and $10m, depending on the measurement of executive time. Sydney University is another example which was brought in under the New South Wales Anti-Discrimination Act; and that cost it $450,000 a year.

Is that worth it? Are we getting value for money? What do we get for this? We will not be introducing quotas for affirmative action; we will be introducing only goals, which in this Bill are renamed objectives. What is the difference between a quota and an objective? A quota system involves reserving a predetermined fixed number of vacancies for women without regard to the individual qualifications of the applicants, and may therefore result in the selection of unqualified applicants. An objective system, on the other hand, is not binding and does not require the selection of unqualified applicants. So provided we are prepared to accept the bureaucratic and business overheads-and the overheads and costs are very substantial- involved in setting up and monitoring objectives, I do not suppose they will do any great harm. They could actually be beneficial if they forced employers regularly to review their recruiting procedures to see that they are truly non- discriminatory. Whether we are getting value for money though is a quite different question.

But quite apart from that, we must be constantly vigilant to see that these non-binding objectives are not converted into de facto quotas, which would be an abuse of natural justice and would be very damaging to our economic efficiency. I repeat, everywhere these binding quotas-putting people into jobs, regardless of their qualifications, merely because they are a disadvantaged group-have been tried-it has resulted in a catastrophe. We must avoid that at all costs. Yes, we must provide fair opportunities, equal opportunities in employment, non-sexist opportunities, but we must not creep into having quotas. As an example of the sorts of dangers I foresee, there is a proposal at Melbourne University at the moment that there must be at least one woman on each selection panel, whether that woman is suitably qualified or not. This is definitely a quota, and I suspect other universities have similar requirements for women's representation on selection panels and departmental boards and so on. This is a form of quota.

I repeat over and over again that we must resist the quota system at all costs. It has been tried in a number of countries and has always been a catastrophe. I do not think anyone in the Senate, as far as I am aware, has been arguing for a quota system, because of the manifest defects of such a system. I think we must constantly watch to see we do not slip into a quota system under another name.

I have a final worry. There is the possibility that the achievements of many women who have, through merit, attained a particular office might be devalued. The question will always arise in the minds of many: Did the woman get the job because she was the best or because she was a woman? Because if other things such as qualifications and previous experience are equal, there is nowadays considerable pressure for employers to appoint women to particular jobs.

I will conclude by saying that two out of three of my personal staff are women. I chose them on merit alone. I can only say that I am sure that they would want to be persuaded and convinced that I chose them for their capabilities and not because they were women. I support the Bill but I do have worries. I sincerely hope that they turn out to be groundless.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986. I say from the outset that I am totally and absolutely opposed to this damnable legislation. The sadness in society these days is that when one is opposed to legislation of this nature a clear inference is placed in the minds of many that one is opposed to having women in the work force and supports some type of bias against them. That is not right; the contrary is the truth. I believe, as do the vast majority of reasonable people in the community, that women are entitled to pursue whatever career they wish. The factors which should determine whether a person gets a job are willingness and the competence that will be applied to the job and the concurrent assessment by the employer that the person is able to perform the job and is the most suitable candidate from those available-one who has the capacity, competence and ability, irrespective of sex.

SPEECH.PARA: There ought not to be any arbitrary restrictions preventing males or females pursuing their chosen career. In addition to the rights of women to join the work force, women ought to be at liberty to be wives and mothers. There should be no inference that a woman who has chosen to raise children has in any way let herself down or has failed to achieve her potential. Some people at the moment seem to suggest that women who choose to be full time wives and mothers are fulfilling less than their capacity or ability. There is an attempt to undermine the confidence of these women, to leave them feeling inadequate and feeling that they have not fulfilled a complete and absolute role in the community.

I find no more admirable role for a woman than that of being a wife and mother and being an intrinsic part of the traditional family unit as many of us understand and accept it. It is a source of great distress to me that many women who seem actively and vocally to promote the role of working women feel the need to denigrate those women who make the conscious choice to assume the role of wife and mother. Perhaps that reveals a certain vulnerability amongst these women and a lack of understanding towards the feelings of mothers who are devoted to their husbands and children.

Let us examine the Bill before the Senate. It is not about achieving equality for women. It has been introduced in the guise of equal opportunity legislation but in reality it is not designed at all to secure equality for women. It is perhaps designed to secure a short term and temporary advantage, but it will be to the long term detriment of women. In attempting to secure an advantage for women over men the Bill will demean the achievements of women who have already succeeded in the work force. In so doing, the Bill will undermine the principle of achievement based on merit. It will not guarantee that jobs will go to the best applicants but inevitably it will result in jobs going to inferior applicants.

In the United States, which has had similar legislation containing quotas-that is what this legislation will provide, de facto quotas-many minority groups have been promoted in the work force beyond their skills and qualifications. They simply stagnate at a level above that to which they ought to have been promoted. The legislation will impose costs on business for no good purpose. The first of these costs will be the cost of complying with the legislation. Business will have to produce yet more paper for government. The second cost will be that of having to carry people who are not necessarily the most suitable for the jobs available. As this Bill at least in theory attempts to enshrine the principle of appointment based on merit, one may well ask how the Bill will enshrine affirmative action legislation rather than simply equal opportunity legislation. This question arises because of the peculiar nature of this Bill and the way it enables the affirmative action program to be administered.

I will now examine some of the provisions of this Bill and indicate why I have reached the conclusion that there is far more to this legislation than meets the eye and why it would have the harmful consequences I have predicted. At the outset, it is worth noting that the Government has very skilfully drafted this Bill so that it has power to deal with employment when the Commonwealth is not given any specific power under the Constitution to deal with it. There was never any intention that the Commonwealth have power to deal with employment, but the Government has attempted to gain power by limiting the operation of this Bill to employment in areas under Commonwealth jurisdiction such as banking beyond one State and interstate trade and commerce. For good measure the Government claims to be giving effect to the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. In this way it hopes to take advantage of the incorrect and unjustifiably wide powers given to the Commonwealth in the Tasmanian dams case. The Government has been prepared to twist and, in my view, pervert the law to its own advantage in an effort to attract unto itself powers which it was never intended that the Government should have.

This Bill will require employers of more than 100 employees to commence an affirmative action program. The Bill alleges that an affirmative action program is a program designed to eliminate all forms of discrimination against women and ensure equal opportunity in employment. It is further defined that employers are required to announce to employees the commencement of the program, to appoint an employee to supervise the program, and engage in consultations about the program with employees and, of course, trade unions.

As a final and most important requirement the Bill requires employers to set objectives and forward estimates. It is these two terms which constitute the most sinister and dangerous clauses of the Bill. The definitions of these terms are as follows:

``forward estimate'' means a quantitative measure or aim, which may be expressed in numerical terms, designed to achieve equality of opportunity for women in employment matters, being a measure or aim that can reasonably be implemented by the relevant employer within a specified time;

``objective'' means a qualitative measure or aim, expressed as a general principle, designed to achieve equality of opportunity for women in employment matters, being a measure or aim that can reasonably be implemented by the relevant employer within a specified time.

The Bill goes on to appoint a Director of Affirmative Action. The functions of the Director are to advise employers on their affirmative action programs, to issue guidelines to employers and to evaluate programs. Employers are required to submit both a public and a confidential report to the Director about their program. The Director then reports to the Minister about any matters connected with her function-presumably the director will be a female-

TALK.START.PARA: —Why should it be?
—I do not know why it should be. It is positive discrimination in favour of one sex against the other. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
