SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BUDGET STATEMENT AND PAPERS 1986-87

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 August, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Senate take note of the statement and papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition was anxious to start the debate on the Budget this week before the Government scurries off for three weeks endeavouring to sell it to the Australian people. When we come back in a month's time, I suspect that the Budget will be so irrelevant to what is happening in Australia that we will be debating other issues of more immediate significance.

SPEECH.PARA: The sad reality for Australia is that the Government has brought down a Budget of despair. I call it that because it does not address, and certainly will not solve, the problems we face. It is not the Opposition saying that we have fundamental problems, it is the Government itself which has described our economic situation as being a state of crisis. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said that we are in a crisis akin to war. He has turned around and claimed that this is a Budget for hope. Yet, if we look at what the Government is predicting in this Budget we see no signs of the hope that the Prime Minister sought. It promises more of the same or worse for Australia. If one looks at the Government's own predictions in the Budget one sees that we will have higher unemployment, for example. It says that we will have the same dramatic balance of payments crisis as has bedevilled us over the past 12 months. We will have another balance of payments deficiency of probably more than $14 billion. The Government tells us that we will have declining investment, and that, of course, is the surest sign of the failure of its economic policy. We have had now three quarters of declining investment. We are told that we have another year of declining investment ahead of us. We have a high rate of inflation-8 per cent is tipped by the Government. That is 16 times the inflation in Japan, and it is many time the inflation rate of our trading partners. The Government itself predicts a lower rate of growth. Given that that is the Government's own prediction, Mr President, I ask you: How can this be described as a Budget of hope? Surely it can better be described as a Budget of despair.

The Prime Minister started off in government with what he described as a crisis. He said in his address to the nation in 1983: `We started with an economic crisis'. In the same address to the nation he said: `Well, here we are, three years later, and we have a crisis which is just as bad'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much worse.

—I am glad for the assistance. I happen to agree that it is a much worse crisis because in 1983 we had the difficulty of a world recession and a drought. We have none of those excuses available to us today. The question that has to be asked is: Could the Government have offered an answer to Australia's crisis? Is there a way out? The Opposition believes very firmly that there is a way out.

SPEECH.PARA: In the House of Representatives last night, in a speech I commend to all honourable senators, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard, made the point in the opening of his speech that there are six major reforms and changes of direction needed if there is to be any hope of the Australian economy being turned around. He said that reforms have to be made to reduce government spending, to reduce taxation, to reduce union power, to provide incentive for employees, to encourage overseas investment, and to improve our transport and communications systems. I respectfully adopt those six points as being points which, if this Government pursued them, would see a quite different set of predictions being made about what the future holds for Australia.

Clearly, what has to be done, what is needed at the moment, is that we have to overcome our fundamental problem of buying more than we can sell. That really is the basic problem that Australia has. Everything else is either a cause of that problem or a symptom of that problem. The cure of that problem is to sell more abroad and to make more of what we use in Australia. We do not do that for the very simple reason that in too many areas others are doing better than Australia. They can produce things more competitively and cheaply. So the questions have to be posed: What can the Government do about that, what can we do about that, and how do we reverse that situation? We have no choice but to produce our way out of our difficulties, to produce more and to produce more efficiently. This Budget does nothing to achieve that.

The one thing that this Budget sets out to do-on paper it does that, although I do not believe that on analysis it will achieve it-is to promise a lower deficit. But the outcome of that promise is quite dubious. The lower deficit seems to be designed for only one purpose and that is to satisfy the money market. Already over the few days since the Budget, it seems pretty clear that that purpose is failing. The Budget growth forecasts have been soured because, as the Australian Financial Review reports this morning, there has been a negative response from the financial markets, and the trade-weighted value of the dollar fell again yesterday from 50.5c to 50.3c. Already the single objective that is discernible from the Budget seems to be faltering if not failing. I suppose the Government might say that in the search for a lower deficit, it was also seeking to reduce interest rates and that that would contribute to helping Australia produce and sell more. But again, the early indications are that the prospects for that do not look bright. Again, we have had an early market reaction which is poor.

I pose the question: How can you expect interest rates to improve, how can you expect the money market to be firm in a situation where the Government itself is saying that we can expect another year of 8 per cent inflation and that we can expect another year of about $14 billion of a current account deficit? It seems to me that those two facts guarantee high interest rates in Australia, certainly interest rates will be well in excess of our trading partners, and from our competitive point of view that is very damaging. If the lower deficit that the Government is promising does not deliver a more stable dollar and lower interest rates, of course the Budget is a complete failure. It is perhaps instructive to look through the Budget Papers to see what the Government thinks will happen to interest rates. It is normal that it should not try to predict the position of the dollar, but certainly we find that the Budget Papers are silent on interest rate prospects. I suspect that that was a very wise position for the Government to adopt because of the fundamentals that this Budget puts down.

With this deficit prediction are doubts, not only about whether it is accurate but also about the way in which the deficit reduction is to be achieved. The Opposition was, of course, seeking a reduced deficit. We believe that that is an important step for the Government to achieve if we are to have economic recovery, but we argued that that deficit should be achieved by reducing expenditure. It will find that instead of achieving that reduced deficit by reducing expenditure, it will simply have increased taxes. It has added another $1.4 billion of new taxes in this Budget. It has also cribbed another $650m by delaying the cuts it promised to the Australian people in income tax as part of the income tax package. So there is more than $2 billion of this deficit reduction which can be accounted for by increases in taxation. That is one of the fundamental reasons why this deficit has not been well received by the people of Australia and not well received by the markets which are both marking down our dollar and marking up our interest rates. The markets have made their judgment adversely, but even if we get a situation where interest rates ease-one would express the hope that we do-individuals and businesses will see any benefits from lower interest rates removed by higher taxes and charges.

I have already stated that the Government itself is saying that it accepts that there is no recovery as a result of this Budget. It is predicting less investment, it is predicting more unemployment and it is predicting lower growth. As individuals, Australians face higher taxes, more unemployment, and the same endless concern about the dollar because of our balance of payments. The fundamental flaw in the Government's position in August 1986 is that it seems to have forgotten that the Budget is only one element of what is required if the position is to change for the better.

If we are to get economic recovery it requires a renewal of investment and activity. It requires the people of Australia to work harder and more effectively. In fact, the Government has left in place all the obstacles which exist to those ends. A person who might be contemplating starting a new business, a person who might be contemplating expanding an old business, a person who might be wanting to make something new or make a product which will better compete with the imports which are flooding into Australia, or making a product that could be sold overseas, needs to see all these things happening. However, for those people all the negatives of recent years are still in place. Indeed, in many cases they have been made worse by the Government.

We have made no secret of our view in regard to the range of issues which have to be tackled if those problems are to be removed and the economy is to assume a growth path. For the guidance of the Government, as much as for the Australian people, we set out in our document entitled `Policies for Business' a summary of the broad requirements which we say would lead to economic recovery. They express in a slightly different form the six points made by John Howard in his Budget address last night. We said that taxes must be substantially reduced and restructured, and in order for this to be possible government spending must be cut at the Commonwealth, State and local levels. We said that the level and cost of regulation of business activity and decision making must be reduced dramatically and across the board. We said that trade unions in general and some trade union leaders in particular must be brought back within the rule of law and monopoly privileges of trade unions must be curtailed. Finally, we said that business input costs, especially those resulting from government taxes and charges, must be reduced wherever possible. Those are quite simple prescriptions. They are clear prescriptions for what needs to be done if Australia is again to be a good country in which to invest and do business. That is a pre-condition for economic recovery. The tragedy is that this Budget on the face of it does little, if anything, to advance even one of those four requirements. It might be argued that in total there is some minor reduction in government spending, although, in fact, once again this is a very high spending Budget. It is a Budget which will spend more of the gross domestic product than any of the Fraser Budgets, for example. Of course, the Budget is also a very high taxing Budget. Therefore, we have a situation in which the Government has not responded to what is evidently needed.

The surprising thing about this situation is that within the Government there has been an acknowledgment of virtually every point that the Opposition has made. If one looks particularly at what has been said by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, over the last three years, and certainly over the last year, one will find in his speeches and interviews an acknowledgment that these are reasons why the Australian economy cannot grow and why we cannot get manufacturing industry into better shape in Australia. But the problem is that the Government has not responded to that acknowledgment. It has not delivered on what it has acknowledged is required. Today I must, as I have done elsewhere on other occasions, repeat my complaint that Senator Button has analysed our problems and yet continued to be part of a government which is either unwilling or unable to solve those problems. That is not just an Opposition view. Yesterday I noted in the Australian Financial Review an article by Mr McGuinness, writing from the distance of London-perhaps distance lends clarity in this case-saying:

There is nothing in the Budget to indicate the Government has taken practical steps to deal with the serious situation it has acknowledged. The Budget's failure is epitomised in the absurdly inadequate proposed discounting of wage indexation.

Mr McGuinness actually goes on to pay a compliment to the Government. He says in the article that this Government, better than any of its predecessors, understands where the problems lie. However, that is sad because he goes on to say of the Government:
It just does not have the resolution, or the political base, to offer real cures.

I think that that is the tragedy of the situation. There appears to be a capacity within the Government to analyse the problem, to understand it and to express it, but a total lack of capacity to do anything about it. In a very real sense 1986 is a year of opportunity. It is a year in which the Government could act in a resolute way. In this Budget, as in the address to the nation of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Government clearly is incapable of resolute action.

Probably the most important area to be tackled if we are to change the scene in Australia is in reform of the labour market. That is outside the strict confines of the Budget, but certainly what is required should be acknowledged in the Budget and a direction should be set for the guidance of the Australian people. In the last few weeks we have seen a whole lot of very well advertised examples of what we mean when we say that there are things wrong with the labour market in Australia. We are not talking just about wages, because the argument is not really about whether we should be a low wage country; that is absurd. The argument is whether we should be an efficient country.

I refer honourable senators to the sorts of silly things done in our labour market and publicised over the last few weeks in relation to Robe River Ltd in the course of its dispute with the unions. That company has reported to us that it is faced with a situation in which unions insist that five employees have to be available on the site for the operation of a machine designed to be operated by two persons. What chance has Australia got when it is required that five people operate a machine that needs only two? Also we find that in order to replace a discharged fire extinguisher after normal hours, somebody has to be called out and paid for four hours at double time. It costs $80 to replace a fire extinguisher. One could go on and on. The only other example I want to cite in the long list of the ridiculous work practices plaguing that single enterprise is that the company is required to have trucks watering the roads to keep down the dust even when it is raining. Those examples are typical of why this country is failing and why it is going down the tube. It is typical of the sort of thing that this Government should be trying to root out and about which it is doing little or nothing. Every Australian knows that Australia is littered with this sort of insanity. Such practices are far more significant than even the stoppages which enrage the population when they see once again our economic future being frittered away.

In the removal of those work practices, it is of course true that management has a key role in working with the work force to get rid of them. It requires a common commitment from employer and employee. However, the point I am concerned about in respect of this Budget is that the Government has not even given a decent lead. Look at the history of the last two weeks. When Robe River management tried to bring these work practices to an end, it really set about doing that in a very vigorous way, and a lot of people were stood down. The Government immediately condemned Robe River for being peremptory. Yet when in the same period elements of the work force hijacked and took over a rig on the North West Shelf we heard not one word of condemnation from this Government. That is typical of the stupid way that this Government behaves in trying to deal with these matters. The Government is quick to condemn management for moving quickly in trying to remove ridiculous work practices; it is silent over the action of trade unionists in taking over an off-shore platform on the North West Shelf.

It is quite true that the Government has acknowledged this problem, just as it has acknowledged so many other problems. It is also true that it has taken some minor steps to do something about it. I want to touch on that matter because it is typical of where the Government is failing. Let us look at what it has decided to do about heavy engineering. The Government is providing $60m worth of assistance to the heavy engineering industry. One of the conditions of that assistance is that over the next three years there has to be a removal of restrictive work practices that prevent the industry being competitive. In other words, the Government is saying to the industry: `Go away and, over the next three years, work at removing those practices and we will put in $60m of taxpayers' money to help you along'. What sort of future has Australia got if we have to spend three years working out and removing restrictive work practices from one narrow segment of Australian industry and paying taxpayers' money as a bribe at the same time? We cannot afford to buy ourselves out of this insanity in that way. We have to get on with the job and abandon the sort of piecemeal approach which is being adopted by this Government. It is absurd to have to pay taxpayers' money to achieve common sense.

The critically important thing in 1986 is that the Prime Minister has told us that we are in a crisis akin to war. In a war one does not have time for year after year of negotiations; nor does one have the money to put down as government subsidies to achieve efficient work practices across Australian industry. This is a job that has to be done quickly and dealt with urgently. We need a sense of urgency from the Government.

Earlier this week I was talking with Simon Crean on a radio program. What I found in him was a commitment to a process of negotiation-not between employers and employees but between employers and trade union officials. What I was particularly struck by was his general emphasis on trade unions and on the idea that we have endless time to negotiate away these problems. The Opposition believes that we have to get away from the situation in which institutional trade unions, which have no particular interest in the success of a particular venture, are involved in decisions which affect the very survival of both the business and the jobs it provides. In this absolutely vital area it is almost impossible to get a serious and sensible debate in this chamber because the Government always tries to polarise any debate which is brought forward by the Opposition. It is impossible to get a civil, and it is certainly quite impossible to get a thoughtful, response from the Government when these issues are raised in this place.

I draw the Government's attention again to the concerns raised by Mr Charles Fitzgibbon in his papers to the Economic Planning Advisory Council and the Productivity Promotion Council of New South Wales, in which he has made it clear from his ex-trade unionist viewpoint that the system is unlikely to improve until the incentive structure is changed. In this debate I suppose one could quote 100 passages from Mr Fitzgibbon's two papers because they contain so much good sense; they contain so much urging of the Government to look at the problem of incentive in the Australian work force. Let me quote a few lines:

There are a number of practical steps to be made to improve productivity, but the most important is the development of a concept of positive incentives and a positive sharing of responsibility at the enterprise and/or industry level.

We find in the Opposition's papers a clear commitment to that sort of principle. Can honourable senators remember when a Government Minister or a Government senator last responded to our concerns in this area by dealing positively with that principle? Where do we find any recognition of it in the Budget? There is none. We have a vital issue here that is central to our economic recovery, but the Budget is totally silent on it, just as the Government is pursuing it in a leisurely way but generally it is woefully inactive. I repeat the point which I think is central in August 1986: We do not have 10 years in which to solve Australia's problems. We face another $14 billion deficit this year and we face a $100 billion plus foreign debt by the end of this year. These are not the reckless predictions of an Opposition seeking office; these are the predictions of the Government itself in its Budget statement. We are, in the Prime Minister's words, in a situation akin to war, and we do not have 10 years in which to negotiate.

The other vital issue-again it is impossible to get a thoughtful response from the Government on this-is the structure of business taxation. When we talk of business dismay at the fringe benefits tax the only response we get in the Senate is in terms of abuse of fringe benefits by high income earners. The Opposition has never denied that there have been abuses of fringe benefits. We make the point that those fringe benefits received by high income earners could be assessed by the Commissioner of Taxation under the present law, and they should be. But the position of the Government is that it responds on this issue by concentrating on that point alone. I have yet to hear in the Senate a Government Minister or a back bench senator address the concerns of employers such as Mount Isa Mines or the other employers in remote areas of Australia who face crippling new burdens which are going to make them uncompetitive in a very difficult international trading environment. I do not hear a single honourable senator acknowledging the deep concerns of those essential producers in Australia, and I do not hear any concern expressed by Government senators about the fact that Australians who are trying to export services-engineering services, for example-now have to pay a fringe benefits tax on the cost of putting an Australian engineer, for example, into a foreign country. That is an economic absurdity, but I never hear it acknowledged or addressed by the Government.

What we have from the Government is a cheap political response, even though Australian Labor Party leaders at the State level have joined the Opposition and the business community in crying out for relief. If we are to have a Budget of hope, we have to find a resurgence of entrepreneurial spirit and drive in this country. It is absolutely absurd for the Government to be saying that it wants a resurgence of entrepreneurial spirit and drive and at the same time to be imposing a new capital gains tax and a new fringe benefits tax. It is absurd for the Government to be imposing the highest taxing Budget we have seen ever. More than a quarter of our gross domestic product is being taken by the Government in taxation, and this is the third year in a row that it has achieved that record. It is pathetic to think the Government could expect a more positive business response, but of course the Budget acknowledges in relation to the declining investment that it does not expect a positive response. The Government itself is telling us that business investment will decline.

The fourth area we identify as needing government attention is that of regulation. Once again, the Government's rhetoric acknowledges the problem. It has again taken some small steps. It has set up a business regulation unit. That is doing some valuable work in co-operation with private enterprise; we support and encourage that. But during the same year as that Business Regulation Review Unit has been operating we find that the Government is passing amendments to the Trade Practices Act and additional amendments to the Companies Code; it is adding to the weight and burden of regulation. It has done that over the objections of the Opposition, and in this Budget we get no promise of any turning back.

The tragic aspect of the failure of this Government and of its policies, both in the Budget and in related areas, is that the supposed economic rationalists among the Ministers have all acknowledged the reality of the points I have made today in criticism of this Budget. They seem to be incapable of developing a coherent strategy which would enable them to overcome the difficulties we face. That is a criticism which has to be laid particularly at the feet of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, who is responsible for manufacturing industry. As I said earlier, he has been quick to identify problems, but it is a matter of great regret to us that he has been incapable of getting the Government to take his concerns into account. What we have seen in this Budget is simply a repeat of the sorts of sorry reversals of industry policy that occurred during this last year.

One of the features of the Budget as far as business is concerned is that the Government made decisions on bounties; it made some across the board reductions in bounties. I point out to the Senate that Senator Button has been stating that a principle on which his industry policy is based is that there should be a more neutral industry structure, there should be predictability, and there should be gradual change. What do we find in the Budget decision? We find a decision which I think was obviously embarrassing to Senator Button, if honourable senators recall his demeanour in Question Time yesterday. He admitted that the reductions in bounties were a pure revenue decision; it was just a way of raising more revenue. It had nothing to do with having a coherent industry strategy. It was not based on the principles the Minister has put forward. If it had been based on them, we can assume that at the same time as the Government cut bounties it would have cut tariffs across the board in the same way. But no, it is only in the area where the Government can make an expenditure saving that it has made a cut. In areas such as tariffs, where it raises taxes, industry has been left in the same position.

So what we have in this decision is an exacerbation of the disparities in assistance to industries, and we have a flying in the face of the Government's supposed support for bounties as a valuable method of assisting industry. When Minister Button introduced a bounties Bill earlier this year he said:

The Government has attached and will continue to attach considerable importance to bounties as one of the key elements in its industries assistance policy of providing direct support to industry against import competition.

Of course, the Budget decision makes a mockery of that. It flouts the intention of section 23 of the Industries Assistance Commission Act, which states that these matters should go to the IAC for examination and report before the decisions are made. In the view of the Opposition, this decision will put back the agenda for bounty assistance by 20 years. Producers will want tariff protection because they have now seen the vulnerability of bounties to ad hoc action by government. Bounties are preferable to tariffs because they do not distort prices and their cost is visible, but the latter point is now being exploited by the Government. It has managed to save a little money at a cost to industries which had been told that they would be given consistent treatment by this Government. At a time when we seek to encourage manufacturing industry I say that the Government cannot expect industries to respond to the lower deficit outcome, if that is achieved, if it shows that the principles of its industry policy are without authority. I believe Senator Button's word will not again be accepted so readily in the business community, in light of that decision. It is exactly the same as the undermining of the Government's industry policy with respect to motor vehicles. The fringe benefits tax introduced by the Government has clearly damaged the Government's vehicle plan. We have another example of the Government having a policy moving in one direction which is undercut and subverted by another.

Before finishing my speech I want to touch on what I think is the other major deficiency in this Budget, that is, its total failure to address the issues of social policy which are fundamental to our recovery as a country. What I find about this Budget when I search for some sense of social direction is not that it is setting a bad direction but rather that it is setting no direction at all. I do not think it would be possible to read this Budget and to determine what attitude this Government has to the sort of society we should have in Australia and what the social impact of this Budget will be on individual Australians. (Extension of time granted). There is no social direction achieved in this Budget. Indeed, if one looks at it from the point of view of the individual, the only thing one can find in the Budget is that it is a Budget about trimming living standards. The Government says in the Budget. `This Budget trims living standards'. So I suppose one could say that is one of the social impacts.

My concern is that in a situation where the Government is predicting an even more difficult economic situation for individuals, it is highly necessary that the Government should express some view about what support it is prepared to offer the families of Australia, which represent the best protection for individuals against the difficulties of change and economic hardship that this Government is imposing. I express particular concern about the way this Government has continued to whittle away the position of families. Because I do not wish to delay the Senate let me merely quote from some of the information which was sent to us all by the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission under the heading `A Fair Go For Families'. It makes the point that in the last 10 years the amount of income tax imposed on a family with four children living on average weekly earnings has increased by 435 per cent, while wages have increased by only 135 per cent. It goes on a little later to say:

The deteriorating economic position of Australian families is also clearly seen when one compares over time the disposable share of earnings enjoyed by families. In two years time an average weekly earner with a dependent spouse and five children will have nearly 9 percentage points less in disposable share of earnings than an average earner with the same number of dependants had in 1977. In contrast, an average weekly earner with no dependants will have 2 percentage points less in disposable share of earnings, and a taxpayer with no dependants earning three times the average weekly wage will have 3 percentage points more in disposable share of earnings.

We have a situation-this has been much debated in the Senate over recent years-where the economic position of families relative to income units in the community without family responsibilities continues to decline. I support the view which the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission has put forward and the Opposition supports the view that the family is the primary unit of support and nurture for individuals and that it is the family which deserves some attention in this and, indeed, in other Budgets. We find in John Howard's Budget reply a clear acknowledgment of the need for the tax system to differentiate in favour of families. I challenge this Government to consider the declining position of families and to consider what impact that will have on the operations of Australian society. I believe that the health of Australia goes beyond the growth of our gross domestic product. It also involves looking a little more closely at the situation of Australians who are trying to maintain their own standards of living and their dependence within a family structure.

We believe that Australia can be restored to prosperity. We believe, as John Howard said at the end of his Budget speech last night, that this can occur only if there are substantial changes to existing institutions and attitudes. John Howard went on to say:

This is the hope for all Australians. We can offer hope through a greater commitment to individual freedom, through a greater commitment to greater individual choice and through a greater commitment to greater individual incentive.

The tragedy of this Budget is that it offers hope to no one. The Government, having analysed Australia's ills, stands condemned for having totally failed to deliver a solution to those ills. I believe that this is a thoroughly bad Budget which is completely inadequate for Australia's current needs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is heading for disaster unless there is an immediate and dramatic change of government policy. The radical free marketeers who currently dominate the Australian Labor Party have brought this country to the brink of bankruptcy. Spending in this Budget has been slashed in education, health, welfare and general services. The domestic economy is being strangled in an attempt by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to please his new constituents-the overseas money markets. The Budget calls for a domestic surplus of $800m. The last time we had a domestic surplus in this country was back in 1981-82. It led to massive unemployment, followed by an 11.5 per cent inflation rate. In 1981-82 we vigorously opposed the policy of the government of the day in taking money out of the Australian economy and we vigorously oppose the same policy in 1986-87. If Australia is to regain control over its own destiny it must start to manage the economy. The Labor approach is simply this: Let market forces reign supreme. The Australian Democrats say that this is a recipe for disaster.

SPEECH.PARA: The concept of managing the economy in the interests of all Australians was criticised yesterday by Senator Michael Baume as being old fashioned. As we all know, the prophet of the market forces philosophy was no less a person than Milton Friedman. I well remember his first visit to Melbourne and his first lecture in this country. I was invited as a guest, along with the Treasurer of the day, John Stone and other distinguished representatives of the Treasury. Milton Friedman expounded his monetarist theory. All we had to do, he said, was to control the rate of growth of the money supply and everything else would follow. `Do not worry about anything but controlling the rate of increase in the money supply. Do not worry about controls in the economy. Do not even worry about the trade union movement. Regulate the money supply and everything else will follow'. It was so simple it is no wonder that the Treasury fell for it, hook, line and sinker.

It appears that Senator Michael Baume has not yet caught up with the fact, and obviously neither has the Labor Party, that responsible universities around this country are now telling their students of economics that Milton Friedman has been exposed as a charlatan. The University of Edinburgh carried out some fundamental research on the monetarist theory and found that the data on which that theory is based was fudged, made up by Milton Friedman so that he could go around the world trying to persuade governments to go back to the concepts of the early nineteenth century-the laissez-faire concept, the survival of the fittest. `Do not interfere under any circumstances with those who are making money.' I suggest that those who are out of date are Senator Michael Baume and the Labor Party-150 years out of date.

Last night Mr Howard committed the Opposition to further reductions in government spending and the encouragement of overseas investment. I ask: How does this policy differ from that of the Labor Party, which Party no doubt will allow Nicholas Kiwi Ltd to be taken over by the Sara Lee company? Nicholas Kiwi just happens to be one of Australia's most successful international companies. In the Australian Parliament now we have the `Liborals' and we have the Democrats. The Democrats are not a socialist party, as we have been criticised for being by the Liberals. We believe that capitalism can work-providing it is managed. The Democrats are the only party that has come up with a carefully costed alternative Budget. We do not jump on bandwagons. We have carefully thought out our alternative strategy. Our proposed Budget shows how these policies could be implemented.

The Democrats' policies would stop the stampede of financial institutions to invest anywhere but in Australia. It would stop tanker loads of orange juice being imported from Brazil at subsidised prices while our oranges are falling to the ground in the Murray Valley. The Democrats' policy would ensure that precious capital available for investment is invested in productive wealth creating industries and is not being squandered on consumer products. We would strengthen the activities of the Foreign Investment Review Board to safeguard those Australian industries we still have left in this country from being sold at bargain prices while our currency is so depressed.

Australia's problems did not start in March 1983. The Hawke Government has made the problems worse through its total sell-out to the international financial community. Basically, Australia is trying to solve its problems and survive as an industrial country with Third World trade patterns. Increasingly this has become impossible. Since the beginning of 1984 our terms of trade have declined by 15 per cent. This has cost the nation $4.5 billion in constant terms. The prices of our exports have plummeted in line with the glut of energy, the slow growth of the major Western economies and the flooding of world markets with subsidised agricultural products from Europe, the United States of America and Brazil. The problem is that our exports are predominantly agricultural products and minerals and our imports are manufactured goods the prices of which have remained constant. Less than 20 per cent of our exports is made up of manufactured goods while in most Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries the level of manufactured goods exported is between 60 and 80 per cent. While we stick to this pattern of exporting predominantly agricultural and mineral products we are destined to live in a cycle of boom and bust. Clearly we are now at the end of the bust cycle.

The Labor and Liberal parties are putting forward the same solution. In a word, it is austerity. I should call it a response rather than a solution because austerity budgets have never solved anything. Austerity budgets are a knee-jerk reaction of conservative governments to difficult situations. They are based on an ideological fervour rather than on rational plans to turn the economy around. The Government says that we must cut our consumption and increase our savings. This, the theory goes, will reduce our demand for exports and help us develop import replacing and export orientated industries to ensure that we pay our way in the world. Consumption will be cut; there is certainly no doubt about that. However, it will be cut in a very inequitable manner. There will have to be increases in indirect taxes and that, of course, will affect everybody. The tax cuts have been delayed but on top of this wage earners are being asked to accept further discounts and social security recipients are being asked to take a cut in living standards. The Government's approach is to screw down the whole economy to reduce the economy's hunger for exports. In essence, the Government is attacking the economy instead of attacking the problem. This type of austerity will not encourage investment in this country; rather, it will have the opposite effect. Government investment and spending will decline, private spending will decline and private investment will decline.

It is clear that there are major institutional barriers to productive investment in this country and the Government has not been and is not now prepared to address them. We have only to look quickly at some statistics. Profits as a percentage of gross domestic product are higher in Australia than in any comparable Western country. In 1984 the share of profits in the Australian economy was 27.8 per cent. In Japan the comparable figure is 24 per cent, in West Germany it is 22.2 per cent, in the United States of America it is 19.1 per cent and in Sweden it is 18.5 per cent. There is nothing wrong with the profit share; the trouble is that productive investment in Australia is lagging. In 1985-86 investment in plant and machinery in this country fell by 7.1 per cent in real terms. However-and this is the crux of the problem-the money soaked up in takeovers jumped alarmingly. In 1984 takeover funds totalled $1.2 billion. In the first half of 1986 $7.7 billion was used in the takeover battle for the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd alone. Goodness knows what the final figure will be for this year when we add the Repco takeover and the attack on the ACI company, to name just a couple, to the takeover attempts on BHP. Where has all this money gone? Almost certainly it has gone back into the share market and not into productive investment.

In the last 12 months the turnover of the share market has almost doubled. If the stock market were to collapse suddenly all that paper money would be lost. We would have nothing to show for that investment in this country. On the other hand, if the investment had gone into productive areas, irrespective of what happened to the stock market productive capacity would still be available to be used in this country. Unfortunately we are applying more and more of our resources to the paper economy and starving the economy of real productive investment-investment in wealth creating industries. Takeovers are the most obvious manifestation of this bias towards paper investment.

The whole system is tilted in favour of takeovers. Under present laws a raider can always beat the market. The reason for this is very simple. If one buys a new machine one pays tax on the income that machine produces. If one expands by buying a company the income from that company, the dividend it pays to the raiding company, is tax free. In other words, due to the avoidance of sections 46 and 50 of the Companies Act one does not have to offset interest charges on the money that was borrowed to buy shares against income from those shares. This means there is an enormous disincentive to productive investment in Australia and taxpayers are subsidising the incentive to move towards paper investment and speculation.

The Government has not attempted in this Budget to find a solution to our investment problems. It has not tried to address any of the serious structural problems hindering industry development. It has merely stuck to the old, tired theory of crowding out, that is, the theory of the radical free marketeers. It simply says cut back on government expenditure and this will make room for private sector financial investment. People will be able to borrow money and invest in industry. This crowding-out strategy is so obviously flawed that I am amazed that any government subscribes to it in this day and age. Those who subscribe to the crowding out theory claim that government debt is too high. A quick look at the figures shows how ridiculous this approach is. In the 1920s, 1930s, 1940s and 1950s total government debt in Australia was equal to well over 100 per cent of gross domestic product. Today it has fallen to 44 per cent of gross domestic product. So our problem is not government debt; our problem is the misdirection of private investment. Investment is in paper profits and not in productive areas. There is obviously plenty of room for private investment. The problem is that that investment is not well directed.

It is the Government's responsibility to give a lead to the private sector and encourage investment but the opposite is taking place. Government outlays have fallen from 15 per cent of total outlays in 1976 to 7.5 per cent of total outlays in 1985-86. Therefore, the Government is allowing the infrastructure to run down. We cannot afford to do this. In the long term we will suffer if our roads, ports and railways are allowed to deteriorate. We will not be able to compete in international markets if we cut back on education and training. We will not prosper in the 1990s if we have run down our health system and have spent enormous amounts of money trying to salvage it when it is too late. We listen to the free marketeers at our peril. They are saying: `Divert valuable public resources from long term development to short term gain for individuals'. I hope we will not leave this legacy, this criminal attitude, to our children.

The Australian Democrats propose a better solution, one that is more equitable and one that attacks the problem more directly. We say that taxes should be levied on luxury imports, such as food, alcohol, motor cars and hi-fi equipment. Demand for imports would be slowed, our balance of payments would improve, local industry would be encouraged to expand and the burden of restructuring the economy would be more evenly borne if we directly restricted or discouraged the level of luxury importation items. Resulting price increases would be quarantined through wage discounting. The Government could then run a responsible, but not a contractionary, Budget policy. The money raised by an import tax could be used to provide low interest loans to export-orientated manufacturing industries, grants for research and development, and also for overseas marketing of Australian goods. We are not suggesting that this money should be given to industry with no strings attached. Industry would have to pledge itself to committing its own resources and unions would have to give assurances on increasing productivity through the scrapping of restrictive practices and the like.

Right now this country is being bled dry by the Labor Party's inspired deregulation of the financial system. Despite the fact that our terms of trade have declined by 15 per cent in the last 20 months, the value of our currency has plummeted by 45 per cent. The Labor Party did not float the dollar; it sank it like a stone. Every time the speculators send the value of the dollar down, of course our problems increase enormously. Our foreign debt grows, our balance of payments gets worse and we enter a downward spiral, driven by the paranoia of the money markets. The Government has reacted to this problem simply by pandering to money markets and to the prejudices of those markets, rather than by developing a strategy to get us out of this situation.

To protect the currency and increase investment, the Government must restrict superannuation funds from moving off-shore. Right now, a total of $8 billion-an enormous amount of money-of superannuation funds has been invested overseas. The AMP Society has plans to shift a further $1 billion off-shore in this financial year. If the Government is serious about encouraging savings to be invested in this country, it should not allow superannuation funds, which represent the savings of all Australians, to be moved off-shore. In essence, the new direction that the Democrats are advocating is to manage our economy, to encourage savings and to encourage productive investment. The policy is quite simple and very straightforward. But if we do not follow it, we will be doomed to bankruptcy.

How can we encourage Australians to save more and spend less on wasteful investments? One way it could be done is to follow what was done in Japan. The Japanese Government simply told individuals: `We will allow interest on your savings in savings accounts tax free up to a certain level'. That is a very simple approach. What happened in Japan? Immediately there was an enormous increase in the amount of savings in the community. That gave a base for the Japanese economy to borrow money overseas, invest dramatically in its industries and expand its productive capability. We must export. We must develop industries that are internationally competitive. Has the Government given any real lead in this direction? The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, has made certain suggestions about how we can go about encouraging our export-orientated industries. My criticism of the activities of Senator Button at this point is that we have seen very little action. I have listened to Senator Button espouse his plans for industry. I have yet to see them being put into action.

We must do something about employee parti- cipation. We must encourage an environment in which employees can use their abilities, and are encouraged to use their abilities, during the eight-hour working day to improve the efficiency of the industries in which they work. It can be done, but it means a fundamental change of attitude in this country. We must break down the confrontation between management and the worker. We must get rid of the idea that the boss says `You're being paid by me to do what you're told,' while the worker says `I'm not going to use my brain power to make money for the boss'. We must achieve a co-operative attitude. As I mentioned once before in this place, the Toyota company last year processed no less than 1.9 million suggestions from employees. All of those suggestions were processed by small group activity-small groups of people of 10 or less, during working hours, who considered the suggestions and made recommendations to management. Management in the Toyota organisation acted on 90 per cent of those suggestions. The greatest genius of all time could not come up with 1.9 million suggestions to improve the efficiency of an industry. That sort of co-operative approach, that worker participation, that involvement of the work force in how companies are being managed, is absolutely essential if our industries are to become export-orientated and efficient by world standards, so that this country can stand on its own feet.

Japan had a problem after the war. In 40 years it has built an industrial machine that is the envy of the world. It now produces more motor cars than the United States. It produces 56 per cent of the steel used in the United States. We can do it in Australia. But we will not do it unless the Government manages the economy and says that it has a responsibility to co-operate with industry, to give it a lead, to find out the best and most cost effective ways in which industry can be developed to export to the world. Industry should look at the world as being its potential market.

I was recently in Tasmania. I looked over the Repco Bearing Co., which is a very efficient organisation. I have no doubt that if there were government assistance, and round table discussions between government, industry leaders, the trade union movement and the workers in that plant, they could come up with a very cost effective strategy to export the products from that factory in Tasmania all around the world. It requires very little to become a little more competitive, to achieve a price structure that enables organisations to export.

We are very short of foreign currency. What has the Government done in discussions with the tourist industry? Queensland possibly has the capacity to double its tourist intake in a very short while. That would be a very quick way of earning foreign currency. Has the Government sat down with the leaders of the tourist industry in Queensland to find out what is the most cost effective way of doubling the tourist industry in that State, and in Western Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you ask some of these questions at Question Time and then you would get an answer, instead of asking rhetorical questions?

—I always get an answer. But my comments today are directed at the Government for inaction. We hear the rhetoric. We are told about the plans the Government has, but there is no action. We are debating the Budget today. In this Budget no money has been allocated to encourage employee participation. No money has been allocated for technology transfer. There is no suggestion about how the Government will tackle our balance of payments problem, short of screwing down the whole economy so that our demand for exports will drop. This will make the whole community suffer. The Government is attacking the economy as a whole rather than attacking the problem directly.

SPEECH.PARA: The approach which the Australian Democrats advocate is not novel. The Japanese economy has always been managed yet I do not hear the Liberal and National Party members accusing the Japanese economy of being socialist. Every time I say in this place that there has to be co-operation between management, governments and workers, I am accused of being a socialist. I am simply saying that we cannot sit back and let market forces run the country. Unbridled capitalism is the most destructive force one can imagine. The power of undirected money impinges on the poor and weak. That is a cruel approach.

If individual enterprise is encouraged and given the opportunity to expand, it will save this country. The individual entrepreneur and the person with an idea that can be developed and sold around the world are what Australia needs now. They have not had encouragement. We shall never have that encouragement unless the Government changes its fundamental approach and is prepared to accept a change of philosophy and say: `We have to pick winners in industry. We have to find which industry has the best potential dramatically to increase its export activities.' When those industries are identified, the Government has to sit down with them and say: `Right. What can we do to ensure that this potential is dramatically increased?'

We are in an emergency akin to a state of war. In 1943 and 1944, the Government was forced to say to those manufacturing industries that had the capacity to increase defence production: `How can we help you to double your output? Do you need this machine tool? Do you need that raw material?' When agreement was reached, the Government made sure, through low interest loans and by other means, that those potential industries could expand quickly. That must happen now. No single broad brush policy can develop our export industries quickly. But there is a fundamental principle-co-operation among government, industry and employees with round table discussions so that the Government moves into what is most cost-effective. If the Government does not do that-there is no sign, and certainly not in the Budget, that it is about to do so-Australia is doomed to bankruptcy. A contractionary budget, such as the one we have just had, will exacerbate the problem, screw the whole economy down, create massive unemployment and increase interest rates. The cut in government spending will discourage investment in the private sector.

Although from time to time we hear some fine plans from the Government, I am afraid that the Government's fundamental policies are such-the Budget is an example-that no action will be taken. Limited reserves of foreign capital are available. Unless we husband those reserves and ensure that they are used to develop our export-oriented industries-manufacturing, farming, mineral and service-and ensure that our scarce capital resources are directed towards productive ends, Australia's future is bleak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with fascination to Senator Siddons's comments on the Budget. We heard for about 10 minutes how he thought that private industries should be protected, although he did not put it quite that way. It was fascinating, while recognising that the honourable senator is in that business, to hear him say that the Government should sit down to talk with private industries and look after them. I would prefer our industries to be lean, efficient and subject to market pressures. Many industries have survived and many will survive. Our biggest problem is that there is too much government involvement in the economy and the private sector, indirectly through government charges, imposts and regulations. I am sure that Senator Siddons's industry and most others would be better off if the Government got out of their board rooms-where the Government now is, albeit indirectly-and their pockets.

SPEECH.PARA: We are discussing the Budget which was handed down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on the night of Tuesday, 19 August. With all the hype, PR and propaganda, it is almost like Christmas-the whole nation seems to come to a halt waiting to hear the Budget. There are good reasons for that, of course. A budget is a blueprint that sets out a government's policies and economic management problems for the ensuing fiscal year. It has to do many things, taking into account the current position. With that in mind, I shall consider some of the problems facing this country dealing first with the economic problems. Our current account deficit is increasing by $1 billion a month. Our total overseas debt has doubled since Mr Hawke and Mr Keating took over the treasury bench-from $36 billion to more than $80 billion. We have the largest budget deficit that this nation has ever had. What does it all mean? I suppose that the figures are pretty large and that, to the ordinary man in the street, they are almost so large as to be meaningless and incomprehensible. It is hard to come to grips with a sum of the size of $80,000m.

Senator Lewis in a previous speech gave a good example. It is like an average family living in suburbia that decides that it wants a better standard of living. It goes to the various finance companies to borrow money. It puts in a pool and spa, landscapes, buys a new hi-fi set, air conditions the place and puts in a billiard room. The family then sits back and says: `Boy, this is really living. Why were we not doing this all along?' At the end of the month, letters come from the finance companies: `Your payments are due.' The family then sits down and thinks: `Gee. We are not even earning that much.' So the chickens quickly come home to roost. The high standards of living which they desired lasted only a little while. The family then has to sell off their goods, send people out to work, work extra time, and so on. That is what is happening with our nation. Just as that family was living well beyond its means, so is our nation.

One of the big problems is attitude. In Wednesday's debate I said that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), when he was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, had built up in the minds of the Australian people the belief that Australia was a utopian country and that they could have their piece of utopia without exerting too much effort. Unfortunately, when he became Prime Minister that utopian dream was still in people's minds. He did nothing to dispel it. In other words, one can have it all without much effort.

An Australian employer has to contend not only with salaries but with conditions, on costs and work practices the likes of which no employer in any other nation has to contend with. It is estimated that on-costs add up to about 80c for every dollar paid in wages. There has been a drawing back from that as employers have started to say: `Whoa. That is enough. We cannot afford it. If you want jobs, we have to sit down and make better arrangements.' I agree with Senator Siddons that, if we keep the Government out of it though, there should be better discussions between the work force and management.

We have had the Mudginberri, Dollar Sweets, Broken Hill and latterly, of course, Robe River disputes. I do not have to go over some of the silly practices that have come to light at Robe River-practices which nobody in his right mind should contemplate, let alone even think that a firm or a nation could afford. We have become known as the land of the long weekend. We seem to like to have those three-day holidays every chance we get. I instance Australia Day, which is supposed to be the great patriotic day for Australians. It so happens that it fell on a Sunday this year. That was not good enough. We were not really celebrating Australia Day, we wanted a long weekend, so we had the Monday off. That was an extra cost to employers and to the nation. We have our inevitable sickies. I doubt whether there is a country in the world where the sickie has become such folk lore. In a major industry in the last few weeks, at the same time that an employee's application for sick leave appeared on his supervisor's desk there appeared a photo in the local newspaper of the employee competing in a marathon run. He wondered why he was called in and asked whether he wanted to resign or be sacked. The sickie has become part of the folk lore of this nation.

We are a trading nation that is not competitive. That is probably a contradiction in terms, but in fact that is what we are. We are an unreliable, high cost, low productivity trading nation. It is a contradiction in terms, and we cannot survive if we go down that track forever. The Government makes much of the accord. I give the Government one point for the accord because it has stopped the excessive wage increases that would have occurred had it not been in place. However, I also take points off for the fact that the accord has sheltered the wage and salary earners of this nation from the reality of a broken economy. The accord has meant that wage and salary earners have received wage increases as the consumer price index has gone up. It is no wonder that employers, and John Howard last night, have called for a wages freeze. The accord has sheltered the people from the realities of the economic downturn in this country.

We have two problems-the economic problem and the attitudinal problem. The attitudinal problem, of course, is very long term. One of the main failures of the 1986-87 Budget is that it is seen by the Government as the only answer to our problems. We have had nothing from the Government which demonstrates that it recognises that there are other problems and that it is looking at a co-ordinated strategy. When the Prime Minister fought the 1983 election he campaigned on many things, but one of those was that he had a special relationship with the union movement and that, as such, he would have an influence with the labour movement that the Liberal and National parties did not have. That special relationship has not borne much fruit in respect of the attitudes of the union movement. Indeed, we have seen that attitude displayed by the Ministers in this Government. It was only a few weeks ago that they took to the newspapers to press their cases to the public on what they thought they should get out of the Budget. That attitude has gone right up into the top section of this Government.

I suppose we have all heard of the Boston Tea Party. It would not take much of an Einstein to come up with a theory of relativity on the Canberra cake party-that one cannot have larger slices out of an ever diminishing cake. Yet that is what the Ministers were after. It is no wonder that the Treasurer made his banana republic outburst. I firmly believe that he said that not so much for the public as to get over to his Ministers, with their insatiable appetites, the idea that there was an ever decreasing cake and they could not continue down the track they had been going down until then. Interestingly, when the Prime Minister returned he literally took over the economic spokesmanship from the Treasurer for a while. It was not too long after that that we had our call to arms as he saw his economic world crumbling around him.

One of the other problems about the attitudinal situation is that our education system is pretty incestuous. We have people there who have not experienced the real life of industry or farming or whatever. So we have students coming out of that system who think that the world owes them a living.

Senator Chaney in his comments indicated how the Budget debate was restricted. Unfortunately, this is something we have seen to a greater extent since this Government came to power, and never more so than this session, when a two-week sitting period was set down but has been reduced to one week. I agree with Senator Chaney that there is not much time for debate in this forum, where the matter should be debated, when we return after this one-week sitting. There will be plenty of other legislation around our ears. The reason for this one-week sitting is that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer want to get around the country to sell the Budget. All I can say is that the Prime Minister had better be a better salesman for his Budget than he was when he was a part owner of Bourke's Store or ACTU Travel.

I give the Labor Party points for the fact that it designed the Budget Speech to be an impact speech. In other words, it was a speech designed to make an immediate impact and get headlines the next day, before people woke up to the reality of it. The Government has done that before and it did it well this time. Even on Tuesday night one of the first things mentioned in the Treasurer's speech was the reduced deficit. The money market eased up, but within an hour, after we saw how that deficit would be arrived at, the market started to ease down again. One has to acknowledge that a reduced deficit of $3.5 billion is a laudable objective. The Opposition does not take the Government to task for the way it goes about it. The reduced deficit will mean reduced government borrowings, and that should ease the pressure on our already high interest rates. But that reduced deficit has been arrived at by a $2.6 billion profit from the Reserve Bank of Australia and, as other speakers have said, including Senator Chaney and Mr Howard, by increased taxation.

There has been an increase of 11 per cent in the Government's total tax take-up by $7.1 billion. That is now 28 per cent of gross domestic product. Last year it was 27.7 per cent of GDP. Interestingly, the average of the tax take to GDP for the Fraser-Anthony years was 22.5 per cent. That $7.1 billion could have been better used for productive purposes and private investment instead of being ripped out of the wealth creation part of the country and put into the stultifying public sector.

A closer analysis of the figures, which is what some of the economists are starting to do, gives quite a different story. The late Sir Phillip Lynch coined the term-he probably wished that he never had-`rubbery figures'. Mr Keating has given the term a whole new meaning. In the last Budget the dollar was forecast to be 68 on the trade weighted index. In reality, it dropped to 50. In the last Budget the GDP was forecast to grow by 3.7 per cent. If one takes out the Government sector, the non-productive sector, the private sector has shown a minus 0.4 per cent growth since the Hawke-Keating Government came to power. Interestingly, the total government sector as a percentage of GDP is now running at about 42 per cent when most economists say that an ideal figure is 25 to 26 per cent. Of course, the government sector is not just the Commonwealth Government, it is also State and local governments. Private non-fixed investment was forecast to grow by 5 per cent. In fact, it grew by 2.6 per cent. The current account deficit was to be $10 billion. It was actually $13.7 billion. No wonder analysts, economists and business are all questioning this Budget's figures and showing concern. During the Fraser-Anthony years debt servicing accounted for 8 per cent of our total export income. It is now running at 36.6 per cent and at the end of June 1987 it is expected to be 39 per cent. Those percentages, as well as our total overseas debt, really put us into third world status. The third largest outlay, of course, is public debt interest. It is behind only social security and payments to other governments, the States, et cetera. Ten per cent of this total Budget is for public debt interest-$7.5 billion.

There has been a promise to reduce the Public Service by 2,000. Interestingly, over the last three years since the Hawke-Keating Government came to power there has been an increase of 25,000 in the number of Commonwealth wage and salary earners, and the Government has promised to reduce it by 2,000. That, of course, does not take into consideration all those employment and job creation schemes to bolster the Government's employment figures which are, of course, funded by the taxpayer. At a very conservative estimate there would be over 100,000 employed in those various schemes. Despite all that, the Government is acknowledging that we are looking at a higher unemployment rate.

It has made much of its income tax reduction. That was mooted some time ago. That has already been deferred from 1 September to 1 December, but of course it will really be negated when we take into consideration the tax bracket creep, the fuel excise and all the rest. It is interesting to note that the fuel excise has increased by 140 per cent since March. For every litre of fuel that is bought, 23.9c goes to the Federal Government. That alone will mean an increase of 0.4 per cent in our inflation rate. That alone is more than the increased inflation rate of Japan or West Germany, two of our trading partners. It was Mr Keating who accused the Fraser-Anthony Government of making every petrol bowser a tax collection point. I bet he is rueing the day he ever said those words. The Fraser-Anthony Government was only an amateur. We now have sales tax on such things as flavoured milk and fruit juices. Whenever we go out to buy our lunch or our children go to a school tuckshop, we are all doing our bit to try to keep this Budget deficit down.

There is a 10 per cent increase in sales tax on luxury cars. Of course if there is going to be such a tax we cannot decry the fact that it is to be levied on luxury items, but how do we define a luxury car? There is no definition of that. All we have is an arbitrary figure of about $30,000, and of course that figure does not really bear any relationship to the cost of production or whatever because a lot of the cars, especially the most innovative cars, that are coming into this country are already loaded up with import duties. Indeed, I think we must recognise that if most cars were not coming in we would probably have a pretty poor type of car here that was not open to the world market situation. I can remember when our great manufacturers here were putting on the market powerful V8s with drum brakes, not really good suspension and cross-ply tyres. It is only because the continental cars particularly, and lately the Japanese cars have been coming in, with their innovative safety designs, improved economy, fuel injection, electronic ignition and all the rest, that the Australian manufacturers have sat up and tried to meet the market. As I said, I am not against sales tax on luxury cars, if there is to be one; but this is purely arbitrary. It is based on a dollar figure and it does not take into consideration the fact that those import duties are already there and already hurting the most innovative car manufacturers in the world.
It would be interesting to see how many rewrites there have been of this Budget and the Budget Speech in the last few weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not enough.

—Obviously not enough. But we can imagine that, as the economic indicators started coming in and the Government's world started crumbling around it, the midnight oil would have been burned very late many times as the Government went through many rewrites.
—You are not wrong, Senator. That is the first correct thing you have said.

—I knew that the honourable senator would be honest enough to acknowledge that. But the Government still has not got it right. As Senator Chaney said, there have not been enough rewrites. As the Right Honourable Ian Sinclair said, it is an Helena Rubinstein Budget-all cosmetic and too damn expensive. So we get back to the fact that we have this two-fold problem-an attitudinal problem and an economic problem-and unfortunately this Government still has not got past treating, albeit pretty shallowly, the symptoms and not the disease.

SPEECH.PARA: It is now in the hands of the Government, with its special relationship that it claims to have. I think it is really the responsibility of all of us, when we get around the countryside, to convince the people of Australia that Utopia, if it was ever there, is certainly not there now and that if they want it they will have to work damn hard for it. If we are going to keep going the way we are, our standard of living will suffer. We are a trading nation, and the Budget has been no help. Not one financial measure has been brought in since this Government came to power that has not hurt the productive, investment, manufacturing or export sectors of this country. It is like a horse trying to run in the Melbourne Cup with hobbles on. Both Senator Chaney and Mr Howard in their speeches have outlined the way we see that it should go, so I will not go down that track.

We have put policies in place and there are more coming out. The basic thrust of them is that we should get out of areas that the Commonwealth Government should not be in. We should be assisting those sectors that can revive us. If one is a dairy farmer and has a cow producing 7,000 or 8,000 litres and testing 4.2 per cent butterfat, one does not starve her; one looks after her and breeds from her. Yet what have we found with this Government? The very sector that can get this nation out of its problems has been starved and has been hurt. We have to reduce the Government's involvement. We have been told: `Man the trenches; put on our tin hats'. What is the use of being out in the front line? I do accept the fact that, if the people of Australia are given a proper challenge, if they are told where they are going and told what the problems are and if they can see daylight at the end of the tunnel, they will be prepared to man the trenches and put on their tin hats; but that is of absolutely no use if there are no logistics backing them up, if they are way out in the front line and there is nobody to supply them with what they need. What is more, in the supply area there would probably be somebody on strike anyhow.

I will say one thing for the Government: At long last it is recognising the problems. We do not now hear the claim that we have a strong and growing economy. It is recognising the problems, but unfortunately it has not come to grips with anything that might attack those problems. We still have the compliant attitude to the trade union movement. This was a Budget of despair, not hope, and it certainly was not a blueprint of good economic management. Australia will suffer further as a result of it.
Debate (on motion by Senator Button) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY EFFECTIVE SELF-GOVERNMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Senator Vigor, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
Introduction
It gives me great pleasure to present to the Senate the first Bill for the effective self-government of the Australian Capital Territory.

Since the passage of the Seat of Government (Administration) Act in 1910, control of most decisions relating to the A.C.T. has rested with a Minister of the Federal Parliament in whom the power to make Ordinances resided. This Bill seeks to vest that power effectively in the people of Canberra through a freely and democratically elected representative House of Assembly.
Effective self-government

The Australian Democrats want to see effective self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. In drawing up the terms of this Bill, we have consulted widely with the residents of Canberra and stuck closely to the principle that the national parliament should have as little opportunity to interfere in local decisions and events as possible.

I believe that the outcome meets square-on the fears and reservations of Canberrans, particularly in relation to finances and to the quality of administration. There is an understandable apprehension that somehow the transfer of powers will cause greater bureaucratic empire-building as local politicians seek to increase their prestige, at least among their peers. Let us be quite frank. Such wastage can always occur. By the same token, if the people of Canberra elect to their Assembly candidates of high quality who want to clean up current inefficiencies, a lot of good work can be done. That is the nature of democracy.

What is needed however, and what has been lacking to date, is a model which maximises Canberra's chances of carving out an effective voice for its residents, and minimises the chance that the current waste within administration will grow.

The contrast is between appropriate and effective self-government as the Australian Democrats are promoting, and a half-hearted Clayton's self-government, without local input, being touted by the government.
Essential features of effective self-government for the A.C.T.

There must be no large cost increases for Canberrans which means there must be a fair financial deal, a deal not easily susceptible to the more outrageous political whims of beleaguered national governments.
There must be a fair electoral system. We have chosen a quota preferential system with three electorates of seven members, with no by-elections.
There must be a staged transfer of powers.
There must be a thorough review and complete overhaul of the outdated legislation at Commonwealth expense.
The Assembly itself must be an effective voice for Canberrans, and not a body neutralised by illogical restrictions and out-dated or inconsistent legislation as in the government proposal.

The Assembly must be the genuine voice of all Canberrans, and not the plaything of any particular section of the community, or the bauble of any dominant faction within some political party. The Bill being introduced by the Australian Democrats meets all of these requirements and has the additional virtue that it has arisen from a process of consultation with the local Canberra community.
A staged introduction

We are proposing an orderly handover of powers to the people of the A.C.T. in three stages, so that after 1 January 1992, Canberrans will be to a large extent masters of their own destiny. At each stage, we want to make sure that the people of the A.C.T. have the resources to manage these powers effectively. We also want flexible administrative structures which open up options in decision making, rather than restricting them.
