All decisions are to be freely-made at the local level and not dictated from elsewhere or by outside influences. At the end of this process, we will leave the Commonwealth only the power to legislate in the national interest, but not to interfere capriciously in the running of the Australian Capital Territory. This will ensure that Canberrans are able to set whatever agenda reflects the community direction that they wish to take.
We are resisting in legislation the forces which have seen to it that well-thought-out recommendations of previous enquiries into self-government have been ignored.

The Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, of which Mr Howard was a member, released a report on ``Self-government and Public Finance in the Australian Capital Territory'' late in 1974. Its members set aside narrow partisan advantage and achieved a remarkable degree of agreement on how the A.C.T. should be run. In March 1975, Mr Howard made these remarks in the House of Representatives:

``I express the view that at all stages the Committee's deliberations on the form of self-government which should be adopted for the Australian Capital Territory were approached in a non-partisan way and in a non-political fashion. This exercise was perhaps the first time since Federation when a committee of any Parliament of Australia had had the opportunity, as it were, of starting from scratch and drawing up an outline of the form of self government for a part of the Australian Commonwealth.''

Similarly, in 1984 the members of the Craig Task Force on Implementation of A.C.T. Self Government concluded their extensive public enquiry and reported unanimously on the nature of A.C.T. government, financial arrangements and the electoral system. The then Minister for Territories and Local Government promised a government White Paper during the first half of 1985 when tabling the Craig Report in the Parliament. This did not happen, nor was there any effective local Australian Capital Territory input when the Hawke government started considering the matter and rejecting any proposal which left Canberrans with more than a pretence of a say in how decisions affecting their lives would be made.
The Hawke government produced a half-hearted proposal with thirteen single-member electorates, very few powers, limited privilege, and over-riding power of veto by the Minister.

The package which emerged from Cabinet's deliberations was rightly greeted with indignant derision almost universally throughout the A.C.T. The Canberra Times, a noted proponent of self-government, thundered:

``A belief, however firm, in the absolute necessity of self-government is not alone enough to engender support for the government's package. The package, in truth, is not self-government at all. It is simply another scheme of A.C.T. management, primarily by outsiders, dressed up to give the appearance, but not the reality, of local participation. It bears no resemblance to the different reasoned proposals which have emerged from various quarters over the past 73 years-even from the Labor party itself.''

Since that time, the ``insulting imposition'' in the form of a ``half-hearted system . . . almost designed to fail'', has been buttressed by nine pages of amendments which the government circulated too late for the Senate and House of Representatives to have any hope of reaching agreement.

That Bill has not been brought on for debate in the Senate, and yet the government is already talking about setting up an appointed Advisory Council. This would set the clock back before 1930 and undoubtedly attract the attention of the Human Rights Commission or its attenuated successor. They were obviously trying to fool the people of Canberra.

It is high time to question the Hawke government's bona fides in this whole process, and the Australian Democrats are doing so by offering a comprehensive constructive alternative. All the evidence suggests that the ALP really want to control the A.C.T. in perpetuity with only 40% support, and that significant sections of the Cabinet want the people of Canberra to be unable to make any important local decisions without outside interference.
Specific features of the Australian Capital Territory Effective Self-Government Bill.
Jervis Bay included

The 1974 non-partisan report of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory stated categorically that ``Jervis Bay come under the Authority of the A.C.T. Legislative Assembly''. All committee members agreed that it
``would be hard to justify the creation and administration of a separate body of law for such a small community''.

Yet in a time of national crisis, and major cuts in government services, we have a proposal to sever the Jervis Bay Territory for the first time since 1915. The Defence Department is already wasting thousands of dollars on environmental vandalism and plans to turn the area into a major nuclear port. This process should be halted immediately and attention turned to the northern parts of Australia which need better surveillance and other useful defence facilities. This Bill includes Jervis Bay in the Australian Capital Territory.
Assembly functions

I have already mentioned that the Assembly must be capable of discharging its duties effectively. It needs a legislative clean slate and proper financial resources. It also needs internal procedures which enable it to address Canberra's problems quickly and effectively. It must not be allowed to wither as an ineffectual body which has lost all community support because it can't achieve anything.

The Assembly will have to develop a reputation for doing things properly. We have given it the best chance possible by making membership full-time and ensuring that members concentrate on their public duties.
We shall not, as in the government Bill, exclude large numbers of residents from candidacy on frivolous grounds.
Self determined committees and standing orders

We shall not set arbitrary limits on how the Assembly conducts its business, and what powers its committee shall have, nor shall we seek to qualify the privilege with which members speak, or otherwise hamstring the operations of the Assembly. Members will answer to the people of the A.C.T. for the manner in which they discharge their responsibilities: they will not be able to shelter behind the claim that they inherited an iniquitous system from the national parliament.
Full powers by 1992

The Australian Democrats believe that from 1992, the Assembly should have potentially plenary powers to legislate for the `peace, order and good government' of the A.C.T. The Commonwealth should basically be restricted to legislating in the national interest, as is essential under the Constitution. This means that the Commonwealth will always be in the position of having to show how rather than relying on various powers of disallowance of laws or dismissal of the Assembly.
Health, education and planning by 1990

At the start of 1990, both the health and education functions will be transferred, along with the financially vital one of planning of land use and the development of land in all areas except those areas set aside by regulation because they have an over-riding national aspect. As a consequence, the National Capital Development Commission Act or its successor will have to be further revised at about that time.
Municipal powers immediately
From the election of the first Assembly, all of the usual municipal powers except those of planning will be transferred to the new body. Each such power is individually assigned by schedule.
Financial guarantees
This orderly transfer of powers will be matched by the wherewithal to manage them through the financial guarantees written into the legislation.

Every three years, the Commonwealth Grants Commission conducts a comprehensive review of A.C.T. finances under terms of reference which allow it to take full account of both Canberra's national capital status, and its very important regional role. For instance, nearly one-quarter of hospital bed use is made by people who do not live in the Australian Capital Territory, and there are other significant examples where the A.C.T. authorities provide services to a very large surrounding area.

The Commonwealth Grants Commission will also have regard to the sums that the Commonwealth makes available to the States and local government in determining the minimum amounts, in total, and in relation to functions transferred to the Assembly at that time. An indexing formula is applied for the two years between every re-evaluation and re-appraisal of the Commission's methodology.

A.C.T. residents are only too aware of how unreliable the word of this Government is after the sale of the Belconnen Mall. All Canberrans will welcome these fair financial guarantees being written into the legislation. They will then have time to organise if any threat of unreasonable federal action arises.
Review of all legislation

All Ordinances made after the inauguration of the House of Assembly will be presented to the Senate and House of Representatives along with a fair summary of the Assembly's views on the matter. It will be harder for Commonwealth Ministers to continue to treat the A.C.T. with the undisguised contempt they have shown in recent years.

For instance, in May 1985, on my motion, the Senate disallowed the hefty and unjustified increases in penalties imposed for trading in unauthorised hours. At the time, Senator Ryan conceded that the offending Ordinance had created even more anomalies, and that it would have been better to completely overhaul the Trading Hours Ordinance 1962. That is what the now-defunct House of Assembly wanted to happen. Despite the numerous inquiries and the years of public controversy, nothing of substance has emerged on this question since then.

Another example typical of the snail-like pace with which overhaul of A.C.T. legislation has occurred is the Tobacco Ordinance 1927, the subject of revision and current manoeuvres by the Tobacco Institute it was to have been completely overhauled several months ago. Case after case of this process can be cited almost at will.
Sunset clauses on all out-of-date legislation

The people of Canberra deserve a fair go at the start of self-government. The Assembly shouldn't have to devote a large part of its scarce resources to examining and restoring outdated legislation. This Bill ensures that the Commonwealth will provide the resources necessary to complete a comprehensive review of all current A.C.T. Ordinances and applicable N.S.W. and Imperial Acts in the first five years of self-government.

All existing Ordinances and Acts will automatically expire at the end of that period unless they have been previously repealed or properly revised at Commonwealth expense. Under the legislation, the Assembly will be able to lay down the guidelines for any revision project through resolutions, and then act upon the report or draft law produced as a result. There will undoubtedly be a long-overdue substantial shake-up of the A.C.T. administration carried out in parallel with this process, and this will enable resources to be deployed much more effectively. No current arrangement will be sacrosanct.

The Assembly will be able to carry out programs of reform without having the past inactivity or incompetence of successive Ministers and Departments as an albatross around its neck. This must be paid for by the Commonwealth and approved by the new Assembly.
Assembly members
I have previously indicated that full-time membership of the Assembly is essential if that body is to properly perform its scrutiny functions.

We propose that members wishing to engage in paid employment outside the Assembly first obtain the approval of the Assembly. Those with an interest in an A.C.T. public contract will have to declare the interest and refrain from voting on that matter. Public respect for the Assembly will be improved by these strict standards.

The legislation includes strong re-instatement rights for those A.C.T. public servants who resign, rather than obtain leave of absence without pay, and who fail to be elected to the Assembly. In this way, and because we are proposing a fair electoral system that will put only candidates with community support into the Assembly, we will encourage people of high standing in the community to nominate for election.
Quota preferential system

A.C.T. residents have had more than thirty-five years of experience with proportional representation as the electoral system has been tied to that of the Senate since the first Advisory Council was established in 1930. Both the Craig Task Force and the earlier Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory unanimously endorsed proportional representation in their major reports on self-government. The government proposed a system of single member electorates in their retrograde bill.
The all-party Committee made these comments about proportional representation in 1974:

``It also significantly lessens the redistribution problems of other systems. It does not, as some suggest, necessarily fail to achieve representation of localities within the electorate and electors should be able to identify a member of the Assembly who resides in, or in the vicinity of, their own locality.''
More choice for voters

We shall assist the public, firstly by including on the ballot paper the suburb in which each candidate lives. We shall also rotate the order of names within a particular group column on the ballot paper so that each endorsed candidate has the same access to the best places in the column. This rotation has been used with great success in Tasmania since 1979.

The absence of party regimentation has benefits both for voters and for parties. A wide diversity of candidates are endorsed. This means much greater choice for the voters while ensuring that there are no damaging factional brawls over who gets which positions on the ballot paper.
Representation of the people

We are proposing three seven-member electorates for the A.C.T. This will allow reasonable scrutiny of the executive and of administration. In each electorate, any candidate with 12.5% of the vote will automatically be elected. A group with a majority of the votes will win a majority of the seats. Consequently the Assembly will very closely mirror the wishes of the people.

A group which receives around 45% of first preferences will stand a reasonable chance of taking four seats out of seven if it tops the poll. Much will depend on the range and quality of the candidates endorsed. No party will be able to ignore large areas of the A.C.T. or large sections of the community.

The Craig Task Force set out three essential features of any fair electoral system in which the wishes of the majority prevailed, significant minority community views were reflected in the legislature, and a workable and stable government resulted. These were:
the closest possible adherence to the principle of one-vote-one value
equity in opportunity to exercise a meaningful vote and to have that vote recorded
equity in opportunity in all other respects particularly to nominate for office and to campaign for election.

In the unanimous view of the Task Force, a multi-member proportional representation system achieves this best of all. Mixed systems were criticised severely for their artificiality and complexity, the two different classes of members, and the potential for distortion of the voters' wishes in the single-member districts. The Task Force concluded that they were `impractical and unnecessarily complex'.

One practical effect of the three seven-member districts is that redistributions will be very infrequent, even with the reduction to 5 per cent in the discrepancy allowed in average enrolments per member. Voters will enjoy the stability in representation that comes when boundaries remain unchanged for long periods.
No by-elections

Another important practical effect is that casual vacancies will be filled by a re-examination of those papers not for sitting candidates. This straightforward procedure is similar to that in Tasmania, but it maximises the number of voters who achieve direct representation in the Assembly at any given time.

Costs to the taxpayer are minimised at the same time, and there is no diversion of government nor are there wild promises made in the hope of securing a seat. There will certainly not be the half-a-million dollar waste created by the holding of 11 by-elections in New South Wales in a period of little more than 18 months.
Conclusion

It is of course disappointing that the government, with the vast resources at its disposal, produced such a pitiful package. The Australian Democrats want effective self-government for the people of the A.C.T. I am therefore proud to bring up a Bill which protects the interests of Canberrans and those of the nation. This Bill will give the people of the Australian Capital Territory a good framework for self-government in which they can make local decisions about their community and its resources. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (EQUAL OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the diabolical and draconian Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986.
—I was just admiring your flowery start, if I might say so.

—It was a frank, factual and fair description. As I have said, this legislation will not provide equal opportunity. It will lead to the conferring of an advantage. This will occur because of the nature and function of the Director of Affirmative Action and because of the requirements to set objectives and forward estimates. By any measure quotas, by another name, will be imposed. To what extent these aspects of the Bill will make it an affirmative action Bill rather than an equal opportunity Bill will depend very much on the person appointed to fill the role of Director of Affirmative Action. The prospect that this legislation may become an affirmative action instrument involves the possibility that the Government will be prepared to lean on people based on the recommendations which the Director of Affirmative Action makes about employers' compliance with the Director's views of what is a satisfactory affirmative action program.

SPEECH.PARA: The Director is required to report to the Minister. As there is no prescribed penalty for failing to comply with any standards set in the Bill, what is the purpose of requiring employers to report to the Director who in turn will report to the Minister? Without any apparent penalties in the Bill how does the Government intend to cope with an employer who suggests, assumes and takes the position that the Bill is a ridiculous waste of time and who has no intention in any way, shape or form of setting any objectives or forward estimates? Does the Government intend this legislation to be a toothless tiger? I think not. I am certain that this will not be the case.

I believe the Government intends to bring pressure to bear upon employers who do not fit into its little social models and its attempt at social engineering. The Government will do this, as it acts in most cases, in the most insidious way. Rather than being open and honest and putting penalties in the Bill, the Government will use the approach that it has used before when it does not have the courage to legislate openly. It will lean upon any employer who fails to toe the party line. Past examples to which one might point include the case of sportsmen who had the courage, commitment and audacity to seek for financial gain or reward sporting contracts and contracts with South Africa. What did the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) say? He said that he would scrutinise very carefully their tax returns. What did the Government do in its legislation on the Builders Labourers Federation?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is something that you could not stand. I know that close scrutiny of any returns would not be anathema to you.

—I do not mind close scrutiny of tax returns. I thought that that was the normal function of the Australian Taxation Office. What did the Government do to employers if they did not comply with its code of conduct concerning the Builders Labourers Federation? It did not legislate; it just threatened them. Ignoring for a moment the merits of the high principles of the government in such instances, there are examples of the Government bringing pressure to bear on people by misuse of the various arms of government in a particularly evil and, in my view, frightening way.
—It worked though, didn't it?

—Yes, it worked. Governments are able to intimidate the average John Citizen. How many people can beat the bureaucracy and beat delinquent governments which are prepared to intimidate people and stand over them?
—Do you think employers should have been allowed to go on bribing builders labourers?
—No, I do not. I would give no marks to the employers that did so.
—Then what are you talking about?

—I am talking about the employers who were not prepared to comply with the Government's code of conduct. Those employers were not outlawed, the Government simply said that they would not receive any more government contracts.
—That's not a bad idea.
—Why did the Government not legislate for it?
—You probably would have opposed it.

—Senator Button knows me better than that. I would have supported it. I am no lover of employers' conduct in recent times concerning employees. It takes two to tango. Under this legislation, because the reports will be made public, employers who do not comply will be held up to public ridicule. There will be enough pressure to ensure that they buckle under. Having established that the Government will be able to coerce employees to comply with the wishes of the Director, how might the Director's powers under this legislation be used to implement positive discrimination? This will occur through the requirement that employers establish objectives and forward estimates. In plain English, these terms mean the setting of quotas on the numbers of women to be employed.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been an entirely unsuccessful attempt in the literature which surrounds these terms to distinguish these terms from quotas. It is suggested that quotas are in some way fixed, whereas these terms imply voluntary compliance and therefore are in some way variable. That is incredibly contradictory. The literature continues to indicate that an example of a forward estimate-the quantitative term-would be an employer aiming to have a certain percentage of positions at a certain level staffed by women within a certain time. Even if it is not compulsory to comply with these estimates, the mere fact that employers are forced to resort to some arbitrarily imposed figure for the employment of women indicates a departure from the merit principle.

The imposition of objectives requires an attempt to eliminate work practices which allegedly would have discriminating effects on women. Such practices might include the imposition of a minimum height requirement, for example, in cases where it is determined that the height requirement is not really necessary. The best person to make that judgment and the necessary stipulations is the employer himself, or herself, and not some outside Director of Affirmative Action who might set foot in the employers' premises only once in 20 years, if ever. Despite claims of the voluntariness of the scheme under this Bill, the scope for pressure to be brought to bear to ensure that an employer complies with the Director's view of what are the objectives and forward estimates which an employer should reach under this Bill is sufficiently wide for these settings to be as mandatory as if they were fixed by law.

As I have said. I am quite sure that the Government does not mean to stand impotent in the face of an employer who refuses to comply with the legislation. Owing to the imprecise words used in the Bill it is impossible to foretell exactly the effect that this Bill will have. In large part it will depend on the mood of the person occupying the position of Director of Affirmative Action. In trying to estimate the likely effects it might be useful to examine the trends which have occurred in discrimination legislation and from this environment attempt in part to predict what the mood of the Affirmative Action Director might be. Although the non-discrimination principles might have started out as something with which few reasonable people would disagree, they have been pushed and perverted by the more radical elements. It is now to a greater extent the target of completely justifiable derision.

We ought to consider a couple of examples from the New South Wales Equal Opportunities Tribunal. The first is Troy Morrison v. the Gallipoli Legion Club Newcastle Ltd. In this case, the complainant, Troy Morrison, was a homosexual who entered the defendant club dressed in women's clothing. Earlier the same evening, there had been an incident where a similarly dressed man had entered the women's toilet. Troy Morrison was refused service by the barman, who did not want trouble in the club-quite properly. The Tribunal said:

Whilst it is conceded the Bar Attendant acted as he saw fit in the best interests of the Club, the Tribunal accepts the submission of Counsel for the complainant Ms Simpson that in refusing to serve the complainant the Bar Attendant made the kind of stereotyped assumptions that the Anti-Discrimination Act is directed towards.

The fact that the members of the club may have been offended by a man dressed in such fashion or that they, the owners of the club, did not wish to have homosexuals in their club were matters the Tribunal was unable to take into consideration.

Another example of the perverse extent to which these types of laws are being pushed occurred in the case of Shane Edmund Burke v. Peter Tralagan and Spence Real Estate Pty Ltd. It is a case I am sure we all know about where the doctor refused to rent his home to an unmarried couple because he believed that this would amount to his profiting from a relationship, which according to his Christian principles, he considered to be immoral. For the practising of his Christian views, the doctor was fined. The Tribunal said:

If a person is a member of a religious order whose doctrines promote marriage as essential for persons wishing to live together, this belief may not be imposed upon persons wishing to obtain accommodation, as a criteria for obtaining such accommodation.

The doctor was undoubtedly of the view, as most Australians presumably would be, that as he owned the home-a reasonably significant factor, I would have thought-he should be able to rent it to whomsoever he choose. The Australian Capital Territory school system has been moving towards positive discrimination within the school system to ensure what the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority regards as sufficient representation of women, Aboriginals and disabled people throughout the levels of the schools system, irrespective of ability or merit. This is the growing level of fanaticism directed to the community at present where the principle of appointment by merit has been disregarded. Dr Peter Wilenski, the Chairman of the Public Service Board, was reported in the Australian of 3 April 1985 as saying that the merit principle was a tool of those in power who maintain the status quo. He said:
Standards of merit, either deliberately or unconsciously, often were based on the values, style and priorities of the dominant male group in the organisation.

We all know that this Government has no belief in merit or excellence. The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) has said this on many occasions. I put it to you, Mr Deputy President, that these examples are an indication of a growing level of fanaticism surrounding the anti- discrimination issue in this country. It is now being pressed to the point that it overrides people's religious beliefs, the right to determine who are appropriate people to be admitted to clubs and even to the point where it is questioned whether it is appropriate for people to be appointed on merit in the first place.

In this environment, I ask the Senate: Can we realistically expect that the Director of Affirmative Action will have an adequate regard for the rights of employers to choose the staff which they determine are appropriate for the positions which they have available? Can we expect the Director to have any consideration for business realities, or will these be treated with the same contempt which has been shown for private property rights and the right to practise one's religion? I believe that the Director will form her own preconceived opinions about whether there is an appropriate level of employment of women in each respective business. Inevitably, this will lead to the same situation which now occurs in the United States of America. In that country when employers impose certain minimum requirements upon employees such as educational standards, height or strength standards which may be more difficult for women to satisfy than men, the courts can now examine whether they consider that the requirement is justified having regard to the employers' business. The onus is placed on the employer to show why the requirement, which is imposed, is justified by business necessity. This has even applied to requirements of minimum standards of education. In Griggs v. Duke Power Company, the United States Supreme Court held that the requirement that janitors employed by the company have a minimum standard of a grade 12 education was, in its opinion, unjustified for the position and therefore unlawful as it discriminated against blacks because a lower percentage of blacks had year 12 education than had whites.

Other aspects of the American affirmative action experience are less subtle. The Civil Reform Act 1978 requires Federal Government agencies to recruit so as to eliminate the under-representation of groups when compared with their numbers in the community. The legislation is therefore requiring the representation of groups such as women, blacks, et cetera, in proportion to their numbers in the community, irrespective of merit. I believe that this will be the result of the affirmative action legislation now before this chamber. Such a result is wrong for many reasons. The first of these is that it requires the involvement of a person outside business to evaluate the hiring programs of businesses. In my view, this is immediately unjustifiable. The hiring practices of employers are matters for those employers and have nothing to do with any government bureaucrat. It is totally unrealistic to assume that any one member of the affirmative action inspectorate will have the knowledge to evaluate the merits of the employment practices of the many hundreds of different types of businesses which may be examined.

How can any bureaucrat-frequently, one can assume, Canberra based-have the knowledge to accurately assess what is an appropriate level for the employment of women in industries from Port Arthur in Tasmania to Port Hedland in Western Australia? How will the Director of Affirmative Action know what actually constitutes merit in a particular industry? Will the Director simply assess merit on academic achievement without any assessment of personality, initiative and drive, which is so important in the recruiting of good employees? The fact is that this legislation is asking a bureaucrat to make assessments about employees in industries which can only be properly made by the employer who is on the scene, who knows what the job demands and who knows how well an employee would fit in with his existing work force.

The final reason for opposing this Bill is that it is the greatest condemnation which can be levelled against it. Rather than improving the status of women in the community, this Bill will undermine it. The Bill is an enormous insult to all women. It is tantamount to the Government saying it recognises that women will not be able to succeed in their own right, but rather they would only be able to do so with government help. The Bill will be of great assistance to all those incapable women applying for jobs. It will be of no assistance to those who are capable. It will enable incapable women, incompetent women, to get jobs which they would not normally get if they were forced to rely strictly on merit, irrespective of sex. In my view, affirmative action legislation is a threat to all those many talented women who have already obtained positions on their merit. The question which, of course, will be asked after this Bill is passed is whether a woman is holding a position because of affirmative action legislation or because of ability. The Bill will undermine the achievements of many women. It will also lead to resentment by men when they see a woman holding a position because of legislation and not because of capacity or competence. The damage to the status of women in the work force is immeasurable.

This Bill is yet another attempt at social engineering by this Government. It is of the same vile stock as the Australian Bill of Rights Bill and as such it should be cast out of this place for the betterment of Australia and Australian business and for the betterment particularly of Australian women. If it is, men and women will both succeed and be seen to succeed on their merits and not as a result of such paternalistic and demeaning legislation as this Bill and as this Government would wish it to be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986. The title of this Bill reminds me somewhat of the Virginia Slims advertisements that one sees in many magazines. The caption at the bottom of these advertisements, as many honourable senators would know, reads: `You have come a long way babe'. Generally there is a picture of a woman of the 1800s era doing some sort of 1800s-type of activity, contrasted with a woman of the 1980s. There are a number of reasons why the title of this Bill and, in fact, its substance remind me of those Virginia Slims advertisements. Firstly, the substance of the Bill reminds me of just how far Labor has come away from what it originally wanted and how far this legislation is from what some women expect of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, to call this affirmative action legislation is to overstate the case in the extreme. As the Minister for Education and Minister assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Senator Ryan) well knows, the legislation is not setting goals or targets and, most importantly of all, it protects the merit principle in employment. Therefore, one asks oneself why this Bill is titled the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill and why it is not called what it really is, an equal opportunity Bill, with the affirmative action part of the title dropped. Well, it is a case of political pragmatism; it sounds good. The title has appeal to some in the general public who I suppose, like most Australians, do not read the detail of every Bill that comes before them. Most Australians go on the headlines that sub-editors put on articles. Therefore, calling this Bill the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill creates an impression of something much greater than an equal opportunity Bill. When one looks to the substance of the Bill to see whether it matches the title, one sees that it does not. In my view it is a deliberately misleading package. The legislation should be called the Equal Opportunity Bill.

Along with other senators and the Minister, in April I attended the Women's Electoral Lobby conference as part of this Government's National Agenda for Women program. At that conference the Minister reminded the women there just how far women, and she in particular, had come since 1972. The Minister informed the group present that she remembered coming to that campus in 1972 when there were tents on the lawns and everyone was having a gay old time. She reminded women that in 1972 the surroundings were much less salubrious than they were on that day in April this year. The good Minister indicated to the group that she was reminded of just how far women, and she in particular, had come when she was being driven to the conference that morning in her ministerial car. The Minister may now regret those remarks, because I assure honourable senators that, as the Minister undoubtedly will remember, they went down like a lead balloon.

I assure the Minister that, in my view, she should not be concerned by the fact that the sensible portion of her contribution was not warmly received, because my own sensible contribution was not warmly received at that conference either. However, Senator Haines made a contribution that was very warmly received at the conference. I agree with the Minister's description when she said that Senator Haines received acclamation from a geriatric cheer leader. Of course, the reason Senator Haines received that warm reception was that she promoted a line at that meeting-a line which she promotes at a number of meetings-to the effect that this Government and, of course, the coalition do not have the interests of women at heart and that the Labor Party and the Liberal Party are all for business but not for the poverty-stricken women of Australia. She instanced, as she has on a number of occasions, the example of business people being allowed to deduct for taxation purposes a very long list of expenses as operating costs. She mentioned that that included, of course, the cost of electricity for running factories. Senator Haines said, however, that the people at the conference were not permitted to deduct electricity expenses for running the home. Of course, this went down very well with the throng at the conference that day. I am very pleased to raise the subject now because as Senator Haines is now Leader of the Australian Democrats I look forward to her introducing some Bills into this Parliament that will put the power she now has where her mouth has been for so many months.

However, I return to the lead balloon comments concerning the ministerial car. It took one Olive Murphy, a Torres Strait Islander whom I understand the Minister has appointed to the National Women's Consultative Council-I congratulate Olive Murphy on that appointment and, for that matter, the Minister for making it-to get up and tell the throng at the conference that she did not have a ministerial car or an air-conditioned office. In fact, what she was telling everybody was that not all women had come as far as some other women-certainly not as far as the Minister. We therefore have to ask just who has come a long way and who is going further.

Of course, the Office of the Status of Women has moved a long way. In my view it has moved away from the Public Service role of privately advising Ministers into one of making public political comments. Senator Giles and the Minister know full well the situation to which I am referring. I make these remarks to reinforce the words of my colleague Senator Hill, who spoke in this debate in this chamber several days ago, when he said that this Bill will only help a number of women. I am pleased that the Government is paying at least some attention in this respect to a particular group of women. The legislation will help those women. It will help a group of women who need help and who need to overcome prejudices. From my point of view, at least, there is no denying that.

Let us, however, keep the acclamation for this legislation in proportion. Let us acknowledge the small group of women that the legislation will help. It will help women in the bigger businesses. It will not help the check-out operator in the small local supermarket to proceed to a higher position. It will not help the sales clerk at the local electrical store to get a small management position over and above her male colleague. It will not help the female technician in a small, high technology manufacturing firm. Certainly it will not help migrant women who work in small, sweaty garment factories in inner Sydney or inner Melbourne. It will not help the women who take laundry at home or who go out to clean for the high-flying professional careerist or the high-flying femocrats. It certainly will not help women who work for trade unions. Certainly it will also not help women who are locked out of permanent part time work as a result of the rigid labour market. These are the women who will be helped on the return of the Liberal Party to government.

Of course, there is another group of women whom the legislation will not help. I refer to the Labor Party female aspirant to the South Australian Legislative Council. For the benefit of honourable senators present and listening who are not familiar with this sad story, I will relate what happened in South Australia so that every honourable senator is able to see whether Labor practises what it preaches. Senator Crowley knows full well what I am referring to. At the last South Australian State election a woman on the Labor Legislative Council ticket very sadly missed out on election by one position. The Minister will know that it is a common practice of both political parties to stand women for election to positions which they may make if they are lucky but, in all probability will not. Of course, this is what happened to the woman in South Australia. She did not make it. However, as luck would have it, at that very election a legislative councillor stood for a lower House seat and won it. The day after the election he resigned, thus creating a vacancy. Here was an opportunity for the Labor Party in South Australia to show that the next person on the list-the woman who could get in if she were lucky and who was chosen shortly before to stand in that election-could move up and take that Legislative Council position. What happened? She did not move up and take that Legislative Council position. She was given the dump. The Labor Party put in a man.

Senator Crowley comes into this chamber wearing a cloak of equal opportunity and affirmative action. However, she does not wear that cloak in her own Party. I ask her to come into this chamber at some time and answer for what she did to assist that woman in South Australia to gain the position which she should have got. If Senator Crowley worked as hard as she could have to get that woman up on that occasion it shows just what little influence Senator Crowley has in her own State.

Senator Crowley has made an error. She has been corrected. The error she made was in referring to a recent national Liberal Women's Conference held in Adelaide. Senator Crowley purported to represent two resolutions, which had been passed a number days apart, as being in conflict with each other. I have read the Hansard, and Senator Walters has pointed out to Senator Crowley her error. The motion passed by the Liberal Party Federal Council was passed on a States rights basis. There is no Liberal of whom I know who does not agree with the principles of equal opportunity. The motion that was passed one or two days later at the National Liberal Women's Conference supported the principles in equal opportunity legislation. To my mind those two are not inconsistent, but Senator Crowley has had this error pointed out to her and I trust that she will not therefore inadvertently misrepresent the situation again.

I support this legislation. Along with most other Liberals, I believe that equal opportunity legislation is a proper function of government. I admit that if the coalition parties were in government we perhaps would have done it differently. We might have extended the voluntary program. Let us not forget that much depends on what people are prepared to do for themselves. The Government cannot do for women what they will not do for themselves, and it cannot do for business what business will not do for itself. To that end I was interested to read in a publication put out by the Liberal Women of South Australia called Equal Opportunities an article written for that magazine by Dr Leonie Still entitled `The Position of Women Executives in Australian Business'. I will quote just a small portion of that article to back up my point that women must do some things for themselves, as business must do some things for itself; we cannot rely totally on the Government to do everything. I quote:

The fight for access to management has only just begun and needs to be conducted on two levels: access to management and access within management (up the hierarchy). While progress has been made in the first area, the other has hardly been addressed. The results of any change will depend largely on women themselves and how determined they are to improve their management status.

So much for the role that women themselves can play. I have said that I agree with the principle behind this legislation and acknowledge that the Government is entitled to choose the implementation of the policy which will put the principle of equal opportunity into practice. There is, in my view, bipartisan support for that principle.

I have a number of concerns with the legislation. I have mentioned the first already, and that is the misleading title. I think it is a pretty cheapskate arrangement, but I need not repeat my remarks in that respect. Secondly, I have a concern that it is an imposition on business. In these hard times-these times of adversity that our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) tells us equal those of war-it seems a little inconsistent to be moving now to put a further burden on business. The Government is seeking to add this burden on business on top of other burdens such as the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and, particularly in relation to my State, the 20 per cent wine tax. When the wine industry has had only one year to adjust to the imposition of the tax in the first place this Government seeks to double that tax.

I also have a concern that the Government is using this Bill to get a foot in the door and, having a foot in the door, it will attempt to step up the provisions of the Bill and move it from what I now believe to be an equal opportunity Bill to an affirmative action Bill. Of this Bill the Prime Minister says:

. . . it seeks to foster the development of affirmative action programs in an atmosphere of consensus and co-operation between government and employers. This approach is also reflected in the only sanction provided in the Bill: The Director's power to name in a report to Parliament any employer who fails to lodge either report or who fails to provide further information on request.

The Prime Minister lists that as the only sanction, and I certainly hope it remains that way. In introducing this legislation, the Prime Minister called it a milestone. He spoke most loquaciously; he oozed concern and sincerity. When I read his comments I thought back to a book I had read by Blanche d'Alpuget on the Prime Minister just before he made that speech. You need have no fear, Mr President; I will not go into any of the passages in the book-I would not waste the Senate's time with such matters, and they are public knowledge anyway. As I was saying, I read the Prime Minister's comments, and I remembered Blanche d'Alpuget's book. My perception was that this man, our Prime Minister, had been through a dramatic change in his attitude to women. He, too, along with the Minister for Education and many other Australian women, has come a long way. Almost like St. Paul on the road to Damascus, our Prime Minister appears to have been converted, unless of course it was a Clayton's conversion for the benefit of Hansard. As I said, the Prime Minister pointed out that this legislation was a milestone. For some Australian women it is; for business I fear it is going to be a millstone around its neck. In conclusion, I support very strongly the principle of equal opportunity and therefore support this legislation. If the coalition were in government it would have proceeded towards the same goal but in a different and less intrusive manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The facts about the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment for Women) Bill 1986-what it is intended to achieve, its goals and its implementation-have been canvassed over and over again in this debate, and it is pointless to waste precious time rehearsing them. I hope I will be able to make some points in conjunction with what has been said during the debate-comments, assertions and so forth that have been made by a wide range of speakers, some of whom have shown a sensitive appreciation of the Bill and its goals. That sensitivity and that appreciation have not been confined to this side of the House. I would like to express my gratitude to those members of the Opposition who have taken the trouble to find out just what this Bill is about, to give it some objective consideration, and to be prepared to be constructive about what many of us believe to be an extremely important matter and an extremely innovative and progressive move on behalf of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to challenge an assertion that was made by Senator Haines very early in this debate that this was one of the few commitments to the electorate that have been fulfilled by this Government. Indeed, in relation to our commitments to women I think Senator Haines will find that our record is very fine indeed. This, I would suggest, is one of the crowning accomplishments in that range of progressive measures. I am sorry that Senator Haines fell into a trap that many other members of the Opposition parties were not able to avoid, and that was to stress the fact that the Bill as it is drafted and as it will be administered initially will not apply to the majority of women in the Australian work force. That is to ignore the structure of the Australian work force, to fail to recognise that amongst the largest enterprises are a majority of Australian working women. They will of course be covered from the beginning of the operation of this legislation, which covers employers of more than 500 employees-not more than 500 women employees, may I hasten to add-which of course widens the range considerably again.

I was a little disappointed to discover that members of the National Party of Australia, even after some years in Federal Parliament in some cases, did not seem to have learnt a great deal. Senator Bjelke-Petersen, for example, seemed to be right out of her depth. It was on the day she asked a question about navy beans, and my notes suggest that she should keep to those issues with which she is obviously very familiar. She worried about pushing women artificially up the ladder and simply failed to acknowledge the fact that for very many women there is no ladder at this stage and that unless we take measures to create ladders which women can genuinely scale there will be very little change, and whatever change there is will be very slow. An analogy that might be useful here is the Haulpak truck, the vehicle that is in common use in the iron ore industry to cart ore. It is not difficult to drive. What is difficult is to get on to the bottom rung of the ladder to climb up into the cab, which is very high in the air. One needs to be a tall or agile person just to get on to that first rung. It has nothing to do with gender. It should have nothing to do with whether one has very long or very short legs. As far as I am aware, long legs are not an inherent requirement for a reliable driver of a Haulpak truck.

Senator Bjelke-Petersen used a rather cliched adage that time is the changer of all things. That is absolutely so, but how much time do we have? It is very nearly 200 years since Mary Wollstonecraft wrote A Vindication of the Rights of Women. It is well over 100 years since John Stuart Mill wrote about The Subjection of Women. It is over 80 years since Australian women and many Western European women won the vote. Without extra measures being taken to overcome the inherent disadvantages of being a woman in a male dominated world, changes, as we have seen, will happen very slowly. To quote Alison Ziller, the Director of Equal Opportunity in Public Employment in the New South Wales Government:
Unfortunately, one of the by-products of a discriminatory system is that a sense of urgency and purpose tends to be lacking among the ranks . . .

She is referring here to majority group managers. I might widen that description and include the majority of politicians and other senior members of our national institutions. Alison Ziller goes on to say:
Perhaps this is because they-
she is referring, once again, to managers-
rarely perceive a need for such a program assuming, as many do, that they have reached their own positions on the basis of merit and genuine competition.

We know that in most cases this is simply not so. The competition has been a very closed competition until very recently and, in many cases, that is still the case. I was disappointed that Senator Hill, who supports the Bill, also managed to avoid some of the realities of the Australian work force and the way in which those realities would be addressed by this Bill. He insisted that it would have an effect only on the better educated and upwardly mobile women. That is patently ridiculous when one considers the fact that, as I said previously, the legislation will apply to enterprises with 500 employees or more in the first instance and will be phased in to smaller establishments as time goes by. Even if the legislation were to apply only to better educated women, let us not avoid the fact that very many well-educated women are currently holding down jobs which are way below their capacities.

I was in a position to say to the vice-chancellor of one of Australia's largest universities on the eve of his retirement that probably one of the greatest benefits he could award his institution before retiring would be to make it possible for the women who were in the secretarial positions in that university to apply genuinely, with a chance of proper consideration, for administrative jobs-women who in many cases had gone into those secretarial positions with not very impressive qualifications but who, as a result of years of experience, had become very competent administrators and who in many cases were practically running university departments. That is not a set of circumstances foreign to the experience of many of us.

If one looks at the clothing trade in Australia, an industry which employs an enormous number of women, including many migrant women and women without formal qualifications, one gets an idea of exactly what the scope of this legislation will be. Amongst the biggest employers of women in the clothing trade are Pacific Dunlop, with a staff of 5,020; Lintrad, with a staff of 7,460; Bonds, Coats, Patons, with a staff of 4,451; BNCK, with 4,000 workers; Sportscraft, with over 1,000 workers; Stafford Ellinson, with 500 plus; and Fletcher Jones, with over 500.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTERIAL ARRANGEMENTS

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that Senator Gietzelt will be absent from the chamber for Question Time today. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Gietzelt in relation to his portfolio, or to those he represents in the chamber, should be directed to Senator Grimes.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to his public statement, reported on 14 August, that there will have to be a renegotiation of at least the wages aspect of the accord. Does the Minister agree that the 2 per cent discounting proposed by the Government is not sufficient to preserve the competitive advantages of the devaluation? Further, is it not also a fact that, quite apart from the devaluation effect, the Budget Papers predict a 0.5 per cent addition to the consumer price index because of indirect tax increases and that there are likely to be other increases in the CPI caused by the Budget, for example, the inflation of health care costs? Will the Government give consideration to arguing at the next national wage case for a higher level of discounting than proposed in the Budget to take into account the Budget impact on the CPI?

—In terms of wages and other matters which fundamentally affect the economy, this Government has always taken the view that it is desirable to obtain results by a process of negotiation if that is possible. The Government has indicated in the Budget Papers that it will seek a 2 per cent discount in the next national wage case but it has also indicated, through various statements by Ministers, that we will seek negotiation with the Australian Council of Trade Unions about those matters later this year. It is true that I suggested renegotiating the accord as it stood on 14 August. It is important to note that, I think yesterday, the ACTU after meeting with its President, Mr Simon Crean, expressed a willingness, as I understand it, to negotiate some of those matters. I do not want in anything I say in the Senate to prejudice the conduct of those negotiations. Frankly, I think that would be crass.
—Crass?

—It is a good word-and prejudicial to the negotiations which might take place. Having said that, in a sense I decline to answer the remainder of Senator Chaney's questions which relates to the CPI effect of indirect taxes and so on because the points he is making are subsumed in the broader question of the extent to which wages should be negotiated in the next wage case.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I acknowledge the Minister's desire not to interrupt or to interfere in any way with discussions with the trade union movement but I must ask him whether he agrees that the impact of tax changes on the CPI is appropriately a matter for consideration when assessing what wage rises should occur during this Budget period.

—Any matter which affects the CPI, whether it be indirect taxes or anything else, is an appropriate matter for consideration when one considers the appropriate wage discount or adjustment which should be made to wages. I concede that point, and I do not think I am doing anything particularly remarkable by making that concession. Any of these factors which impinge on the CPI have to be taken into account. Having said that I emphasise what I said earlier. It has always been a source of extraordinary surprise to the Opposition. Question Time after Question Time in the last three years the Government has been asked: `What are you going to do about wages in the next quarter?' Given the circumstances prior to the current disastrous downturn in the current account, satisfactory results were obtained by the Government. There is no doubt about that. All I asked members of the Opposition to do, on numerous occasions, was to possess their souls in patience and we would provide an answer. However, there is no point in putting all of these things on the public record in the Senate. It might be very enlightening to honourable senators but we will not be there when the negotiation process takes place.

—Will the Minister for Education inform the Senate whether any education decisions in the recently announced Budget will ease the high cost to country parents who need to send their children away from home for their education?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to answer Senator McKiernan's question by saying that, yes, there are measures in the Budget which will be of particular benefit to country parents and country children. I know that Senator McKiernan, who represents a State which has many such families, will be pleased to learn this. The main form of assistance to individual students is the assistance for isolated children scheme, which has been revamped. Expenditure on that scheme will be increased by 16.4 per cent in the next financial year. The net effect of these increases will be to improve opportunities for those students who have to leave home to go to school. As Senator McKiernan knows, the AIC provides financial assistance to the parents of children who, because of geographic isolation or disability, must study by correspondence, must live away from home to attend school or must live in a second family home which provides daily access to schooling. The scheme will be changed next year to make it more consistent with Austudy, the new student assistance scheme through which financial support will be paid according to age.

ANSWER.PARA: The most substantial increase in benefits will go to isolated students aged 16 and over. Students aged 16 and 17 can now get a maximum benefit of $73.28 a week and students aged over 18 can get up to $80 a week. The income test applied to parents to determine students' eligibility for assistance will be substantially relaxed-it will be relaxed by a factor of 15.6 per cent-and there will be a guaranteed minimum payment of almost $1,000 a year regardless of family income. As well as these income support measures for students and families we have decided to fund the loan video scheme for another three years. Honourable senators who have isolated areas in their States will be well aware of that very successful program that assisted students living at home in remote areas. An amount of $1.3m has been allocated for this purpose.

To further demonstrate our concern to improve and upgrade our programs for country areas and country children, I have announced a major review of rural education by the Commonwealth Schools Commission. In order that that review have the direct input of parents of isolated children a representative of the Isolated Children's Parents Association, Trish Mitchell from Queensland, has been appointed a member of the Commission. In terms of higher education, the Minister for Primary Industry, John Kerin, and I will be setting up a review of agricultural colleges that train young people to work in rural industries. It is clear that the Government's income support and assistance to isolated families programs and increased emphasis on the needs of country students at all levels of education will lead to a great improvement in educational opportunities offered in country areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. The Budget Papers reveal that there will be a reduction in real terms of funding under the heading of law and order. In particular, the Australian Federal Police allocations will be cut 2.7 per cent in real terms. Will the Minister advise whether the Government will be completing its program of increasing AFP numbers by 300 by 1988 and whether the reduction funding will result in any reduction in the fight against crime and drug trafficking generally?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have about three pages of notes which state how terrific the AFP is and how terrific it will continue to be as a result of the budgetary provisions. I am not exactly sure whether I am precisely answering Senator Archer's question. It will take an awfully long time for me to read the notes. I seek leave to incorporate them in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
AFP Resources and Achievements

While focusing strongly on the need to impose tight financial discipline, the Government remains committed to the maintenance of its law and order programs. In this regard and in line with the strong public committment made by the Prime Minister during the 1984 election campaign, the government has increased the real level of resources available for the Australian Federal Police in 1986-87.
Since taking office the Government has increased AFP manpower by 462 which represents an increase of approximately 18%.
Certain routine guarding functions have been removed to other agencies (Australian Protective Service).

In addition, the effectiveness and professionalism of the AFP has been significantly improved through a number of organisational and administrative changes implemented as a result of the joint management review and the resources review, both initiated by this Government.

In August 1985 the Government issued the AFP with a new charter of objectives and priorities recognising its development as a federal investigative body. In accordance with its priority tasks of countering drug trafficking, organised crime and large-scale fraud against Commonwealth revenue, AFP resources have been redeployed to effect very significant increases in staff resources devoted to drug investigations, fraud and general crime, and intelligence.
A five-year deployment plan has been developed to ensure the most efficient use of the resources available, in terms of the Government's objectives and priorities.
Some of the more important achievements of the AFP are:
Major drug seizures
Major fraud investigations
Improved domestic and overseas liaison and intelligence-gathering capabilities
Better co-operation with other Commonwealth agencies
Improved terms and conditions of employment for AFP members
New accommodation in Canberra for majority of AFP headquarter staff.
AFP-MAJOR ACHIEVEMENTS SINCE 1983
Significant seizures of heroin, cannabis resin, cocaine and other narcotics through combined efforts with other Commonwealth and State agencies.
Major drug seizures include:
2.25 tonnes of cannabis resin located in a container at a Sydney Wharf.
120 kgs of heroin imported from Thailand.
disruption of a syndicate responsible for importing between five and seven tonnes of cannabis resin of which approximately one tonne was recovered (Operation Lavender).
Major fraud investigations include:
a scheme to defraud the Australian Taxation Office by manipulation of Sales Tax payable on imported or wholesale merchandise, involving an amount in excess of $6 million.
a conspiracy to defraud Australia Post of stamps valued at over $428,000.
a $250,000 fraud committed against the Department of Social Security by one person using multiple false identities.
a major conspiracy to defraud the Commonwealth of approximately $20 million by the use of a commodities futures scheme.
seizures of $4.9 million in counterfeit Australian $50 notes together with materials used in their manufacture.
extensive medifraud investigations.
Improved domestic and overseas liaison and intelligence gathering capabilities by:
stationing liaison officers in the U.S.A., U.K. and in key South East Asian countries.
maintaining close liaison with the Australian Customs Service, State Police Forces, Joint Task Forces and the National Crime Authority.
Several important achievements, in the area of terms and conditions of employment for AFP members, have flowed from Government initiatives undertaken during the current term of office:
the thirty eight hour week;
the working party appointed to review the terms and conditions of service applicable to the AFP from which flowed;
the 4.5% equitable base salary increase;
the detective/investigator's allowance;
the first overall review of the level of AFP allowances since 1980; and
a complete review of the Federal Police Arbitral Tribunal Determination which detailed terms and conditions of employment of members and included new conditions such as,
parental leave,
leave for adopting parents,
flying disability allowance.
The establishment of the Industrial Relations Branch within the AFP.
The majority of AFP Headquarters staff in Canberra will move into new accommodation in Northbourne Towers in December 1986.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education. I refer to cuts in the special purpose education programs, particularly those which concern the ethnic community. Can the Minister inform the Senate why so many programs of direct value to the ethnic community have been cut?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think all honourable senators will be aware that the Commonwealth Government has made substantial and lasting improvements in the educational opportunities for migrant children since the time of the Whitlam Government. Our contributions in those areas will continue to be substantial. In terms of special purpose programs, special teacher training, teacher development and review of curriculum materials to make them more appropriate for migrant children, the Commonwealth has and will continue to play a major role. However, as part of our budgetary restraint, we have been obliged to make some cuts in special purpose programs, some of which directly concern the ethnic communities.

ANSWER.PARA: It is important to put those cuts in the proper context. We have reduced funding for the English as a second language program, but we have also indicated at the same time that State governments can move further into that field. We will provide the States with the assistance to do so by making it clear to them that if they wish to nominate ESL provision as a target for the additional funds available under the resource agreements, the Commonwealth will certainly agree to that. I remind honourable senators that funds provided for English as a second language to new arrivals-the most needy group of migrant students-have not been cut at all. That program will continue at the same level. But additional funds for the ongoing element of the program may be sought under the resource agreements.

Also, we have had to decide against any further growth in the ethnic schools program. That program had burgeoned at a very dramatic rate in recent years and is now at a level that the Government is finding some difficulty in sustaining. However, we will sustain it at its present level. I point out to honourable senators that under the ethnic schools program, not one student or school currently in receipt of assistance will be disadvantaged. The Commonwealth had funded through the Schools Commission a small program called the multicultural education program. That has now been phased out. The reason is that it is now time, we believe, for schools in both state and non-government systems, to incorporate the multicultural perspective throughout the curriculum and make it part of the mainstream, not simply a small add-on approach to education.

Of course, the development of most interest to ethnic communities in the education area is the development and finalisation of a national language policy. We have almost finalised that very complex task and funds have been allocated in the Budget for early implementation of the national language policy. It should be remembered that all of the special purpose programs which most directly alleviate disadvantage have been preserved-that is, the disadvantaged schools program, the participation and equity program and basic learning in primary schools. Those programs are of benefit not only to mainstream disadvantaged students, but also, of course, to those migrant children who live in disadvantaged areas and attend schools targeted under the disadvantaged schools program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. It arises obviously from the excessive length of the Minister's answer. The Minister is either making a statement or debating the question. Those seem to me to be the two choices. She has certainly gone well beyond simply answering the question. I ask you to call her to order.

—There is no point of order. Senator Chaney would know that the Chair has no control over the length of a question or an answer. I have pleaded with questioners to reduce the length of their questions. This week I have pleaded with Ministers to reduce the length of their answers. I again make that plea and ask Senator Ryan to heed my remarks.

—Yes, Mr President, I will happily co-operate with you. In conclusion, the major programs of assistance to ethnic students will continue and the special needs of students from non-English speaking backgrounds will be given additional emphasis in all of the programs which the Commonwealth funds.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I will be very happy if the answer is brief. The Minister mentioned the national language policy. Can she advise when this policy will be presented?
—I should have available a penultimate draft document by November which will be the subject of further consultation with the ethnic communities and other interested parties.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy, and preface it by reminding the Minister that last Wednesday, in reply to a question by Senator Sanders in relation to uranium sales to France, he said that Australia would now seek to capture 25 per cent of the French uranium market and that this would open up opportunities for `Roxby Downs and new suppliers'. Does this mean that the Government anticipates that new uranium mines will be opened in the future in addition to Roxby Downs? If so, are Jabiluka, Koongarra, Ben Lomond and Yeelirrie among the likely new mines, and what are the names of any other prospective new mines? Finally, can the Minister say whether the Government will issue export licences for any new mines apart from Roxby Downs, or is it simply laying the groundwork for a future coalition government to do so? I would prefer it if the answer were not incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, neither Senator Haines nor Senator Sanders, who put out a very feverish Press release later that afternoon, were listening very closely to what I said the other day. I stated:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . in the context of the market for all practical purposes now being opened . . . it is therefore possible for Roxby Downs and new supplies-
not `suppliers'-
coming on to the market to now actively pursue the French market in a way that was not possible during the currency--

TALK.START.PARA: —Hansard says `suppliers'.

—Hansard got it wrong. I am very happy for Senator Haines to listen to the tape, if she has any problem with that. Obviously, that is what I intended because very shortly afterwards, in response to a question from Senator Kilgariff, which tracked over exactly the same territory as Senator Haines has got herself in a twist about today, I stated:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Labor Party policy on limiting to three the number of mines from which uranium can be produced and sold remains, I assure the honourable senator and everyone else, quite intact.

I said that about five minutes after I had answered Senator Sanders's question. There is no question of any change of policy in that respect so far as the Party is concerned. I was simply making the obvious point that in relation not only to the material coming on to the market from Roxby Downs, itself a new supplier, but also the new material coming forward from Nabarlek and Ranger, the French market would be open to both of those existing suppliers with their new supplies, in a way which was not previously the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport aware of the recent tragic accident in which two school children were killed while travelling in a school bus in south-west New South Wales? Does the Commonwealth have any jurisdiction over safety regulations concerning bus travel? If so, does the Government intend to review those regulations so as to improve safety?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have discovered the brief given to me by the Minister for Transport about the accident which occurred on 12 August in which a semi-trailer collided with a small bus at Balranald. All the indications are at the moment that the crash was caused by human error rather than problems with the maintenance or design of either vehicle. The report indicates that the school bus drove across the front of the semi-trailer. A range of safety features for trucks and buses is covered by the Australian design rules called up in State and Territory legislation. Operating safety requirements, however, are essentially matters for State and Territory administration.

ANSWER.PARA: The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport Safety reported in June 1986 on passenger coach safety and found that passenger coaches are in general a safe form of road transport. The Committee made a number of recommendations for additional safety items. These are under consideration preparatory to a formal response in Parliament. The vehicle standards committee of the Australian Transport Advisory Council is currently working on incorporating the latest overseas developments in braking for trucks and buses and looking at seat belts for front-row passengers and improved seat strength requirements in buses. None of those, though, would have had any effect on the results of the Balranald crash.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Will the Minister inform the Senate whether reports that, first, the New South Wales Teachers Federation and the Australian Council of Churches have been giving money to the FLNKS terrorist group in New Caledonia and, secondly, the Catholic Church in Australia has been funding the Philippine Communist Party-which has committed terrorist acts through the New People's Army, its military arm in the Philippines-are true? If so, why is the Government not enforcing the law which makes those in Australia responsible for this funding liable to 10- to 14-year gaol sentences under the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978?

—I have no idea of the factual foundation of Senator Sheil's question. I shall have the matter checked and respond accordingly. However, I doubt very much from the information he has given that there could be any question of a breach of that legislation, even if his premise is true. But I shall check and let the honourable senator know.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Will he confirm that the 1986-87 Budget shows a decrease of $7m in our bilateral food aid commitments and a halving of Australia's contribution to the world food program? If so, does that mean that this year the Australian Government will reduce its purchases of Australian grains? Will the Minister assure the Senate that these cuts will not affect our aid to major food shortage areas on the African continent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As recorded in the relevant Budget Papers, the 1986-87 Budget provides for a decrease of about $8m in our bilateral food aid commitments. As for the world food program, there has been a halving on paper which stems from the fact that no provision has been made in the 1986-87 Budget for a contribution to the next-1987-88-WFP biennium pledging period because the level of Australia's pledge has not yet been decided by the Government. That matter will be considered in due course in conjunction with an overall review of the food aid program, which is being conducted as a follow-up to the Jackson report of the review of the Australian overseas aid program.

ANSWER.PARA: The reduction in the food aid budget for 1986-87 will mean a reduction in grain purchased in Australia in wheat equivalent tonnages from 455,000 in 1985-86 to an estimated 320,000 in 1986-87.
