The reduction, which has been acknowledged as significant, in the size of Australia's food aid budget must nonetheless be viewed against the background of a difficult budgetary situation in which the aid program had to bear its share of the restraint necessary. The reductions in the food aid program have been made possible not only by deferral of a decision on any new commitment to the 1987 and 1988 biennial program of the WFP but also by a significant easing of the food crisis in sub-Saharan Africa, where improved conditions have resulted in a reduction in the number of countries critically affected by the emergency from 21 in 1985 to six in 1986.

Within the 1986-87 food aid budget, provision has been made for Australia to fully discharge its current-1985-86-pledge to the WFP and, at similar levels to those in 1985-86, to provide for refugee situations such as those in Pakistan, Somalia and Thailand and for displacement of vulnerable groups in those key African countries which are still suffering the effects of drought.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Despite the fact that the United States of America is moving to a lower corporate tax rate of 34c and with corporate rates of 35c in the United Kingdom, 33c in Singapore and 18c in Hong Kong already in place, the Government is about to go against the general international downward trend by introducing a higher corporate rate of 49c. Therefore, I ask: Is it a fact that the only countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development with a higher tax rate on distributed profits are France and Ireland, with 50c rates? Does the Government acknowledge that its proposed higher rate has been overtaken by events and will further decrease the rate of return to Australian business and actively discourage overseas corporations from seeking direct equity investment in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —We must at the moment concentrate on firms' pre-tax profits rather than after-tax profits. I would argue that the more serious issues in relation to this country's current problems concern pre-tax rather than post-tax profits.

ANSWER.PARA: I come to the specific point of the question. It is true that, according to newspaper reports, the taxation environment is changing internationally, particularly in the United Kingdom and the United States. I think that more sophisticated observers of the United States corporate tax proposals would not be deluded by the optics of what is happening there. I cannot provide an analysis at the moment but more sophisticated observers have. In fact, a dramatic decline in corporate tax rates in the United States is not taking place. The United States taxation system has been riddled with enormous concessions of one kind or another to businesses. As I understand it, the proposal is that many, if not all, of those concessions are to be abolished to obtain the optic effect of a 34 per cent corporate tax rate. What that means in real tax terms has to be analysed carefully.

Corporate tax rates in Australia are affected by, for example, a generous depreciation allowance-a five/three depreciation allowance-which by next year or the year after will, I think, cost revenue more than $1 billion. There is also a generous allowance in respect of research and development and a number of other such allowances which affect the direction of industry and ultimate corporate tax rates in a wide range of industries which are very important to this country.

I do not know what the particular comparative point about Singapore is. That point has been made for years, under all governments. Singapore not only has a relatively low nominal corporate tax rate but, for many years, it operated an economy which provided tax holidays of five years' duration to companies to attract them to invest in Singapore. The 18c rate in Hong Kong is not in any sense one that would be regarded as a comparable rate in an economy that is totally different and subject to totally different circumstances. The honourable senator said that France and Ireland had rates of 50 per cent. I do not know about them. I would be surprised if real corporate tax rates in Germany and Sweden were not higher than in Australia. Certainly, an altogether different picture is painted if one adds the other burdens imposed on corporations in those countries, such as the 93 per cent on-wage costs in Germany.

The point which I am trying to make-I am not in any sense trying to detract from what may be a valid point in the honourable senator's question; I concede that-is that many of these comparisons must be carefully examined before we can reach a particular conclusion about the Australian tax structure.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Will the Minister elaborate on the details of the changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, so as to prevent any misinformation by the Opposition? Will he specify, in particular, the details as they relate to the chronically ill and measures to ensure that such people will not be unnecessarily financially burdened? As the dispensing arrangements for the contraceptive pill have been changed so as to double the supply per prescription and, therefore, maintain current costs, is there any possibility of similar changes in other prescriptions so as to keep costs down for the chronically ill?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The new pharmaceutical benefits scheme, which as Senator Crowley knows will come into effect on 1 November, was introduced by Dr Blewett and the Department of Health in consultation with the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, the aim being to develop a more equitable scheme and also to provide for the chronically ill protection that does not exist under the existing scheme. The new scheme provides a safety net for those most in need who have to purchase large numbers of prescription drugs. From now on, an individual or a family, including concessional beneficiaries, will have to pay for no more than 25 pharmaceutical benefits prescriptions, after which they will receive them free. Pensioners and their dependants who at present receive prescriptions free will continue to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: The cost to general beneficiaries will go up from a maximum of $5 to a maximum of $10 but the average cost under the new scheme will be about $7.20 or $7.30. There will also be an increase for concessional beneficiaries and their dependants, who will now pay $2.50 as distinct from $2. The safety net will run for 14 months from 1 November 1986 to 31 December 1987. After that it will be based on a calendar year.

People will be able to obtain a prescription record voluntarily from their pharmacist. They will enter on a form the record of their prescriptions and, after 25 entries, the chemist will issue the family with a pharmaceutical benefits entitlement card, which will allow them to receive prescriptions free for the remainder of the year. In the case of oral contraceptives, as Senator Crowley has said, people will not have to pay more under the new scheme because the number of supplies per prescription will be doubled. In fact, the cost of oral contraceptives per year will remain at about $30. I have no knowledge as to whether Dr Blewett wishes to extend that provision to other drugs on the pharmaceutical list, but I will obtain that information for Senator Crowley. The Pharmacy Guild and the Government are convinced that the new scheme will provide protection for the chronically ill and is more fair and equitable than the previous scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and follows on somewhat from the question Senator Zakharov asked a while ago. I preface it by saying that no doubt the Minister is aware that studies done several years ago in countries such as Finland and Sweden, and a more recent study in Canada, have shown that the rate of accidents between two or more vehicles is reduced by about 20 per cent simply by requiring drivers to leave their lights on during daytime driving. In fact, when it was first introduced in Finland, in the first four years the accident rate dropped 27 per cent. I ask: Does the Minister agree that if this system were adopted in Australia, it could save some 500 or 600 lives per year? Will he therefore ask the Minister to investigate the matter and perhaps suggest to the States that it be incorporated in legislation?

—I have no direct brief on this matter. I have certainly seen the system in operation in Scandinavia and I know that the accident rate has been reduced in the Scandinavian countries. Interestingly enough, I went through the phase in the United Kingdom where drivers did not turn their driving lights on at night but just drove with parking lights. I remember the hoo-ha there was in England when the Government tried to get drivers to turn their lights on at night. I am afraid that the same thing would happen here. As Senator Townley knows, any suggestion that one should turn one's lights on or put one's safety belt on is likely to be considered a breach of civil liberties. I think it is a sensible suggestion and I will refer the matter to the Minister for Transport and get a considered response from him. Anything we can do to reduce accidents of any type and to reduce the considerable cost to the community, as well as the distress to individuals and families, is worth while. I will take up his suggestion in that spirit, refer it on and get a decent reply.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Education. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to criticism over the past few months of the Federal Government's contribution to tertiary education in Queensland? If so, are these criticisms justified and, in particular, can the Minister explain how tertiary education in Queensland will be affected by the 1986-87 Federal Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The claims made by the Queensland Minister for Education, Mr Powell, about unfair treatment for Queensland in terms of higher education places are absolutely wrong. On many occasions I have pointed out to the Senate and to the media how wrong they are. Mr President, in deference to your wish that Ministers should not make long answers, I briefly remind the Senate of the situation with regard to higher education places. Since our Government has been in office we have seen a growth in higher education places, which by next year will be a growth of 14 per cent. The number will go up by nearly 40,000 places to just on 300,000 places, which is an increase over that period of 14 per cent. In this time the number of places we have allocated to Queensland has grown by a massive 22 per cent-that is, 8,000 extra places. So while the overall growth has been 14 per cent, Queensland's growth in places has been 22 per cent. As well, it is our intention to continue to give preferential treatment to Queensland--
—Hear, hear!

—In terms of the allocation of higher education places because, indeed, Queensland was very seriously behind when we came to government in 1983. I am glad that Queensland's Senator Boswell acknowledges that. Since we have been in office we have been overcoming that backlog by giving Queensland a much higher number of higher education places than the national rate of growth. We are pleased to continue this strategy, but I only wish that the Queensland authorities and, in particular Mr Powell, would acknowledge what we are doing.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the Senate as well that in the Budget this week we have allocated foundation grants for one of the few new higher education institutions we are funding at this stage, the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education. That CAE, along with the Western Institute in Victoria, are the only two new institutions to be started next year. Without taking up undue time, the facts simply do not sustain the view put by the Queensland authorities that Queensland is being badly treated. The facts sustain my claim that Queensland has been getting preferential treatment and will continue to do so.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the answers given by the Minister yesterday to Senators Parer and Watson regarding the fringe benefits tax. I now ask whether the Minister can clarify specifically whether ex gratia payments made by a company to an employee or associate, as defined in section 136, paragraph 40, are subject to fringe benefits tax? There has been a specific request for this information. If the Minister is not able to supply it, I wonder whether he could arrange for an early statement to be made by the Treasurer.

—If I recall correctly, I did say yesterday that I would see whether the Treasurer had anything to add. I am afraid that I do not have anything now. I apologise for that. I will try to get the information for the next sitting day.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. As it is Senator Grimes today, it is especially appropriate that I direct my question to him because he is from Tasmania. Has he seen the letter published in today's Hobart Mercury, signed by the Liberal member for Denison, inviting the Minister to abuse him as much as he likes, and making sweeping allegations about the Government's financial treatment of Tasmania? What are the facts about these matters, especially the Government's funding of the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme? I ask him whether there is any relationship between the context of the letter of the honourable member for Denison and another letter in the same newspaper today from a long-standing member of the Liberal Party, in which she admits that the Liberal Party State Council:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . is certainly not the place for heavy intellectual input . . . We just meet to have a good time and see each other.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Coates says, it is a vintage day in the Hobart Mercury today, with letters from Liberal Party members of parliament and long-standing members and delegates, I gather, of the Liberal Party in Tasmania. Mr Hodgman's letter is, I suppose, in the form of a Press statement attacking the Federal Government's treatment of Tasmania, and I thought it was familiar. In fact, when we go back through the records, except for the short period when he was a Minister, he used to put out this sort of statement no matter who was in Federal government.
—At least he was consistent.

—Yes, very consistent. For years he used to put out statements complaining bitterly that the Federal Government had cut back the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme, cut back on expenditure and heavens knows what. I suppose the best example of the sort of tactic he uses is the example of the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme. He says we have reduced it by more than 12 per cent in real terms in the past two years. The only change that is to be made to the scheme will in fact be made this year when there will be a reduction in the fees that are paid for goods that are carried in trailers and pantechnicons. In fact that was a recommendation of the independent public inquiry into the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme which was carried out by the President of the Inter-State Commission, Mr Justice Everett. He made that recommendation because in fact freight charges for goods carried in these units has fallen on average by about 25 per cent, or about $470, since the last review in 1985. As the cost of that transport is less, then so will the estimated costs to the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme be less, by about $200,000, which is considerably less than one per cent compared to the 12 per cent Mr Hodgman talks about.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Hodgman is carefully ignoring the fact that the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme and the payout on that scheme is dependent on the amount of costs of transport. If the level of transport increases, the costs go up. If the level decreases, they go down. The figure in each Budget each year is an estimate of what will happen in future years. The figure for the payout of the previous year is an exact measure of the amount of transport. Some years it goes over the estimate and some years it goes under the estimate. But it is driven not by the amount of money made available by the Federal Government, but in fact by the amount of transport which goes across. That is an old trick of Mr Hodgman's, a trick which is recognised by bodies such as the Tasmanian Chamber of Industries, and I do not think most people in the State take much notice of him. Similarly his calculations in other areas are equally false.

I agree with Senator Coates that the letter which has been written by Mrs Lord is extraordinary. She says that the meeting of the State Council of the Liberal Party is just a chance for people to meet one another and occasionally hear a speech by a politician. She praises the speech made by Senator Sir John Carrick this year, although she is a bit disappointed that the media did not think much of it and did not print any of it. But she is certainly right when she says that the State Council of the Liberal Party in Tasmania is not the place for heavy intellectual input. Everyone knows that. The journalists report it that way. As she says: `We just meet to have a good time, to meet each other and to talk to each other'. Fair enough. I hope they continue to do that and have their nice social occasions. Then no one will take them seriously, just as they do not now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is he aware that for the 1985-86 year the Medicare levy would have needed to be set at 2.8 per cent of income in order to meet the cost of medical and hospital benefits as the amount of general revenue needed to supplement the levy equalled a further 1.8 per cent of the levy? How can the Minister support the Treasurer's claim that an increase in the levy to 1.25 per cent will enable Medicare to be self-financing, when the Government plans to spend nearly $4,000m on medical and hospital benefits in 1986-87 and the levy is estimated to raise only $1,795m over a full 12 months? Would the Minister therefore explain how a truly self-financing Medicare program could have less than a 2.8 per cent levy of personal income?

—One thing about the Senate and the present Opposition is that some things never change, and some things never change in the tactics that are tried by members of the Opposition. There has never been any suggestion by Dr Blewett, by Mr Hayden when Medibank was introduced, or by any Treasurer or Minister for Health on this side of the House, or by any Treasurer or Minister for Health on the other side of the House, that the levies that have been imposed by both parties to fund health insurance in this country would ever pay totally for the cost of health services in this country. That has never been suggested. It has never been a claim made by anybody. If Senator Knowles would like a long lecture on the exact figures in the past of universal health schemes that have been supervised by both coalition parties and Labor parties in this country and the difference between the amounts raised by the levy and the funding of health in this country, I will give it to her. I am sorry I do not have the exact figures here. I would hate to mislead the honourable senator. All I can say is that I will refer her to almost identical questions which have been trotted out in this place by members of the Opposition year after year, even when they were in government, to their own Ministers, who gave the standard reply. I will not bore honourable senators now or I will have Senator Chaney getting up taking points of order on me.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. The Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, in his speech in reply to the Budget last night, reneged on all the coalition's spending promises with the exception of abolishing the assets test. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the expenditure promises the Opposition has abandoned? Is the Opposition's promise to eliminate the deficit now credible on the basis of this change to the coalition's fiscal policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noted the statement Mr Howard made. One of the more bizarre events of contemporary Australian politics is that at a time when the nation is facing very serious economic problems the Opposition's formula for overcoming those problems is to resume paying pensions to millionaires and to bring back the free boozy business lunch. That is about the depth of its contribution. However, I suppose I should be grateful that after having personally attempted for many months to get Mr Howard to come clean on the $2 billion of additional expenditure he has been running around the country promising everyone, he has now cut that down to a bit more than $150m in additional outlays. There is a great deal more of course on tax expenditures or revenue foregone.

ANSWER.PARA: These are some of the promises-incidentally the list is not exhaustive-which Mr Howard last night repudiated: The promise to underwrite sugar at $240 a tonne. Let it be noted by the National Party of Australia and by everybody in Queensland that last night Mr Howard repudiated that promise formerly given by the Opposition to underwrite sugar at a price of $240 a tonne. That has gone right down the gurgler. I hope that when the National Party tries to speak with the other fork of the Opposition tongue, the other prong of the forked tongue with which it normally speaks, it will be noted and accurately reported in Queensland that in fact Mr Howard has repudiated that undertaking.

He repudiated the promise to pay a full excise rebate on fuel used by farmers-that is $137m. He repudiated the promise of full freight equalisation-another $110m. He repudiated the promise to provide greater funds for rural adjustment. He repudiated the promise to remove the excise on brandy. He repudiated the promise to abolish export inspection charges. He repudiated the promise to restore tax benefits on income equalisation deposits and to remove the sales tax on oils and lubricants. That is just a sample of the promises that were repudiated by Mr Howard last night. Mr President, as you will have noted, all those promises deal with the rural sector. It was the National Party's shopping list of political goodies that he repudiated last night. I have not even started on the Leader of the Opposition's own list of political goodies which he repudiated last night. Mr President, in view of your exhortation to keep answers short I will not go through the whole list of promises repudiated last night. I will save that for the future.

Notwithstanding the fact that the Leader of the Opposition repudiated almost $2 billion worth of promises that he had been racing around the electorate for the last 12 months gladly handing out to every pressure group he met, the Treasurer yesterday costed the Opposition's list of tax expenditure promises-these are not outlays but they would blow the deficit out-to $5.9 billion. In addition, if Mr Howard's policy on wages were implemented, pay as you earn tax collections would fall by $400m. His Medicare policy would also lead to a very significant increase in net outlays as would the vague recommitment to have compulsory work or training as a prerequisite for the unemployment benefit. When all those things are put together the bottom line is a blowout in the deficit to more than $10 billion.
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the House to come to order. I want every honourable senator to appreciate that Senator Walsh is being generous in co-operating by giving a short answer.

—I promise that I will be very short. Even though the Leader of the Opposition repudiated $2 billion worth of sacred promises and undertakings which the Opposition had given, the bottom line, if his policies were implemented this year, would be a deficit blowout to more than $10 billion-even more than the one he left behind for this Government to cope with.

—I refer the Minister for Education to the intended administrative charge, as I believe the Government likes to call it, on university students. First, was the dollar value of the charge plucked from the air as being some sort of symbolic collection of administrative costs, set purely by reference to political pragmatism or has the Government made a conscious decision in principle to recoup all or a proportion of administrative costs? Secondly, if the latter is the case, what percentage of administrative costs on average, or roughly, does the charge represent? Thirdly, has the Government set firm criteria for what can be classified as administrative costs by a university? If so, will the Minister make those criteria available to honourable senators?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The $250 administrative charge which some categories of students in colleges of advanced education and universities will be required to pay does not represent a specific proportion or percentage of administrative costs. Although the Government looked at the possibility of working out the level of the charge in that fashion, the administrative costs of institutions vary very widely according to the size of institutions, their age, the extent to which they enrol external part time students and so forth. There really is not an average figure which would fairly generalise the administrative costs of institutions.

ANSWER.PARA: If Senator Vanstone is interested to know the breakdown between administrative and tuition costs in institutions my best advice would be to direct her to the annual reports of institutions which set out quite clearly their academic salaries bill, expenditures on libraries and so on. I am sure that Senator Vanstone is familiar with those reports. If she reads a few of them she will see that there is an enormous variation in the extent to which costs other than those directly related to the employment of teachers and research staff are incurred. The figure represents no particular proportion of the costs.

The advice I received when this matter was being developed was that between 8 per cent and 20 per cent of an institution's costs are administrative. As Senator Vanstone will note, that is a very wide variation. So the charge does not represent a percentage of a particular cost. Rather, it represents the Government's view of what would be a fair contribution from students and what level of charge would very clearly delineate it from the cost of tuition fees.

We did not want there to be confusion in the minds of students or institutions about our intentions. Our intentions are very clear. We require the better-off students in higher education institutions to make a contribution at a flat rate determined by us as being fair and reasonable and about which we have announced our future intentions; that is, that the $250 will be indexed according to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission index of institutional costs that we use for the cost supplementation of grants to institutions. There is no more precise basis to the charge than that. I conclude by saying that in our view and I think in the view of many people that is a fair and reasonable contribution to expect from students who, after all, are benefiting to the extent of $6,000 up to $14,000 a year by way of the place they hold for which no tuition fees are payable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Do I understand from the Minister's answer that the charge has been set at a small amount relative to the expected costs of, say, tuition fees so that there is no misunderstanding in students' minds as to the Government's intention? Given that that is the case, will the Minister give an undertaking that in the next Budget the Government will not-

—Order! The second part of the honourable senator's question is out of order. It is seeking additional information. With respect to the first part of the supplementary question, does the Minister wish to answer?
—I do not think that there is anything to add.

—I refer the Minister for Finance to the comments that the Opposition Leader, John Howard, made on this morning's edition of the radio program AM in relation to the construction of the Alice Springs to Darwin railway line. Can the Minister give an indication of the current estimated costs of any such proposal and whether the Opposition Leader's position on this issue is consistent with that of the Northern Territory Country Liberal Party Government?

—This was one of the Opposition promises, reiterated as recently as three weeks ago at the Country Liberal Party conference in Alice Springs by the undertaker-by the National Party Leader-which I should also say that Mr Howard this morning repudiated. That promise was to build a railway from Darwin to Alice Springs. I think that Mr Howard actually said this morning-I do not have a transcript but this is my recollection-that the Northern Territory Government has a proposal for a private railway and that the Opposition supports it. Mr Howard had to be boxed in before the interviewer could get that much out of him. He did not want to talk about the repudiation of the Northern Territory railway but the interviewer jammed him a bit and in the end Mr Howard said that it was a proposal for a private railway and that he supported it.
—We will not sell uranium to France.
—It is called a proposal for a private railway by the territorial-
—Senator Walters made a whole series of new promises. They are not going to sell uranium to France.

—I did not hear that. It was called a proposal for a private railway by the Northern Territory Government but hidden away in that private railway proposal was a capital grant from the Commonwealth Government of $150m. So if the Leader of the Opposition says that he supports that proposal, he supports the $150m capital grant to go with it. It was claimed by the Northern Territory Government that the railway was viable on the basis of a very shonky economic study which firstly ignored the capital cost of the line and secondly assumed a very optimistic level of freight growth. It further assumed that all freight moving between Darwin and Alice Springs would be carried on the railway and nothing on the road, and assumed that all freight would travel the full distance from Darwin to Alice Springs without any being dropped off at Katherine or any of the other places along the track. Then finally for good measure it added on so-called external benefits to the rest of the Australian railway system because of the goods that would be carried on the rest of the system from Alice Springs to wherever it might go to. To the extent that those benefits exist, they exist whether the link between Alice Springs and Darwin is by road or rail. Finally, this demonstrates, as the Sydney Morning Herald said this morning, that Mr Howard's rhetoric is fine, but the specifics and the details of what he proposes to do make him unbelievable or put him in danger of not being believed, and I am sure he will not be.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator Vallentine asked me about the nuclear safeguards arrangements applying to Australian uranium in France, and how the requirements of the Government's nuclear safeguards policy are actually met in respect of this nuclear material. I am happy to now supply, as promised, some fuller information to supplement that which I gave yesterday. I seek leave to have that information incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Yesterday Senator Vallentine asked me about the nuclear safeguards arrangements applying to Australian uranium in France and how the requirements of the Government's nuclear safeguards policy are actually met in respect of this nuclear material. Assurance that uranium supplied to France by Australia would be used for strictly peaceful purposes stems from the requirements of the Australia/France and Australia/Euratom nuclear safeguards agreements and application of nuclear safeguards by the International Atomic Energy Agency and Euratom to nuclear material supplied to France for peaceful purposes.

Australia's bilateral safeguards arrangements with France are based on international legally-binding undertakings and obligations. They provide that Australian uranium will not be diverted to military or nuclear explosive purposes nor used for research thereon; and that Australian uranium and derived nuclear material will be covered by IAEA safeguards to verify compliance with this.

The bilateral safeguards agreements, together with France's `voluntary offer' to accept IAEA safeguards on nuclear material in peaceful use provide the basis for applying safeguards entailing the accounting for and control of Australian origin nuclear material in various stages of the fuel cycle. Australian origin nuclear material in France is also subject to Euratom safeguards. The Euratom safeguards system verifies by inspection and accounting procedures that nuclear material supplied for peaceful purposes is not diverted to military or nuclear explosive purposes.

Under the Administrative Arrangements to Australia's bilateral safeguards arrangements a system of records and reports has been established by which the Australian Safeguards Office is kept informed of Australian origin nuclear material in its various forms in bilateral treaty partner countries. This information provides the basis for periodic reconciliation of accounts kept by the ASO with those kept by its counterpart organisations. These accounting procedures confirm that Australian uranium in France remains in exclusively peaceful use. Further information on the way in which the ASO accounts for Australian uranium is set out in its 1984-85 Annual Report which I tabled in Parliament earlier this year.

Senator Vallentine fails to appreciate that in accounting for Australian uranium supplied to France it is not necessary for this material to be physically separated from uranium provided by other countries. National origin is attributed to nuclear material on the basis of equivalent quantities rather than particular atoms of nuclear material. This is the basis of nuclear accounting and is a well established approach in a number of other domestic and international commodity areas where there is a mingling of material from various sources. A rough analogy may be drawn with banking: we do not expect to withdraw the vary same notes and coins as we have previously deposited but we do ensure that the value is the same. In the same way we are concerned to ensure that the requisite quantities of nuclear material in France are identified as of Australian origin and accounted for in accordance with our nuclear non-proliferation requirements.

Each country which is a nuclear weapon State has a separate fuel cycle for production of high enriched uranium for weapons production purposes. In the case of France, this weapons grade enriched uranium is produced at the Pierrelatte facility. The civil nuclear enrichment facility to which Australian uranium is transferred is located at Tricastin. For operational reasons, including that of nuclear criticality, it is not possible to produce high enriched uranium, in a civil plant. This physical separation at one of the most sensitive stages of the fuel cycle provides an additional measure of assurance.

Data made available to the ASO confirm that the quantities of Australian origin nuclear material anticipated to be present in the French civil nuclear fuel cycle do actually exist, are precisely accounted for and are clearly labelled with the obligations which Australia has imposed by virtue of its nuclear safeguards agreements with both France and Euratom. In addition to IAEA safeguards applied to Australian uranium in France this material is at all times subject to safeguards measures prescribed by Euratom and is available for inspection by Euratom Safeguards Directorate inspectors. It is the imposition of these obligations on Australian uranium that ensures that it is not diverted into nuclear weapons fuel cycles.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN DELEGATION TO THE SEVENTY-FOURTH CONFERENCE OF THE INTER-PARLIAMENTARY UNION IN OTTAWA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the report of the Australian delegation to the seventy-fourth conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union held in Ottawa, Canada, in September 1985.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate a statement concerning that report in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

The 74th Conference of the IPU was held in Ottawa, Canada, over the period 2-7 September 1985. The Australian Delegation comprised myself as Leader, the Hon. Ian Wilson, MP as Deputy Leader, Senator Margaret Reid, Senator Kerry Sibraa, and Mr Peter Baldwin, MP and Mr Peter White, MP of the House of Representatives.

From the outset, I wish to commend the Delegation for the work which they undertook in Ottawa as representatives of the Australian Parliament, and to thank them for their co-operation and assistance throughout the period of the meetings.
The Conference was attended by 459 Members of Parliament from 94 countries.

With respect to the attendance of countries, I wish to place on the Hansard record, as has been similarly done within the text of the Report, the fact that at these meetings Papua New Guinea was admitted to the IPU as a new national group. It is with considerable pleasure that I report that the Deputy Leader of the Delegation, Mr Ian Wilson, and I had the honour to be the first to congratulate the Leader of their Delegation, Mr Speaker Bonga of the National Parliament, on the admission of his Group.

The topics discussed at the Conference were a reflection of the close links which the IPU has forged with the United Nations over past years. Given that the UN had designated 1985 as International Youth Year, it was fitting that there was an item on the Conference agenda which concentrated on youth, and their problems and needs in a most complex national and world environment. It was appropriate that to this item was attached a further subject dealing with the role of Parliaments in combatting illicit international drug trafficking. I found the debate on this joint topic to be most constructive and worthwhile. It was one to which all national groups contributed in a most humane and positive manner. The fact that the Conference unanimously adopted a constructive and far-reaching Resolution was most gratifying to me, to Members of the Delegation and, I am sure, to all participating national groups.

Given that 1985 marked the 40th Anniversary of the United Nations, it was fitting that the work of the UN concerning its efforts towards decolonisation was listed as another topic for debate. The Australian delegation participated fully in the consideration of this item. As Honourable Senators might suspect, it was not the most harmonious of debates. Australia contributed significantly in the Committee deliberations on this item, intervening on a number of occasions to preserve the decorum of the Committee's proceedings and to ensure a balanced debate. It is appropriate that I indicate to the Chamber that the Delegation was not happy with its outcome. Whilst the final resolution put to the Conference was adopted by a substantial majority, its passage was not achieved with Australia's support. The Delegation was unable to support in full the contents of the Resolution because in the opinion of the Delegation it lacked balance in several significant areas. Of particular concern was the fact that the Resolution singled out certain countries for mention, making specific attacks on their policies, which could not be substantiated or which, equally, could be levelled at many of the nations making the accusations.

A further item considered at the Conference related to the burden of foreign debt, particularly as it affects developing countries. Although this subject was a complex one and one in which many contrary views were expressed, it is pleasing to note that the Resolution as finally agreed to by the Conference was achieved by a unanimous vote.

Each of the three subjects are dealt with in detail in the Report and I suggest that Honourable Senators will find many aspects of the Report and the Resolutions passed by the Conference to be of interest.

As Leader of the Australian Delegation for three Conferences, I have given some consideration to the role of the IPU and the part played in it by Australia. I believe that when Parliamentarians meet together for the purpose of discussing topics of mutual interest to their Parliaments there are great opportunities for many positive contributions to be made and these can only improve understanding between nations. As I have said in my preface to the Report, however, the Australian delegations that I have led have questioned seriously the subjects which continue to be placed on the agenda with the support of certain national groups. These, essentially, are divisive topics and rarely achieve positive results. Unfortunately, this practice is becoming more frequent and such topics tend to appear on the agenda year in and year out. I would prefer that future topics be more constructive and ones that an organisation such as the IPU can more effectively and profitably deal with. As Leader of the Delegation at future conferences I will be attempting to draw to the attention of other Leaders in appropriate forums the need for the IPU to recognise its potential in these areas, and that it should address the harm it is doing to its effectiveness and reputation. I will be developing this thought further in the Delegation's Report arising from the Mexico Conference held earlier this year.

In conclusion, I again thank my Parliamentary colleagues who accompanied the Delegation to Ottawa. I thank the organisers of the Ottawa Conference for their most hospitable and warm welcome, and the efficiency with which they ran the Conference. I thank in particular the Australian High Commissioner to Ottawa, Mr Laurie, and his excellent and most capable staff for their help, assistance and support to the Delegation whilst we were in Ottawa. The tireless efforts of the Secretary to the Delegation, Mr Tom Wharton, and the Department of Foreign Affairs' adviser, Mr Geoff Crawford, must be also recorded. All members and accompanying persons were grateful for their assistance.

The report which I have just tabled provides an account of the deliberations of and conclusions reached at the 74th Conference of the IPU held in Ottawa, Canada, with particular reference to the contributions made by Members of the Australian Delegation. It contains, as Appendices, the principal resolutions agreed to by the Conference and the speeches made by the Australian Delegation.
I commend the report to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the report of the Australian delegation to the seventy-fourth conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union in Ottawa, I recommend to honourable senators that they read the statement which Senator Colston has just incorporated. Conference interparlementaire
ORGANISATION FOR CONSULTATION AMONG WOMEN PARLIAMENTARIANS AT THE INTERNATIONAL LEVEL
CONCERNED about the small number of female parliamentarians in IPU delegations.

—In our report.

—Very much so. I want to mention Ruth Barber, who looked after us to a considerable extent. She has worked for the Australian High Commission in Canada for over 40 years. Last year she was made an honorary member of the Order of Australia. She came to Australia last November to receive the award from the Governor-General.
