DEBATE.TITLE: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (EQUAL OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the debate on the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill before the lunch break I was describing how poorly qualified women who are employed in the clothing trade. I should have included in that description women working in the textile and footwear industry as well. These women constitute a very large proportion of the female work force. There are no fewer than seven extremely large enterprises whose employment total is about 25,000 workers. These workers will be involved in the first stage of our affirmative action program. We hope that the opportunities for women in those industries will be greatly enhanced by the genuine and prompt adherence of their employers to the requirements under this new legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point about the clothing, textile and footwear industries is that less than 10 per cent of the employees in those industries have trade or other qualifications. Of that less than 10 per cent, 90 per cent are men. It is absolutely clear that an enormous amount of disadvantage is being suffered by women in those industries. I might add that at present an enormous amount of restructuring and rationalisation is going on. There is also an appreciation by employers, assisted and encouraged by the unions, of the need to provide education and training on the job to enhance the qualifications and opportunities of the women in those industries. We hope that the affirmative action legislation will be arriving at just the right time to add a boost and a fillip to the opportunities of those women.
Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill

Senator Boswell's contribution to the debate reminded me of what a very prominent Queensland woman said at a meeting of business and professional women not very long ago. She said that at first she had been hostile to the concept of affirmative action. This woman, Sallyanne Atkinson, the Lord Mayor of Brisbane, went on to say that she had felt initially that the idea of affirmative action was rather patronising of women. That idea has been served up on a number of occasions in this debate. However, a few days prior to the particular meeting at which she had made this statement she had been required to employ a public relations officer. Naturally enough, she had selected the best qualified of the applicants. Subsequently, her judgment was questioned-`A woman? In an important position like that?'.

As Gloria Steinem would say: `Click'-meaning that moment at which one's personal experience sheds light on a previously poorly understood philosophy. That click is yet to happen amongst many members of the Opposition in this place. I know, for example, that the leadership of the Country Women's Association is still in the dark. The click has not occurred to them. I do not wish to sound critical; I am simply suggesting that they have yet to be exposed to such experiences. Having chaired the Western Australian Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation for several years, I can cite dozens of cases from city and country, large and small enterprises, primary, secondary and tertiary industry that demonstrate the need for this legislation. In 1986 women are still being denied the range of opportunities available to ordinary men simply because they themselves are not men and are ordinary women.

Within the last few weeks I have had an experience in regard to the mining industry in the Pilbara. A group of six workers had been employed there on a temporary basis. This group included two women. They were working on a promise of consideration for permanent jobs as vacancies arose. The four men were given jobs; the two women were left languishing. As a result of working with those particular men, the women knew that their qualifications were equally good for the jobs that were being offered. When I made inquiries of the management of that particular company I was told: `Oh yes, if we are looking for drivers of course we want people with years of experience, not those who have just acquired their B class driving licence'. It had not occurred to that management that there are other qualifications required of drivers besides years of experience. Twenty years of holding a driving licence does not necessarily qualify one to be classified a crash-hot driver, nor does it mean that one is able to cope with the tedium, the boredom, and the hours and hours of repetitive work that is required for the sort of driving which these people were going to do; it does not necessarily mean that one will turn up for work on time; it does not necessarily mean that one will do an honest day's work for an honest day's pay. These are factors that we are asking be taken into consideration, for a change, in relation to the selection choices still being made in many industries.

Senator Knowles's contribution was somewhat academic. It was not unfamiliar to those of us who have read the work of Dr Gabriel Moens, which is described by Marian Sawer of the Social Justice program of the Australian National University as a `slip-shod, second-hand and repetitive case for the status quo'. There was much reference in the honourable senator's speech to the downgrading of excellence and merit. Of course, nothing is further from the truth as far as this legislation is concerned. We believe it represents an opportunity for the upgrading of skills, for the identification of merit and for the encouragement of excellence amongst women, not just amongst males. We had a whole lot of references to things such as collectivist outcomes and other terminology with which Dr Gabriel Moens generously fills out his publications. Once again it is jargon that has no relevance whatsoever to this legislation. We simply have to acknowledge that there is a group of people for whom there is a philosophical objection to equal opportunity. I quote further from Dr Sawer's critique of Gabriel Moens's Affirmative Action: The New Discrimination:

While Moens waxes eloquently on the injuries done to `innocent persons' through affirmative action programs, he is curiously silent on the injuries done to `innocent persons' when private corporations decide to move their capital elsewhere, or to replace workers by robots. Injuries can only be inflicted, apparently, by public policies designed to improve employment equity, not by `market forces'.
Much of Moens's work is designed to play on the prejudices of those who are opposed to equal opportunity for women.

They will go on at great length about how they really do believe in equal opportunity, but obviously there is that deep-seated objection which they are no longer-perhaps this is an improvement-prepared to acknowledge.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been the same people for 100 years, haven't they?

—I would think that is quite accurate. The same sorts of people tend to take that attitude towards managerial prerogatives as well. We could argue until we were blue in the face and we would not change their minds. There still are managers in this country and elsewhere who believe that they have no social responsibilities whatsoever. I am glad to report that those numbers are diminishing and, in the face of the lead that is being given by this Government through this and other legislation, we hope there are not too many by the year 2000.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walters managed to spend about 10 minutes criticising other women; I would not stoop to do that. I think her position can be described most accurately as unreconstructed Neanderthal. I am very disappointed about that because I thought that as a result of exposure to some more progressive arguments in the last two or three years she might have managed to change her mind. I would not bother to discuss her intervention except for the fact that she was completely inaccurate, and I believe deliberately so, about the National Agenda for Women, which is now nearing the end of its period of consultations within the Australian community. The whole point of the National Agenda for Women, of course, for anybody who takes the trouble to find out, is to consult Australian women.

I am very interested to hear Senator Walters's criticism that from what she has seen of the Agenda it has tended to concentrate on those issues which are closest and of most immediate importance to women. The whole point of the Agenda is to ask women what their priorities are. The pamphlet, copies of which have gone out very widely in some tens of thousands to Australian women, is asking them to nominate their priorities. If they wish to include issues such as taxation, transport, housing and international affairs, nobody will be more delighted than I. I hope-indeed I trust-that over the last few years there have been more women who are inclined to take a wider view of their position in the world rather than just their position in Australia or in their local communities. It is interesting to note that internationally the conservative view is that women should confine their participation to matters which affect them immediately and directly. That is not our view in Australia. Our activities in the last few years have been directed towards opening up the minds and imaginations of women beyond their immediate spheres.

I find it also very strange that Senator Walters believes it is perfectly okay for women on average to be earning only about three-quarters of what men are earning on average. This means quite clearly that women do not have access to the better paid jobs. I think that is appreciated by Senator Walters, but her insistence that women choose lower paid jobs is quite extraordinary and defies even my imagination, which I think is possibly a little better than hers. The jobs that are available to women are those that are lower paid, stereotyped, and concentrated in a few occupations. The justification for our legislation is clearly laid out in the appendices to the second volume of our publication on affirmative action. I would urge Senator Walters to expand her knowledge just that little bit, which would give her that sort of understanding. I find it very sad to hear her putting this point of view, emphasising differences between women, instead of working on the similarities. We all know that typically a woman's life is one of phases. If she combines a career with child bearing and rearing she will be in and out of the work force, looking at some stages for part time work and at some stages for full time work. This has been recognised within the women's movement and within the Australian Council of Trade Unions for some time now. A great deal of effort has been put into making accessible part time work with a range of entitlements for women, ensuring that other measures are put into place to make it possible for women to combine a career with their domestic responsibilities to give them something like the chances that men have always had in this society.

One of the contributions from the Opposition mentioned the stagnation of women promoted beyond their levels. I ask honourable senators: Do only women stagnate if promoted beyond their levels? That level of debate completely ignores the fact that many men are in jobs which are beyond their capacities. Out there in the community there are many women in jobs that are below their capacities.

Senator Vanstone gave us a list of women who she believes will not be helped. She made some of the same mistakes Senator Crichton-Browne made, in referring to the fact that she believes that migrant women, women in part time employment and so forth, would not be at all assisted. Measures of this nature have a flow-on effect to everybody in the community. They start off, we hope, by sensitising management-not just the management of large enterprises but also management who will see from the point of view of their own enterprises that it makes good managerial sense to provide a range of opportunities, training and encouragement across the whole of the work force, not just for that small group of males towards whom it previously had directed its aspirations.

In addition to the sensitisation of management, we have those other effects-the opportunity for women to show that they can do jobs that had previously been considered beyond their capacities, too stressful or too demanding. Those women act as models and provide encouragement to other women-young women or older women who may see that there are some possibilities for them at the age of 40, 45 or even 50 to retrain, to expand their opportunities and to use their potential. Women also become gate-keepers. The concept of gate-keeping is an extremely important one, and it is particularly easy to identify within the education system, where in the past the inspectors, all males, have been the gate-keepers, the ones who opened the gate for promising young males. What we are saying is that there are promising young middle aged and maybe even more mature females waiting to be identified, to have their skills developed. This can be only an advantage to Australia in a macroeconomic sense and to individuals in a personal sense.

We are not just about women as managers, as seems to have been assumed by Senator Vanstone and others; we are about women being given the opportunity to develop their skills, to move into whatever sphere of activity they are capable of doing, given the chance. It may be that a secretary is able then to join the administrative stream. It may be that a clothing trade worker who has been on a machine for years is given the opportunity to become a cutter or a forewoman or to train for another job. It may be that a nursery worker is given the opportunity to study horticulture and to expand his or her opportunities. We are about horizontal and vertical equity. Much as I would like to continue for the other five minutes to which I am entitled, I am aware of the constraints on our time. I am very grateful for the support we have had from many honourable senators and am very satisfied to know that this important piece of social reform will be with us and in operation before very long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Peter Baume said on behalf of the Opposition when opening the second reading debate on the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986 in this place on 12 June, the Opposition will support the passage of this Bill. The reasons for our support have been outlined by Senator Peter Baume, and by the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, in the other place. We have, however, made it clear that our support is given with some significant reservations. As Senator Peter Baume has said, these reservations include the additional burdens to be imposed on employers, the additional government bureaucracy, the additional regulation and the additional cost. These are all matters that are quite contrary to the thrust of the Opposition's whole approach to government. For that reason we have reservations about this legislation. The strength of our reservations varies from one member of the Opposition to another. My personal reservations are strong. I will explain them and my reasons for them in the course of my remarks today.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make it absolutely clear at the outset that I totally support the goal of equal opportunity for all. I support equal employment opportunity for all because, as Senator Peter Baume said in his speech, it is a fundamental Liberal goal to seek to empower people in their lives. My reservations to this Bill are several. They relate to the question of whether the objectives of the Bill, which I have just outlined, can be achieved by the type of action that is now being foreshadowed in this legislation. As I said a few moments ago, the additional regulation and bureaucracy, the burden on employers and the additional costs cut across the thrust of my Party's approach to government. As coalition parties, our policies are directed towards less bureaucracy, less regulation, fewer burdens on business and less cost. I will return to some of these points later in my remarks.

My other reservations about the Bill relate to whether it will genuinely enhance equality of opportunity. If I thought it would, I would wholeheartedly endorse it, subject only to my cost and regulatory reservations. I doubt, however, that it does. If the Bill were to reflect genuinely the aspirations and needs of Australian women, I would support it; but I doubt that it does. I would argue that this legislation, in fact, works against these principles. Despite the Bill's rhetoric of equality of opportunity, in practice it is likely to favour a counter-principle of equality of outcome.

The Bill represents a significant element of the Government's National Agenda for Women. But, when the Australian Labor Party talks about women and the needs and aspirations of women, it does not mean the majority of women in Australia, or the majority of women in the work force and certainly not the majority of women in the home. Rather, it tends to mean a small section of radical feminists who are not representative of the majority of Australian women. It is said by the supporters of this legislation that it is going to alleviate sexism. In fact, by forcing employers to consider individuals as representatives of their sex, it will perpetuate the very sexism it seeks to counter.

The Bill's concept of the merit principle is at best ambiguous. It can be argued that the underlying concept of merit in the Bill is not necessarily the best person for the job but, rather, the person who is just good enough, the person with the minimum qualifications. The amendment which has been circulated on the definition of merit in the Bill does not seem to me to overcome that quite basic difficulty. Dr Marian Sawer, a well known supporter of this Bill and a leader of the feminist movement in Australia, has described the merit system as a fable. She has said:
Merit has historically been an extremely inflexible concept and generally operated to exclude those who differ in significant ways by organisational gate keepers.

As the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women and the undisputed founding figure and caretaker, perhaps, of this Bill, it is illuminating to look at Senator Susan Ryan's views on this subject. Whilst adamant that the Bill will not violate the principle of merit, Senator Ryan, too, holds the implicit assumption that to date it has yet to be genuinely applied. She says:
The concept of merit and the application of the principles in individual situations is fraught with difficulties . . . the concept is so important and yet capable of so many and varied definitions.

The implicit conclusion endorsed by this Government is that employers, by and large, have employed people not on the basis of merit but on the basis of their sex. The merit principle is regarded as having yet to be used. Only a Bill such as the one before us will allow for its genuine operation, say the proponents of the legislation. That is an attack on Australian employers. It is saying that it is not the talents, aptitudes or levels of education, training and experience that have been uppermost in the minds of Australian employers in selecting employees, but rather that candidates are considered as representative of their sexual group. We might ask ourselves: If the concept is so important and yet, at the same time, so capable of so many varied definitions, why did the Government not seek to define `merit' in the Bill?

Most of us would understand the merit principle as being the selection of the best or most competent person for a job. The best applicant is selected in a procedure that requires an assessment of candidates on the basis of their formal qualifications and individual characteristics which are genuinely relevant to the job. This Bill will result, I believe, in an erosion of this principle and will invite reverse discrimination because in practice employers will be required to consider individual candidates, not necessarily on their merit but rather as representatives of their sex. Let me give the Senate an example. The South Australian College of Advanced Education, which was selected by the Government as a pilot for its voluntary affirmative action scheme, states in its affirmative action policy explanatory notes:

Staffing Committee (shall) be required to examine the percentage of male and female staff on contract, both academic and general, and take the relevant percentages into account when considering tenure.

In other words, whether a man or a woman will be given tenure is not to be determined by his or her merits and achievements, but rather by something over which he or she has no control and which is unrelated to his or her merits and achievements, namely, the effect that it will have on the male-female ratios in the institution.

Another illustration of this trend is the announcement last year by the New South Wales Department of Education that, from the beginning of 1986, 40 per cent of all vacancies for promotion must be filled by female teachers. The Department did not even bother to include anything at all about promotion on the basis of merit or even seniority. By forcing employers to take into account the sex of candidates for positions in their businesses and institutions, this legislation runs the very serious risk of perpetuating sexism-something that we are all trying to get away from.

We should be aware that, if this Bill is enacted, as it will be, a high proportion of all organisations with more than 100 employees will be getting the female-male ratios right. Employers will be required to reassess, and perhaps lower, their standards.

I will provide a very illuminating example from Professor Lachlan Chipman. At his university the professor of geophysics had a vacancy for a lecturer in his department. It just happened that his entire staff was male, this being a field in which men have traditionally outnumbered women. He sought permission to advertise for a lecturer, stipulating the requirement, which is quite common today, that inter alia the successful applicant should have a PhD in geophysics. The equality of opportunity officer asked him two questions, having seen the advertisement being processed through the system. The first question was: Are there significantly more men than women with a PhD in geophysics? The answer was clearly yes. He was told that the PhD requirement was clearly discriminatory because it was a criterion that significantly more men than women satisfy. The second question he was asked was: Is it absolutely necessary to have a PhD in order to be capable of performing the duties of a lecturer in geophysics? The strict answer was that it was not. There have been distinguished geophysics lecturers who have never completed a PhD, although their numbers are small. On this basis, the professor of geophysics was informed that he could not include a PhD requirement in the advertisement but he should specify a level of qualification which represented the minimum standard necessary to be capable of performing the job competently and that was likely to be the `least indirectly discriminatory'. The professor replied that such a standard would be a good honours degree in geophysics and remarked in passing that if the best applicant had a PhD he would recommend that person's appointment. The equal opportunity officer at the university retorted:
You certainly can't do that as this would involve discriminating on the basis of qualifications not specified in the advertisement.

The lesson of these examples is clear-that is, reverse discrimination has already been practised under the auspices of the pilot program. The Bill now before us contains no provisions to stop it; indeed, it implicitly endorses it. Proponents of the Bill have repeatedly denied that it involves the setting of quotas. However, the objectives and forward estimates required by the Bill are, in effect, likely to be the same as targets and quotas. They will be centrally determined outcomes which are dependent upon the ideology of the policy makers of the day rather than the individual views and judgments of employers and employees.

The Australian Labor Party's dangerous dream of imposing an egalitarian blueprint on Australian society will be advanced one step with the passage of this legislation. That blueprint calls for equality not just of opportunity-surely equality of opportunity is something with which no Australian would disagree-but also of outcome. Down that path lies mediocrity and the demise of the pursuit of excellence, and it has the dreadful greying effect of bringing people to a common denominator, regardless of their strengths or weaknesses, their interests and aptitudes, and their sex. That is what socialism is all about-the greying of our society. If anyone doubts that that is the approach of members of the Government let me quote a recent address from the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women, Senator Ryan, one of the architects of this Bill. She stressed the importance of the availability or supply of suitably qualified women, an importance with which I agree. She stated that the success of affirmative action programs:
. . . needs to be preceded by equality of opportunity and indeed, more importantly, equality of outcomes in education.

Supporters of the Bill have made the correct observation that statistically women are under-represented in the work force. However, from this they have drawn the conclusion that this proves sexual discrimination. I think that is very dubious reasoning. Under-representation does not, in itself, represent or demonstrate sexual discrimination. This conclusion is rarely discussed. It is assumed that it is so obvious that little need be said in its support. However, there are a number of reasons to explain the statistical under-representation of women in the work force. They go far beyond educational opportunities, employment opportunities or employment practices. Numerical imbalances result from a range of complex cultural factors including individual choice, differences in aptitude and interest, determination to succeed in and develop a career, parental investment in children, which can vary, and chance or sheer accident. Looking at the statistics of representation can be a very dangerous and misleading path to follow.

Scant regard has been given to the damage that this legislation will do to those women who have and will gain positions on their own merits. For successful women doubts must always remain. Was it their sex that got them their job? In most cases the answer would be quite categorically no, but imposing these sorts of objectives and targets, particularly if they lead to quotas-which they may well do down the track-does great damage to the position of those people.

This Bill is yet another instance of the Government's misunderstanding of and hostility to the functioning of a free market. If an employer persistently hires labour on criteria irrelevant to the job his business will be a very inefficient enterprise and the market will judge him accordingly. Even so, there is a surfeit of existing government equal opportunity agencies and commissions overseeing employment practices in Australia. At least these have the virtue of judging discrimination on an individual basis, not as a collective phenomenon. If discrimination occurs our various equal opportunity agencies have sufficient power, and rightly so, to penalise the offending employer.

The last thing business needs is another layer of regulations that entangle enterprise in more bureaucratic red tape and impose additional costs. It is thought by some that because the Bill does not include legal sanctions for failure to go along with its provisions it should not be opposed and there are no grounds for concern. Such a view is naive. It implies that employers consider breach of legislation as unimportant. It implies that the business community pays scant regard to the due processes of government, that being named in parliament has no impact on one's standing in the community. The Government has argued that the business community supports this legislation. However Australian businesses partook in the pilot program, under the auspices of the Office on the Status of Women, on the understanding that voluntary schemes are the way to tackle the issue, not proposed prescriptive legislation. On the last count they are sticking to this view. There is not support for this legislation in the business community.

This legislation represents a considerable burden on business. It has been described to me and to others as a bureaucratic nightmare. For example, large companies which have a large number of subsidies-there are many such companies-will be required to reformulate employment data for incorporation in their reports to the new agency at great cost. They will be required to explain why mines in northern Australia, metallurgy departments in Thomastown, apprentice intakes and so on do not reflect the particular industry average.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his second reading speech argued that the costs of this scheme will be minimised by the small size of the administrative agency and the avoidance of unnecessary paper work. The estimated initial cost is put at $1.5m per annum in the explanatory memorandum to the Bill. That includes the expenses of the Director and 25 staff at the Office of Affirmative Action. However, history is replete with instances of agencies, once established, generating their own growth and momentum. There is no indication that this scheme will be contrary to historical record. Indeed, there is every reason to believe that history will well and truly repeat itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not while I'm around, it won't.

—I hope Senator Walsh is right. But listen to some of the arithmetic because, to me, it is simply not feasible for 25 people adequately to assess and monitor a total of 4,538 establishments. The Office of the Status of Women has informed me that, of those 4,538 establishments, 65 are universities and colleges of advanced education, 516 are private enterprises employing over 1,000 people, 525 employing between 499 and 1,000 people, and 3,443 employing between 100 and 499 people. Each of those establishments will be required to submit two written reports-one for public consumption and the other confidential-annually. That is a total of 9,076 reports. How on earth can 25 people adequately handle this mountain of paper? Quite clearly, they cannot and quite clearly, therefore, the pressure will be inexorable-even, I believe, on Senator Walsh-for ever increasing expansions in that capacity.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to that requirement are the other functions of the agency-research and community education activities, and monitoring and evaluating the effectiveness of programs. That ignores all the other costs such as those I have already mentioned-for example, those relating to the business sector. As Professor Mark Cooray pointed out recently, this Bill, in the tradition of the Australian Labor Party social legislation, contains no provision for aggrieved persons to seek judicial determination regarding allegations of wrongdoing. The reason for this is clear. If the courts are given such power, concepts such as merit will have to be decided through a process of rational argument. By opting for the political enforcement of the legislation in the person of the Director of Affirmative Action, the Government has given itself the freedom to interpret the law according to its own political persuasion.

In summing up, there is no doubt that this legislation will have far reaching social and economic consequences for Australia. Some of those consequences may well be seen by many people to be adverse, despite the commendable overall objective of the Bill. Whilst not opposing the Bill, the opposition, though, believes that it has serious deficiencies. It will move a series of amendments in an attempt to correct some of these deficiencies. I believe that these amendments deserve the support of this Parliament because we, as a parliament, ought to be aware that we are dealing with what is a very significant piece of social legislation for this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is entirely appropriate that I take the opportunity in the debate on the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986 to congratulate Senator Janine Haines on her election to the leadership of the Australian Democrats. It was an historic election. She has taken her place as the first women to lead a political party in this House. She did it all without the benefit of affirmative action or equality of opportunity legislation. Indeed, many people associated with this chamber have achieved eminent positions on their own merit without the benefit of this legislation. I refer to Senator Lady Bjelke-Petersen, who sits beside me in the chamber, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle who sits in front of me, and yourself, Madam Acting Deputy President. I refer also to Miss Anne Lynch, who is one of the four members of the top echelon in the office of the Clerk of the Senate. All of these ladies have achieved their positions without the benefit of any such legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I took the trouble to look up the origin of affirmative action. It was a term that was introduced during the administration of the late President John Kennedy in America. It was intended under his Administration to mean that any legislation that was passed had to take into account the effect of the legislation on minority groups in that country. Of course, in very short order, certain viragos, termagants and shrews saw the opportunity of using that kind of thought in determining how they could twist this legislation to their advantage. They declared, for a start, that women were a minority group, which had nothing to do with the meaning of affirmative action. They then twisted the legislation again so that it was not merely a matter of taking into account the interests of minorities, but it had to favour the minority. Of course, they declared women to be a minority. Certainly, if legislation is used in that way, one is trying to cure discrimination by creating more discrimination, which is rather similar to trying to cure a snake bite by giving a person another snake bite. Members of the National Party of Australia who have spoken before me have shown that they are entirely opposed to this legislation. Our policy, particularly in Queensland, is entirely opposed to affirmative action. The title of this Bill is a misnomer. The legislation is sneaking in as an affirmative action Bill, whereas in effect it is ostensibly an equal opportunity for women Bill.

If one looks at the text of the Bill, one sees that it is intended to change the attitudes of people. This kind of government administrative decree has been tried in various countries around the world. I do not know why we do not take notice of what has happened in other countries. I refer, for example, to what happened in Iran when the late Shah of Iran tried to emancipate the women of that country to some degree, particularly in regard to education, job opportunities, dress, and marriage laws. He caused such a revival of Islamic fundamentalism that the whole country was turned upside down. A similar set of circumstances occurred in Japan when that country tried to change the attitudes of its people-that is, men and women-to the way in which women lived in that community. There has been a return to fundamentalism in Japan. That came about because of the attitude of the women. I have had experience in working under legislation that incorporated equal opportunity laws. They were a complete failure because the way in which people work with each other depends on their attitude to each other.

These attitudes do change over the years. For example, in the days of our grandfathers it would have been the philosophy of the family to educate the men and domesticate the women, because that is the way the world worked at the time. But when my father had his family, all members of the family were educated to the same degree. I have two sisters who are graduates and two brothers who are graduates. We all work and have happy relationships with each other and with the community. So there has been a gradual change. But legislation was not needed to bring about such changes. When we introduce legislation such as this, there has to be an administration to run it. The Government is crying poor mouth trying to streamline the operations of government, to make it more efficient. But it is introducing a bureaucracy which has nebulous powers and no teeth with which to administer its department. It is just creating another expensive bureaucracy which will grow.

I remember when measures such as legal aid were introduced. We were told that legal aid would cost just a little bit to start with. But the assistance began with a much bigger budget than had been expected and expenditure escalated sharply. I am sure that this legislation will be the same and that staff numbers will increase as well. The Bill will introduce more controls and restrictions. It will give the unions another stick with which to bash employers, as though employers are not already under enough union dominance. Here is another union arm which will restrict employment flexibility. Here is the Government saying that it wants to free up the work force and trade unions, but this legislation will be another way of making the work force more inflexible.

Honourable senators have mentioned the two types of report which will have to be produced every year-one public, one confidential. That will be another reason why employers will not feel like employing people any more. I do not want to rehash the debate, but the question has been asked: Will a woman who has achieved a position of some eminence feel that she has done so on her own merit? She might suddenly realise that she has obtained her position because of affirmative action. She might be just a token appointment. The framers of the legislation deny that. They say: `No, the legislation will not have that effect. People must be appointed on merit.' Who will say in the report at the end of the year: `There were no women good enough to be put into this position.'? Which employers will be brave enough to say: `This year, there were no women worth promoting.'? I am sure that, if many women were promoted, there would be no problem. But if, for some reason, not enough women were promoted, an employer might feel that he had better promote some women so that he did not fall foul of the affirmative legislation. A stigma may even be attached to women because they were appointed under the provisions of this affirmative action Bill.

The National Party of Australia is completely opposed to affirmative action in all its forms. As this is an equal opportunity Bill and not an affirmative action Bill, it seems that we will go along with it, although I see it as a toe in the door for social engineering which should never be contemplated in a free democratic country of ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the thrust of the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill. Our understanding of that thrust is such that we wish to ensure that the legislation is not misinterpreted as being `affirmative action' in the quota sense in which that expression has been used currently and some years ago in other countries, particularly in the United States of America and especially by women's movements. We so understand the thrust of this legislation to be equal employment opportunity that we wish to amend the Bill's title from `Affirmative Action' to `Equal Employment Opportunity'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government hopes that by calling something which has bipartisan support `affirmative action' it will somehow be able to placate the extreme advocates in Australia and overseas, particularly in the women's movement, with the idea that it is achieving some of the goals of affirmative action and quotas which are not acceptable to the Opposition. Following various arguments, those goals are now not acceptable to the Government. There is something of a pea and thimble trick and some misleading of the public in the Bill's title. The Opposition and I contend that it is only a slogan and that the genuine and substantial thrust of the legislation is towards equal employment opportunities for all Australians. We support that thrust.

For decades, it has been the Liberal Party's conviction that we need values that maximise fairness and freedom of opportunity for all alike. The Liberal Party's political philosophy is based on freedom of the individual. It was my sorry observation, particularly during my first years as a senator, that my Party did not sufficiently live up to that clear principle, which my colleagues and I and our supporters had always upheld. My Party has had a dialogue with many women, in particular, but I must not exclude the various articulate men who welcome a considerable revolution in values and social expectations. We have deliberately determined, therefore, that we will put into practice and reality the achievement of the principles which we have espoused for decades. While there has been that transition from theory to practice amongst Opposition members, there has been a similar percolation of views in the Labor Party. But there has been also an extreme movement, which the Government does not now support, based on the old meaning of `affirmative action' and the achievement of quotas.

Senator Peter Baume, the Opposition spokesman on community services and the status of women, in his speech during the second reading debate, accurately set out the Opposition's views. He carefully set out the Opposition's principles and practical goals as well as some of the history of women's achievements in Australia. He relied on a great deal of material-`pace setting', if one likes to call it that-showing the outcome in my State of South Australia. I do not need to repeat those points which Senator Peter Baume so accurately and carefully addressed. He referred also to those matters to which we object which relate to the slogan `affirmative action'-a slogan without content. We intend to amend the Bill thoroughly to substitute `equal employment opportunity' wherever `affirmative action' is written. We intend also to limit the unnecessary cost to industry and the educational institutions and the bureaucratic machinery and to abolish the need to report, which is proposed in the Bill.

We do not welcome the fact that a new statutory authority is to be set up to monitor what is a voluntary program that builds on the successful work of the pilot project, which we have all so favourably observed. We want to take out the slogans and overstatements. To that end, in Committee we propose moving 40 amendments, 20 of which are substantial, the other 20 being contingent on the major change to emphasise equal employment opportunity.

I wish to refer especially to higher education institutions. Honourable senators by now have heard me on many occasions talk about education matters, not the least higher education matters, and one of those matters to which I have referred a number of times in recent years has flowed from a Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts inquiry into the tenure of academics. I had the honour to chair that inquiry. In that report, which was put down in the Senate in September 1982, there is a specific section on the employment of academics in our universities and colleges which relates to equal opportunities for men and women alike. The sorry situation is that, whereas 45 per cent of higher education students were women, only some 20 per cent of higher education employees and staff in those institutions were women. It is a sorrier story when we see that in 1981, the last time for which figures were available to the Committee, only 2 per cent of professors were women; only 4 per cent at the associate professor and reader level were women; 9 per cent at the senior lecturer level were women; 18 per cent of all lecturers were women; and about 40 per cent of tutors were women. The average number of women on staff in universities was 16 per cent, whereas 45 per cent of all students in our universities were women.

In the colleges of advanced education there is a similar pattern whereby those at the senior level, the most responsible teaching and researching roles, are small in number, with some higher proportions, but still less than 50 per cent, at the lowest level. The average for all our colleges of advanced education, on the last occasion these statistics were developed, was 22 per cent. It was the goal of the Senate Education and the Arts Committee in reporting to the Senate some years ago that a number of proposals we recommended be put in place so that the sad outcome for opportunities for women could be redressed. To this end in our report to the Senate we addressed some five factors that we felt had led to this poor outcome. On pages 88 and 89 of the Committee's report we referred to those five factors. The first was that, being realistic, until quite recently women had underestimated their own abilities. Whereas a smaller proportion of those who undertook and completed honours year studies went on to higher education, the highest degree they undertook was mostly a masters degree and not a doctorate degree, despite the fact that of those who undertook first and second grade masters degrees more than 70 per cent of those graduating were women; in those highest grades only some 40 per cent were males. Women have a capacity for achievement, ability and excellence. It is evident from those statistics that women have the capability to do very well with a masters degree, yet only a very small proportion actually enrol for a doctorate, the highest research studies.

The second factor was a lack of mobility and, of course, family responsibilities that are the lot of many women. There has been too slow an acceptance in Australia of both men and women alike being responsible for the care of children, especially small children in the home, and domestic duties. Until recent years that great burden has fallen almost exclusively upon wives and mothers rather than upon husbands and fathers.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADJOURNMENT

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 4.15 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my habit to speak on the adjournment, particularly when people are anxious to leave Canberra, but it is my understanding that the Government intends to vote against the adjournment motion and, indeed, has the support of the Australian Democrats in doing so. That means that the Senate will continue to sit. Again, I understand from discussions between the Whips and between myself and the Manager of Government Business (Senator Grimes) that this is for the purpose of completing the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986, which is currently being debated. We are seeking to amend that legislation to entitle it the Equal Opportunity in Employment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to express in the strongest possible terms the objection of the Opposition to what the Government proposes. The suggestion that we sit tonight is a suggestion which was made only today and it is just the latest of the actions which demonstrate that the Government not only cannot handle the Australian economy but cannot handle the Parliament either. The situation is that, having demonstrably failed this week to bring down a Budget that could win any public acceptance, the Government cannot run the Senate program with any efficiency at all. I suggest that, if we are to be kept here, the Government should organise a chook raffle. That will show that it is not capable of doing even that.

The unfortunate situation we have is that the Government apparently has organised the numbers to keep us sitting, without warning, after it had reduced the first period of sittings from two weeks to one week. Opposition senators were notified initially that there would be a two-week sitting period in the month of August. Subsequently the Government determined that it would reduce that sitting to one week, with a three-week break before we come back for a further parliamentary session. We have already had our arrangements significantly messed about, but to have them messed about with the amount of notice we have had today is completely unconscionable and really does nothing at all for this institution. Quite apart from anything else, the Parliament no doubt will be put to additional expense. A great number of arrangements will have to be broken. I know that many senators have already had to cancel engagements they had entered into. Additional transport costs will be incurred and no doubt additional costs of running this Parliament will be incurred-and why? It is because the Government believes that it is in some way important that we should deal with this affirmative action legislation as a matter of urgency.

I do not think there would be very many people in Australia who would regard the extension of parliamentary sitting hours to Friday night as being necessary in that particular cause. If we were to deal with some legislation that was going to do something about the extraordinary interest rates in Australia, about the rising level of unemployment the Government is predicting, about the fall in private investment, about our diminishing standards of living, there might be some virtue in it. Instead, we have a government which is determined to debate issues which for most Australians, I am sure, are peripheral to their central concerns. This legislation is being given priority at this stage, and at very great inconvenience to everybody concerned.

I must say that I am missing Senator Chipp already. Senator Chipp was not always predictable in these issues, but I have to say that on the issue of extending parliamentary sittings he had some rather strong views. I do not think he would have been very impressed with the idea that we had to extend the first week of sittings in a new session. I am sorry that his successor has not shown a bit of character in this matter and is prepared to put everybody to this inconvenience.

If one looks at the way this week's business has been dealt with, the Opposition ran one matter of urgency, which took a couple of hours of parliamentary time. We took less than the amount of time we were entitled to in General Business, and we did not seek to debate the South African statement that was put down. The great bulk of this week has been devoted to Government Business. It is not the fault of the Opposition that the Government saw fit to give priority to legislation bringing the Commission of Inquiry to an end and the legislation relating to parliamentary remuneration and the reduction of parliamentary salaries. It was not the Opposition's doing that these matters took priority over the affirmative action legislation, which originally had been listed as the Government's own priority. On the list that was circulated last week that was put forward as the Government's priority. In fact it was not given priority in the legislative calendar of this week, and again that is a mark of the Government's lack of organisation of its program.

Even at this late stage I would ask the Government to reconsider the inconvenience that it is imposing on everybody, quite unnecessarily, and to no good effect. I believe that the Senate should adjourn now. I think we have done the work for which we were summoned here this week. It is the Government that has said that we should not be back here next week. I think it should maintain the hours that it predicted when it called us back to this place for this week of sittings.
Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (EQUAL OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was interrupted I was referring to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on tenure and our references in a section of that report that called for equal opportunity in employment in higher education institutions. Having set out the statistics of a lamentable outcome for the proportion of women employed at various levels in our institutions, I was addressing the reasons why this had happened. I referred first to the unfortunate underestimate that many women have made of their abilities in their preparation for such employment, many having taken masters degree studies rather than doctoral studies, so excluding themselves from competition with those men who have taken the higher qualifications and gained the broader skill and experience.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I was referring to the lack of mobility and opportunity that has arisen by women more than men feeling the burden of family responsibilities. Whilst I have been aware very much in the last five years that increasing numbers of men have recognised this and are moving towards taking a equal share of domestic responsibilities including the care of young children, it is still very much the case that this is the biggest factor that has distracted women from gaining a fair employment opportunity in higher education institutions. I know a family in Adelaide of which one member is a senator. For the last 10 years priority has been given, following quite conscious and well discussed decisions, to the ability of that senator to perform his role not only here in the chamber but also throughout South Australia and about the country. The wife in that family is equally capable and equally able to make a contribution to the local and wider communities. She is equally well prepared as a result of background study and training as a teacher. Yet even after that senator has been in this place for eight years she is a part time teacher and the senator works full time. Whilst that situation is often the case we do not have enough self-awareness, however carefully thought out and shared the decisions may be. Too often men have priority of outcome concerning the contribution they make and the way they make available their abilities, expertise or experience to serve in their profession.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not least in politics.

—Not least in politics. I have a special admiration for those women amongst us in the Senate and the House of Reps. I have an equal admiration for their spouses who have reversed the roles that I have just outlined. This placing of priority on family responsibility and on lack of mobility--
—Oh, a PhD such as you talking drivel.

—I see that the Senate Whip on the other side disagrees with my assessment. I believe that those values are too infrequently stated in this Senate. In this debate on the second reading of an important measure I will demonstrate that there are senators who want to take up this matter. Senator Robertson can have his turn in a moment.
—I was simply saying that a man with a PhD talking such drivel is an insult to our education system.

—I believe that the values about which I am talking are important. I am ashamed that a senator in this place does not share those values. A fourth factor that has led to the outcome which I have lamented is the vicious circle resulting from promotion panels and appointment committees in higher education institutions too often being even exclusively made up of men; they have had insufficient representation by women. This problem is being addressed. One of the thrusts of this Bill is to improve these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: In the closest university to me in my State, the University of Adelaide, there has been some pace-setting towards achievements to this end. To some extent this has been encouraged by the sorts of views that I have just tried to summarise and that we have urged in the Senate Committee report. Attention has been given in that university to the findings of the Senate Committee.

Finally on this matter, I refer to the lack of women representatives in the tenured levels of universities. I have already said that some 40 per cent of tutorial positions are held by women but the figure is only some 2 or 3 per cent for professorial positions. In the most tenured areas there are few women; in the less tenured and contract positions there are more. It is not a solution, and the Senate Committee did not see it as a solution, to tenure tutors so that they can have more secure and permanent employment within a university. The solution must not be to change the definition of tutor but to ensure that there is genuinely equal opportunity for women to gain the existing tenured positions in the more responsible teaching and research areas of universities and educational institutions.

As to the solutions, the Committee pointed not only to an awareness of these disabilities and the loss of resources to our higher education institutions but also to the need for specific measures to overcome the problems. As we have said more generally about this Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill, the specific measures do not introduce coercion by quotas. They are not to put in place unnecessary bureaucracies or set up statutory authorities. They are not to have costly reporting and monitoring procedures. By direct decision we can see new flexibility in the way men and women are employed in our higher education institutions.

More opportunity to have extended leave without pay should apply to tenured fractional appointments, as well as flexibility, especially for men and women who are caring for young children. I will expand on that briefly. At the moment it is possible to be tenured in a university or college if a person is full time. Why cannot half time positions also be tenured so that a person has the same security of employment and the same commitment and over a long period can build experience and expertise in teaching and research? This could take into account people's family responsibilities or any other legitimate community responsibility. I am convinced that if there were half time tenured positions the factors that I have outlined would be better addressed and overcome.

Regarding extended leave without pay, it should be possible for lecturers or senior lecturers-whether they be men or women-who have young children to seek from a higher education institution leave without pay for a four- or five-year period. During that time when they are preoccupied with the care of small children they could voluntarily, because they have tenured positions and know that after a period of years they will return to the same work, periodically, even weekly, come back to the department of which they are a member, remain the recipients of all the usual journals, newsletters or other materials on what is happening in their department and even attend seminars or give an occasional lecture to keep in touch, while choosing the option of taking extended leave without pay. On return to work they can go back to the commitment they had in that higher education institution. It is these kinds of solutions which we set out in the recommendations of that tenure report. If I have spoken a little at length on this matter it is for two reasons: First, this Bill directly addresses all higher education institutions in Australia; secondly, the Government has not yet responded to the Senate Standing Committee's report on tenure. If it is seen that this Bill is to some extent an indirect response by the Government to what we called for in the Senate Committee, that is a degree of Government response. But I understand that this year, after some advice from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, there will be a formal Government response to the Senate report on tenure.

In the thrust of the legislation before us, I believe that there is a move-more than words-towards concrete aspirations and goals in achieving some of the aims we have set out, and to redress the lamentable decades in which women in particular have seen reduced opportunities for such employment. I refer now to two other matters before the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Senator Ryan) replies to the second reading debate-merit and flexibility of employment. The principle of merit is enshrined in an early clause of the Bill. Clause 3 (4) states:
Nothing in this Act shall be taken to require a relevant employer to take any action incompatible with the principle that employment matters should be dealt with on the basis of merit.

This is the distinguishing feature of the Bill and means that it is not an affirmative action Bill, in the sense that most people have understood that term, but it is an equal employment opportunity Bill. No one who gains employment in Australia should feel the sense of inferiority or even guilt that they have gained such a position because they are part of a quota, or because although they lack the merit they were given the chance just to even up the numbers. It is demeaning and it does not make the grounds for that person to have the confidence, to have the ability, to achieve the work, the goals and the tasks for which that position has been created. The only way for a person to have confidence and ability to achieve in a position of any employment is for that person to know that he has applied for a job on an open basis and that he was the best person available. The question of merit is to us in Opposition the distinctive aspect of this Bill that has led those of us who most strongly support its thrust to gain support for it, nevertheless, with our amendments. There is an explicit rejection of quotas. There is no appeal to mediocrity, but rather to excellence.

Whilst not supporting prescriptive legislation, or any new statutory body, or any form of employment quotas, the Opposition supports the thrust of this legislation because it is, by this principle of merit, equal employment opportunity. The Opposition also supports any initiative for a voluntary program on equal employment opportunity for women. The Opposition supports the removal of discriminatory and restrictive legislation, and discriminatory and restrictive regulation. The Opposition supports improved educational opportunities for women, and voluntary action and incentives. Some of my colleagues have, perhaps at too great length, noted those matters of bureaucracy, regulation, costs, and interference which are matters in this Bill which we will seek to remove by amendment.

Regarding flexibility, I have already spoken of extended leave and of tenured part time work. I make the same remarks more briefly about job sharing, about part time work in every respect, about flexible hours and even flexible leave in certain seasons of the year. The flexible arrangements for employment called for are much more facilitated by the industrial relations policy of the Opposition than by the inflexible aspects of the accord. I am sure that Government senators will agree with me that the accord has for too long stayed with the orthodoxy of not allowing sufficient flexibility for shared work, for part time work, and for flexible hours. The Opposition's industrial relations policy will greatly assist that.

In all, we support the thrust of this legislation because we want to see fairness in outcomes and in social values in Australia. We want to move towards that by education, not by regulation; by aspiration and goal setting that is voluntary, not by quotas or bureaucratic mechanisms. When we reach the Committee stage, those aspects to which we object, when amended, will make the thrust of this Bill more effective.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable senators for their contributions to this very important social reform Bill which, when in place, will provide better work opportunities for all women who work in the private sector and in higher education institutions, and all women who aspire to work in those sectors. Because the reform is such a major one it has provoked a number of differing responses from honourable senators in this place. I acknowledge that a reform of this character will not have exactly the same measure of support from every person in the place. Nonetheless, I think it is a remarkable fact that the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986 is being supported. (Quorum formed) Before the quorum was called I was on the verge of concluding the second reading debate and thanking honourable senators for their contributions, diverse as they were, and noting that it is a very important fact that the legislation is supported by the Opposition and by the Australian Democrats. I thank them for their support. I also place on record my gratitude to Senator Peter Walsh, who represented the Liberal Opposition on the working party, which is the basis of this legislation.
—That is almost as good as Senator Brownhill.

—I am sorry-Senator Peter Baume, who represented the Liberal Party on the working party and who made a very constructive contribution. As the concerns of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats are set out in their proposed amendments for the Committee stage, I will not take the time of the Senate in commenting on specific concerns now. The second reading amendments moved by the Opposition are not acceptable. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

That the words proposed to be added (Senator Knowles's amendment to Senator Peter Baume's amendment) be added.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by indicating that the Opposition has 41 amendments to the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill, but it is our hope that, with the agreement of the Committee, we might consider the first 18 amendments together since they all address the single question. Our first amendment is to the title of the Bill and the next 17 amendments are consequential to that title. Therefore, I seek leave to move the amendments together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Title, leave out the title, insert the following title: `An Act to promote equal opportunity in employment matters, to establish the office of the Director of Equal Opportunity, and for related purposes'.
(2) Clause 1, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
`1. This Act may be cited as the Equal Opportunity in Employment Act 1986.'.
(3) Page 2, clause 3, sub-clause (1), definition of `affirmative action program', leave out the definition of insert the following definition after the definition of `employment matters':
`equal opportunity program', in relation to a relevant employer, means a program designed to ensure that-
(a) appropriate action is taken to eliminate any unjustified discrimination by the relevant employer against women in employment matters; and
(b) measures are taken by the relevant employer to promote equal opportunity in relation to employment matters;'.
(4) Page 2, clause 3, sub-clause (1), definition of `Director', leave out the definition, insert the following definition
` ``Director'' means the Director of Equal Opportunity;'.
(5) Page 4, clause 5, sub-clause (4), leave out `affirmative action program', insert: `equal opportunity program'.
(6) Page 5, heading of Part II, leave out the heading, insert the following heading:
`PART II-EQUAL OPPORTUNITY PROGRAMS'.
(7) Page 5, clause 6, sub-clause (1), leave out `affirmative action program', insert: `equal opportunity program'. [not necessary if (28) is agreed to]
(8) Page 5, clause 6, sub-clause (2), leave out `affirmative action program', insert: `equal opportunity program'. [not necessary if (28) is agreed to]
(9) Page 6, clause 8, sub-clause (1), leave out `affirmative action program' (thrice occurring), insert: `equal opportunity program'.
(10) Page 7, clause 8, sub-clause (2), leave out `affirmative action program', insert: `equal opportunity program'.
(11) Page 7, clause 9, sub-clause (1), leave out the sub-clause, insert the following sub-clause:
`(1) There shall be a Director of Equal Opportunity.'.
(12) Page 7, clause 10, sub-clause (1), paragraphs (a) and (d), leave out `affirmative action programs' (twice occurring), insert: `equal opportunity programs'.
(13) Page 7, clause 10, sub-clause (1), paragraphs (e), (f) and (h), leave out `affirmative action to achieve' (thrice occurring).
(14) Page 8, clause 13, sub-clause (1), leave out `affirmative action program' (twice occurring), insert: `equal opportunity program'.
(15) Page 9, clause 13, sub-clause (3), sub-paragraph (b) (i), leave out `affirmative action program', insert: `equal opportunity program'.
(16) Page, clause 14, sub-clause (2), leave out `affirmative action program', insert: `equal opportunity program'.
(17) Page 10, heading of Part V, leave out the heading, insert the following heading:
`PART V-DIRECTOR OF EQUAL
OPPORTUNITY'.
(18) Page 13, clause 31, sub-clauses (1) and (3), leave out `affirmative action programs' (twice occurring), insert: `equal opportunity programs'.

One of the requirements for the success of this legislation is that it receive community acceptance. One of the features which have already appeared during the debate and which have been referred to, erroneously, on a number of occasions, is that people argue that this is an affirmative action Bill. This may come down to semantics, but people have believed that this an affirmative action Bill as affirmative action is generally understood.

I go back to the analogy I drew in the second reading debate involving a running track with two lanes. One lane has hurdles, the lane marked `women', and one lane has no hurdles. As I understand it, an equal employment equity measure would remove the hurdles from both tracks altogether. Affirmative action, as many people in society understand it, is a measure which would move some of the hurdles from the women's track to the men's track. In other words, it would make it harder for men to catch up. That is as many people understand it. Many people define affirmative action as giving preference on the basis of gender.

The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) made clear in her second reading speech, as is clear from the legislation and from what she has said since, that she has no intention of giving preference on the basis of gender. I come back to clause 3 (4) of the Bill where the principle of merit is enshrined. But I say to the Minister that it is the name of the Bill that causes difficulty particularly in some of the more conservative groups in this society. They are the people one would like to see supporting the legislation and they believe that this is an affirmative action measure, as they understand that term, which involves gender preference.

The Government has redefined affirmative action to mean equal employment opportunity. That is a kind of Gareth Evans semantic nonsense. To define affirmative action, which means one thing out in society, to mean something else is fine if one is just using words, but if one is trying to talk about getting legislation which people will understand and appreciate for what it is and which they may then wish to support for what it is, it is not unreasonable to look at the title carried by the legislation and to say that that title may affect the degree of acceptance which the legislation has.

There is a general community understanding that affirmative action involves some kind of preference for a disadvantaged group and that when it is affirmative action for women it involves some gender preference. It is our belief, and the Minister has confirmed this on many occasions, that she is talking about a Bill for employment equity. In seeking to have the title amended the Opposition is proposing to do nothing more than to have the name of the legislation reflect what it is. There is nothing wrong with our proposal to have the Bill renamed, as proposed in our first amendment, to call it an Act to promote equal opportunity in employment matters. There is nothing wrong with that because that is what the Minister has been saying in all her speeches. That is what she is about. We are asking nothing more than that she should allow an amendment to call the Bill what it is rather than to call it a Bill to promote affirmative action.

I believe that one of the reasons why the term affirmative action has been used is as a sop to members of Labor's own radical wing who wanted an affirmative action Bill. Senator Haines, who is not in the chamber at the moment and who I understand may not wish to support the amendment, called the Bill soon after it appeared an affirmative non-action Bill. In terms of affirmative action, as she understood it, this is not an affirmative action measure. I have spoken to a number of women concerned about affirmative action and they do not regard this Bill as an affirmative action measure. It is not. It is a Bill about employment equity. Perhaps it is quaint and old-fashioned, but we are supporting the measure and want to see it called what it is.

Opposition members believe that if we call this legislation what it is-that is, a Bill about employment equity-many more people will understand it for what it is. A lot of unnecessary community concern will be put to rest and it will be much easier for people such as I moving within the Liberal Party, moving within the liberal people, even moving within very conservative groups in society, to promote the virtues of this legislation if it is called what it is rather than, as Senator Haines said, an affirmative non-action Bill. As it is not an affirmative action Bill, it is entirely logical to name it what it is.

The other 17 amendments we propose merely go through the Bill step by step and reflect the words `equal opportunity in employment' throughout the Bill. We are suggesting that the title be changed and that appropriate consequential changes be made to answer the very criticism made by Senator Haines and by many women who spoke to me when this Bill first appeared. I make these comments against the background that we support the legislation, but the task we have of winning community support for the principles of the legislation is made more difficult by a title which has been designed to appease a more radical group of women but which has not appeased them and which is doing great harm and causing great misunderstanding among some more conservative groups that could be great supporters of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not accept the arguments put by Senator Peter Baume. I certainly appreciate his desire to have legislation which is properly understood and accepted by the community, particularly by women in the community for whose benefit it is designed. Our Government has used the term `affirmative action' from the outset to describe a policy of systematically removing discrimination against women. I think during that time there has been a process of community education to ensure that our policy is understood and widely accepted, although it does have some critics. The term `affirmative action' was used by the affirmative action working party from the outset. The short title was in a form recommended by the working party, of which Senator Peter Baume was a member. There seems to be no reason to change the title at this late stage. I think in a sense it would be breaking faith with all those bodies, not only the working party but also the 28 corporations, the higher education institutions and others, who co-operated with the exercise from the outset. The meaning we attach to `affirmative action'-the systematic removal of obstacles to employment equity for women-is, I believe, now broadly understood, and no good purpose would be served by a change of name at this stage. The Opposition's amendments also seek to remove references to women at certain points. The Government does not agree with this proposal. (Quorum formed).

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is probably more convenient if we proceed with the Opposition's amendments and then with the amendments of the Australian Democrats. This means that we may not do all the amendments in sequential order but will come back to the Democrats' amendments later. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (19) Page 1, after clause 2, insert the following clause:
`Purpose of Act'
`2a. It is the purpose of this Act to promote equal opportunity in employment matters for all employees.'.

This amendment, which has been circulated in my name, inserts after clause 2, a new clause 2a to specify the purposes of this Act. There is a need or there would be some advantage, in our view to explain this legislation and make its purpose clear. This is especially so in view of the refusal of the Government to accept what was absolutely logical and pick up Senator Haines's argument-an argument which she advanced in public but did not support in the chamber when it came to a vote-that this is not an affirmative action measure but an employment equity measure.

As the Committee has determined that it will not change the title of the Bill, it seems appropriate that there should be within the legislation a clear statement of the objectives. Therefore, we propose that there should be inserted a clause 2a which sets out that the purpose of this Act is to promote equal opportunity in employment matters for all employees. The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) is quite correct when she makes it clear that this Bill refers only to women. We would like the Bill to refer to all employees in terms of equal employment matters. In my speech at the second reading stage I made it clear that I had no doubt that there had not been employment equity for women, but surely the purpose we are seeking here is employment equity for everyone. That should be the Government's purpose. If it is not, if the Government is determined only to seek employment equity for some people, I would be interested to hear it say so.

There were several ways in which we could have moved and sought to make clear in the legislation that this is a Bill about equal employment opportunity. The Committee has seen fit to reject the first and most logical way to make this matter clear and to put a purposes clause in the Bill which is consistent with what is done in many other Acts of Parliament where a purposes section is included.
