The purposes clause that we have proposed here is entirely consistent with the rhetoric of both the Minister and the Government and with the views expressed in the second reading debate by me on behalf of the Opposition, by some of my colleagues, and by Senator Haines on behalf of the Australian Democrats. It is also entirely consistent with the agreed views, even of those who do not like this legislation because they think that this is an affirmative action Bill.

If we were to include the statement that the purpose of the Act is to promote equal opportunity in employment, we will be doing no more than putting into the Bill a purposes clause which states accurately, and in a manner which has been agreed by all parties, the purpose of the Bill. It will put that clause into legislation and have the effect of promoting proper community discussion and understanding of the purposes of this Bill. It is about employment equity and the promotion of equal opportunity, and it seems to me that it would help in terms of presentation and understanding of the legislation if this clause were inserted in the Bill itself, as has been done with other pieces of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HAINES
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Peter Baume is certainly correct in saying that during the second reading debate, prior to that and since then I have referred to this piece of legislation as being `essentially defective' to the extent that it is not as strong as many people want it to be. The title itself has come in for the odd pot shot from me on the grounds that, while it claims to be an affirmative action Bill, in effect there is not a great deal of action in it. It is certainly not the sort of affirmative action style of legislation that applied in the United States, where quotas were set absolutely, and that has left quite obnoxious memories with most people. Those memories have led people to believe that any Bill called an affirmative action Bill, whatever might or might not be in brackets afterwards, is indeed a Bill leading to quotas rather than being, as Senator Peter Baume quite correctly points out, a Bill which promotes equal opportunity in employment matters for all employees regardless of sex, marital status, pregnancy and so on. In effect I believe that it states for the first time in legislative history that merit should be the main criterion.

SPEECH.PARA: To return to the comments of Senator Peter Baume on this clause, it might not be such a bad idea to leave `Affirmative Action' in the title and just let people realise that it does not mean quotas and established percentages of people who have to be in any situation. Certainly, while I think this legislation is weak, it is important to women, important enough for us not to delay its implementation for yet another month by fiddling around with the title or by inserting clauses like a statement relating to the purpose of the Act, however accurate that statement might be.

The implementation of the legislation itself, I would hope, would indicate more surely and more definitely than any statement in the Bill that its purpose is to promote equal opportunity in employment matters for all employees. Senator Baume is wise and experienced enough to know that what is in an Act is not always taken by the community at large as being a correct description. Simply stating that something is so in an Act does not always make it so in the community's mind and does not always lead people to believe that it is so. Getting this Bill out of the Senate, on to the statute books and into operation as quickly as possible without delaying it another month is a far more effective and sure way of making the community aware that-

TALK.START.PARA: —But don't you have amendments?

—I will come to that, Senator. As Senator Baume says, this legislation will promote equal opportunity in employment matters for all employees. Senator Walters interjected and asked me whether I had any amendments. I most certainly do. They are amendments that will essentially strengthen the legislation.
—Won't they delay things?

—Since the Opposition is not supporting them and neither is the Government, there is no point in my proceeding with them and prolonging this farce any longer. I will certainly raise the concerns that I have about the question of special attention being paid to Aboriginal women, migrant women and women with disabilities. I shall also raise the question of whether tertiary institutions should be allowed to put in confidential reports and so on, but since I have had an absolute indication from the Government that it is not prepared to support these amendments and since as recently as this morning I was informed by the Opposition shadow spokesman through my Whip that there would be no support from Opposition members on any amendment other than the one on subsidiaries, there is no point at all in my proceeding with these.

SPEECH.PARA: Even with my conviction that this Bill is desperately weak I certainly will not put in jeopardy legislation, which I suppose can be best described as better than none, by delaying its implementation for another month. For somebody like me who, unlike Senator Chaney, has a commitment to getting this legislation on the statute books and to making it clear to employers that the community and the Parliament will not tolerate the unequal treatment that has been meted out to women in the past and who does not, like Senator Chaney, see the legislation as peripheral to the dealings of this place, something less important than the economic matters he has said he would be happy to have this chamber continue to discuss by sitting past the adjournment hour, it is important that the legislation be put into place now. However, that does not make me any less angry with this Government for messing up its own program so that we are confronted with a farcical situation tonight which means that I have to act in this way and not proceed with amendments that I think would improve matters and would significantly embarrass a government which says it would not support them. I really have no choice if the women in Australia, who have been waiting for this legislation for far too long, are ever to get any benefit from it at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines has just suggested that she will not support any amendments because she believes that will delay the legislation, and she does not want the legislation delayed. I put it to Senator Haines that our duty in this place is to deal with legislation on its merits. It will not matter if this legislation is amended and receives royal assent sometime in September. It will not affect adversely the women of Australia. If this Committee, in fulfilling and discharging its functions, improves the legislation it will have assisted women in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator said to the Committee: `Forget the merits of anything that is being proposed; I want the legislation through, and I am willing to let through defective legislation'. That is unbelievable! There is one amendment which will ensure, for example, that a great class of women presently not able to take advantage of this Bill will be able so to do. Senator Haines suggests that in order to save three weeks she may not consider that amendment on its merits. I suggest to her that we are here to examine the merits of the matter, and if this amendment that I have proposed is defective, let her say why it is defective. To argue the matter on the basis that the legislation has to go through quickly is simply not good enough.

The reason that we are in a rush is that the Government has not scheduled enough parliamentary sitting time. This is my thirteenth year in this place and it is the first time I can recall sitting for one week only at the beginning of a Budget session. We could have sat next week. We could have had the legislation through next week, had normal procedure been followed. The Government, for political reasons, has lifted the Parliament. Is Senator Haines now saying that as the Government has lifted the Parliament she will lift whatever obligations there are to improve the legislation? I say to the honourable senator now that when I said to her Whip this morning that we were not disposed to support any of her amendments I had not seen them in their full form. That may well be my problem, but I have now looked at them. I give no undertaking that we will not support some of her amendments if she can convince us by argument and if they are worth supporting. I am going to proceed as a supporter of this legislation to try to get the very best Bill through the Parliament to help achieve the Bill's purposes. If the Bill passes through the Senate with an amendment or two and if Senator Ryan then has to go out and say to people that it will not actually receive royal assent until mid-September-having had to be dealt with only by the House of Representatives-and only then will it come into effect, no bad effects will flow from such a three weeks delay at this stage. After all I am not against the legislation; I am for the legislation. I want to see it through, but I want to see decent legislation through. The argument that the Democrats will not consider amendments simply because they do not want to exercise their task in this chamber of review is one of the weakest arguments I have ever heard. I hope that the amendments will be taken on their merits. We will certainly take Senator Haines's amendments on their merits and we will see what happens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HAINES
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I ought to respond to that little homily from Senator Peter Baume by reminding him that his Party as a whole does not treat legislation on its merits and defines certain legislation as being untouchable. (Quorum formed) Senator Baume pointed out the importance of dealing with legislation on its merits, come what may. I suggest to Senator Baume and to others in his political camp that his Party regularly fails to deal with legislation on its merits if it defines that legislation as being a Budget Bill. So apparently it is all right for Senator Baume's Party to come up with a category of Bills which it chooses not to deal with on their merits but promise at the end of the speeches made just before its members vote with the Government in the division that it will repeal the legislation when it gets back into power, but it is not all right for me to say that this Bill is okay as far as it goes, I think it is weak, it could be better, but I am not holding up matters for the sake of strengthening legislation which, once it is in operation, presumably can be tightened up as needs must.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as Senator Baume's amendment is concerned, since the title of the Bill reads `Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill', I fail to see why we need to put in a purpose of the Act any more than we need to put into any other piece of legislation whose title reasonably accurately describes its purpose a clause specifying it. As for Senator Baume's comment about this chamber letting through defective legislation, that has happened on more than one occasion in this place either because some of us on all sides of the chamber have not been as vigilant about clauses as we should be, which is why we get so many amending Bills before us, or because times change and they have to be altered in any event.

As far as I am concerned, this Bill is defective only in the sense that it does not go far enough. What it does it does adequately enough. Therefore I guess it is not in any real sense of the word defective in that it is inoperable or particularly anomalous. To me it is simply weak, it could go beyond what is does and certainly Senator Baume's amendment does not improve in any way at all either its functioning or its implementation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears to me that Senator Haines is saying-I would like her to tell me whether I am right-that she would agree with our amendment if the legislation was not going to be held up. Senator Peter Baume's amendment is in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the purpose of the Act to promote equal opportunity in employment matters for all employees.

It appears that while Senator Haines believes that the amendment is accurate she thinks it is superfluous and she does not want to hold up the Bill for a month, et cetera. As I understand it, the Bill will be held up for a month because I have an amendment-the next one coming up-with which Senator Ryan has already agreed.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—Senator Ryan would admit, though, that when I asked her whether she would agree to that amendment she said that it would be acceptable to her. That is exactly what happened. I took the amendment to Senator Ryan prior to the last parliamentary recess and asked her whether the amendment I was putting forward met with the intention of the legislation. She said yes, I asked `Would you accept my amendment?', and she definitely said that she would. I will be very surprised if she is blatantly saying at this stage that she did not do so. I would be most interested to hear her reply.
—On a point of order, Madam Temporary Chairman: We are having an argument about an amendment that is coming up after this item has been dealt with. For goodness sake, let us stick to this item.
—On the point of order, Madam Temporary Chairman: Although we have an amendment before the Chair we are considering the Bill as a whole. I would like us all to keep in good humour if we can.

—I was relating the fact that, Senator Ryan having said she would agree to this amendment, the Bill would have to come back to this place anyway. It would have to go to the House of Representatives. That is why I was dealing with just that section. I am not dealing with my amendment as yet.
—Order! Senator Walters--
—Well, as I said, I am not dealing--
—Senator Walters, I would like to deal with the point of order, if you would be so kind as to allow me.
—That is what I did. I said that the only reason I am dealing with the-
—Would you allow me to rule on the point of order?
—Oh, fine, Madam Temporary Chairman. I thought you indicated that you had not heard my point.

—I have not said anything yet. It seems perfectly reasonable to me to stick to the amendment before us. I acknowledge that Senator Haines was roaming a little widely around the question, but she was explaining her position in relation to this and other amendments. It seems to me that we will get through this legislation with the least trauma if we deal with amendments sequentially.

—Madam Temporary Chairman, I am dealing with this amendment. I was trying to be helpful to Senator Haines by telling her that we will have to come back anyway, and that therefore I did not see that as being a problem to her. We will see what Senator Ryan has to say when she rises to speak. I do not think there would be any disagreement with the proposition that the Bill provides, and certainly should provide, for equal employment opportunity for all employees. That is certainly how the Government has drafted it, and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has stressed that appointment will be only on merit, that there will be equal opportunity for the person with the best capacity to fill a job. As such, I am very surprised that the Government will not accept the very obvious purpose of the Act. A Bill usually has a purpose for an Act. The Government, by refusing to accept this amendment, will only encourage the people who are looking at the name alone to believe that the purpose of the Act will not be to have equal employment opportunity for all employees.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HAINES
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —If it helps Senator Walters in any way, let me say that there was never any intention on my part to support this Opposition amendment. I wish to make it clear that my failure, if you like, to support this amendment is simply predicated on the basis that I do not think it is a particularly useful amendment. It adds nothing at all to the Bill and is itself of no particular intrinsic worth. The only amendments from the Opposition-I am saying this now in response to a comment that Senator Walters made during her speech a moment ago-that I had any intention of looking at fondly were the ones relating to the application of the Bill to Federal statutory authorities and the reporting of subsidiary companies. I think I gave some indication to Senator Peter Baume months ago that those were the only areas where we were even remotely of like minds. I am somewhat mollified by assurances that have been given to me by the Minister-I presume that they have been given also to Senator Baume-with regard to the applicability to statutory authorities of legislation or regulation of some sort. The only area about which I will feel mildly foolish for not proceeding is the question of subsidiary companies and, quite frankly, that to me is a small enough price to pay to get this blasted Bill on the statute books.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears that Senator Haines's arguments against the bona fide amendment put forward by the Opposition are, firstly, that it may delay the operation of the Bill and, secondly, that it is not useful. I therefore ask the Minister to address those two matters directly as I wish to hear the Government's view on this matter. The Government may be quite neutral with regard to delay because there are amendments being put forward by the Australian Democrats that the Opposition may well support. Therefore, I believe that this chamber should rightly and responsibly look at every matter on its merits, take into account the arguments for the various proposals and then make the decision.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the amendment not being useful, I address myself to clause 8 of the Bill. Sub-clauses (1) (f), (1) (g) and (1) (h) directly outline what the affirmative action program is to do. One requirement is for the employer, in matters of employment policies and practices, to identify any patterns or lack of equalitive opportunity in respect of women, to set objectives and make forward estimates and to monitor and assess these objectives. It is possible for some to interpret those three sub-clauses as amounting to an opportunity for quotas to be imposed. I believe that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister explicitly and uncontroversially stated that the purpose of the Act is not to allow those ambiguities in clause 8 of the Bill. They are useful in describing the specific purpose of this legislation. I ask the Minister: Firstly, what is the Government's view on the possibility of the legislation being delayed a few weeks in the event that it has to go back to the House of Representatives? Secondly, what is wrong with the words that are in the Opposition's amendment No. 19?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason why the Government cannot accept the proposed amendment is that it is unnecessary. I remind honourable senators opposite that it is no longer the practice of parliamentary counsel to draft object clauses. This practice has been dropped and the purposes of the Bill are now set out in its long title. This is the case with this Bill and all Bills coming into the Senate. It is not that I or the Government has any argument with the intention of what the Opposition has put but rather that it is totally unnecessary, as Senator Haines has pointed out, because the objectives intended to be achieved are covered in the long title of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my speech at the second reading stage of the debate I foreshadowed that I would move an amendment to ensure that the word `merit' in clause 3 (4) is properly interpreted. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 3, sub-clause 3 (1), after the definition of `higher education institution', insert the following definition:

` ``merit'' means the suitability of a person for the discharge of duties of the kind to be performed in a capacity in which that person is employed or is proposed to be employed, and does not include preference for a person by reason of the sex, marital status or pregnancy of that person;'.

The first description of the word `merit' in the Concise Oxford Dictionary is `quality of deserving well'. I sincerely hope that that is not what the Government means by the word `merit'. The commonly accepted meaning of the word `merit' is the person who has the best capacity to perform a particular job. However, we are not dealing here with what is commonly accepted; we are dealing with legislation and the word `merit' is described as the `quality of deserving well'. Madam Temporary Chairman, that could mean that a woman deserves a job more than a man deserves it purely and simply because she is a woman-for no other reason. Indeed, one would expect that the word `merit' would be described in this Bill in the exact way that the Concise Oxford Dictionary describes it-the quality of deserving well. If that is the case the people of Australia have been hoodwinked in the most decisive way that has ever occurred because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said that there will be no sexual preference; a person will get a job purely on merit. Yet the word `merit' has not been defined in the legislation. When one looks at the dictionary one finds the first meaning of that word is not the best person for the job-there is no such description at all-but the person who is the most deserving. Of course that person could be a single parent and have several children but not have the performance record or capacity to do the job compared with someone who has all the capacities to do it. As I have already indicated, the Minister assured me unequivocally before the last recess that she would accept this amendment. I approached the Minister. I went to her office. I met her in the corridor-she will remember it well-and I said to her `Will you accept that amendment?' and the Minister said unequivocally yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will explain.

—There is no explanation because that is exactly what the Minister said. The Minister unequivocally said that she would accept the amendment. If the Minister backs off from that answer which she gave to me-I sincerely hope that she will not deny that that is what she said-I can only presume that she is finding that meaning of the word `merit' a very handy meaning, that the Minister has said to herself: `It is not what Caucus would have let through. It is not the interpretation that the Party would have given or allowed to go through but it is a very handy one to have in this legislation'. I do not believe that that was the Minister's intention at the time I spoke to her and I will be very interested to hear her answer, she having unequivocally told me that she would support my amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept Senator Walters's amendment and I would like to explain the misunderstanding which has arisen in Senator Walters's mind.
—There is no misunder- standing.

—Perhaps Senator Walters would listen to the explanation since she has sought one. Certainly I have no argument with the interpretation of the word `merit' Senator Walters put forward in her amendment. I have made it clear, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has made it clear and various other members of the Government have made it clear from the outset that the word `merit' means capacity to do the job and that preference will not be given on the basis of gender. Senator Peter Baume, Senator Walters's leader on this matter, has also understood and acknowledged that point from the outset. So there has been no misunderstanding as to our interpretation of the word `merit' or the concept. It means the person best suited to do the job. That has been acknowledged at all stages of the debate, by the working party and so on and it is the intent of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: My response to Senator Walters when she approached me about her interpretation of the word `merit' was something along these lines: I agree with the interpretation. That is what we mean. I said that I would accept no amendments to the legislation, but that when Senator Walters raised the matter at the Committee stage I would give her the assurance-as I am now doing-that her interpretation is indeed the appropriate interpretation. It is an interpretation that does not involve gender preference but involves employment equity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true. Indeed, I have with me the amendment I handed to the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) and the Minister read the amendment and said: `I will support that amendment'. There was absolutely no other interpretation at all. The Minister did not mention that the Government would not accept any amendments; she did not mention that she would stand in this place and give me an assurance. She read the amendment that I handed to her and said that she would support it. For her now actually to face me in the chamber and tell me that she did not say that is quite extraordinary. I am appalled, because there is no way in the world that the Minister made any sort of statement which could possibly get her out of her comment to me that she would support my amendment. There were no ifs and buts; there was absolutely nothing. For the Minister now to stand in this place and face me and tell an untruth really does surprise me. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to find out how Senator Haines and the Australian Democrats feel about this word `merit'. I think Senator Haines was outside the chamber when we were discussing the interpretation of this word. I ask Senator Haines and the Democrats whether they are prepared to support the interpretation of the word `merit', as I am quite sure they believe that it should be interpreted, as the person who has the best capacity to perform the task, instead of the interpretation of the Concise Oxford Dictionary, which is `the quality of deserving well'. I wonder whether the Democrats would care to speak on that. I challenge them to give their interpretation of `merit' and to say whether they believe that it is important to have the word that I believe is the crux of the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill defined in the correct way; in the way the Government intended it to be defined, according to Senator Ryan's description.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be inserted (Senator Walters's amendment) be inserted.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 5, sub-clause 6 (3), leave out `80', insert `90'.

Honourable senators will be aware that the amendment I have just moved is identical to amendment No. 1 circulated by the Australian Democrats. This amendment seeks to deal with the case of those employers who, having been relevant employers, have a diminution in their work force. It simply determines the level at which the Act would cease to apply to them. I say to Senator Haines that this amendment that the Democrats have circulated has some merit in the eyes of the Opposition. In order to ensure that it is placed before the Committee, I have moved it as being an appropriate amendment to the Bill and one which, while it does not go as far as we wanted, is an appropriate compromise. I congratulate Senator Haines on having placed it before the Committee and on having circulated it, and I have moved it accordingly.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HAINES
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Peter Baume thinks that he will upset me unduly by moving a series of my amendments, I am afraid he is very sadly mistaken. If I have to say every time he does so that to me and to the Party the establishment and implementation of this legislation is more important than the fine tuning, I will say it every time. I certainly believe that we have more right on our side in allowing this piece of legislation to go through on the grounds that we support it as far as it goes-we would like it to go further, but are not prepared to hold it up-than Opposition members have in allowing various tax measures and other Bills to go through, having howled about them in the House of Representatives and again in this place, on the specious ground that they are Budget Bills and that they will repeal them when they return to government. I say to Senator Baume: Do not preach to me tonight. It will not work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it will not work. But I want it to be clearly on the record that the Australian Democrats circulated in this chamber, for the information of honourable senators, a set of amendments which they proposed to move. Now we are giving them the chance to vote for their own amendment. We will take it to a division. Senator Haines and her colleagues may then vote against the amendment if they wish. That amendment was circulated by her Party as being an appropriate amendment to this legislation. We support the amendment. I hold the Democrats in contempt, because they would not have submitted this amendment to the Committee had they not thought that it had some merit. They have obviously considered it as a group and have agreed that the amendment is worth supporting. But when it comes to the test, the Australian Democrats not only will not move their own amendments but also they will not vote for their own amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian people should understand that the Australian Democrats went to them, seeking a mandate to let them be the keepers of public morality. I seem to recall the phrase: `Keep the bastards honest'. But when it comes to the point--

TALK.START.PARA: —Come off it, Senator.

—Senator Siddons does not like it. I will watch Senator Siddons vote against an amendment circulated in this chamber by his Party; an amendment which, I suggest, he is not now prepared to move, an amendment which we have moved to give the Democrats an opportunity to vote for their own amendment. If it had sufficient merit when the Democrats drafted it, it had sufficient merit when it came before the Committee. But there is a big difference between what the Australian Democrats say-what they indicate they will do; the promises they make to the public-and what they deliver. Increasing numbers of the public have contempt for them as a party. If this is the way in which they are going to be led by Senator Haines, I suggest they will have a very short-lived existence under her leadership.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest to Senator Haines that these amendments were to have been moved by her in the Committee of the Whole. We have moved the first one. I indicate that Senator Haines was quite right when she drafted it. It has considerable merit. We wish to support it and to see it passed. I will now explain why. One of the less satisfactory features of the Government's legislation was its decision that a certain level of employment, in this case, 100 employees-and we will have more to say about that in a technical way later-should qualify an employer to come into the program. We do not argue with that. That is an adequate provision. But the Government has determined that some employers could possibly play a little game to reduce their numbers of employees, say, to 99 employees, thereby seeking to avoid inclusion in the provisions of the Act. I think that is an accurate expression of the concern that the Government has. It does not want people playing games in that borderline region.

The Opposition has a view that employers do not work in that way and that they will not design their employment policies to avoid the provisions of this legislation. We had proposed that the Government's clause, which actually proposes that an employer, having gone into the program, does not get out until the number of employees is down to 80, was unduly onerous. We had proposed simply to oppose that sub-clause. The Democrats, on the other hand, with the wisdom of Solomon, said: `Surely there is a middle road'. Not only did they think there was a middle road, they composed an amendment and were willing to put it forward until it looked likely that it might succeed. So great is the morality and probity of the Democrats that when their own amendment has been moved, they are now-if I understood Senator Haines-not supporting it. I think it is pathetic. They are pathetic as a party.

We shall be interested to see what happens to this amendment. It is a very good amendment because it provides that employers will not be able to commit a sin which the Government was worried that they could commit. Yet the solution which is proposed is not as onerous as the solution which the Government has proposed. It provides an answer which lies somewhere between the Government's position and the Opposition's position. It was a very good amendment. It still is a very good amendment. It deserves the support of the Committee. I suggest to Senator Haines that, if she says she will not vote for it, she should try to justify that action having regard to the merit of the amendment. She should tell us what is wrong with voting for the amendment, because that is the test, surely, which even the Australian Democrats will apply to whether or not they vote for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HAINES
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not join in Senator Peter Baume's cute little games, for all the reasons that I have outlined. It has not sunk into his head that my interest is in expediting a piece of legislation which, even though it does not go as far as we would like, is in the interests of women. Those same women will not thank me one bit for holding this up in order to play around with numbers, which I may well have been, and was, prepared to do, had there been time available. Now there is not, and that is the simple fact. I say again that the Bill as it stands is all right, as far as it goes. I would prefer it to be improved. I will say that again. If it makes Senator Peter Baume feel any happier to know that I would like it to go further, fine; and he will, I suspect, then with enthusiasm support the private member's Bill that we will introduce on the first day back in September, which contains all these amendments. So in fact we can have the Bill implemented and then upgraded if necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest to Senator Peter Baume that at least that is a far better way of behaving than Liberal senators did when promising to repeal a lump sum superannuation Bill that they in fact did not oppose in this place. Despite the fact that the Opposition thought it was, in total, outrageous, it defined it as a Budget Bill. If Senator Baume is going to start plumbing the depths of whatever he is trying to do, he should look to himself first, because with him there is no match. He has supported the Government measures in a wide range of areas over the years that he has been in opposition. Indeed, he has voted with the Government when we have called divisions on legislation which he has expressed outrage over and which he said would severely damage sections of the community. Yet when it has come to the vote, despite having made those claims-I cite the 1984 wine sales tax legislation as a case in point-he has voted with the Government to pass it.

I am at least saying that the legislation as it stands will not be as good as it could be. But at least it is of benefit to a section of the community that requires assistance. I will not remove that benefit by attempting to amend the legislation to improve it when there are other ways I can go about that. If the honourable senator wants to go through the 10 amendments I have here, he may go his hardest, but I am afraid that it will not cut any ice with those women in the community who want this Bill to go through in the form that it is in-who would have liked it improved but who came to me and said: `While we want it improved, we do not want this legislation held up in order to improve it, and only in order to improve it, because we would like it on the statute books in its present format and we can take action thereafter'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave of the Committee to have incorporated in the Hansard record the three pages that set out the 10 amendments that have been circulated with the title `Amendments to be moved in Committee of the Whole by the Australian Democrats'.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
(1) Page 5, sub-clause 6 (3), leave out ``80'', insert ``90''.
(2) Page 5, sub-clause 7 (1), after paragraph (a), add:
``(aa) in the case of a relevant employer who participated in the program known as the Affirmative Action Pilot Program-1 August 1986; and''.
(3) Page 7, sub-clause 10 (1), after paragraph (f), insert the following paragraph:
``(fa) to promote the development of special programs to meet the particular needs of women of Aboriginal descent, women from non-English speaking backgrounds, and disabled women;''.
(4) Page 9, sub-clause 13 (3), after paragraph (a), add:
``(aa) information on action taken by the relevant employer in respect of each of the matters set out in sub-section 8 (1); and''.
(5) Page 9, sub-clause 14 (1), after ``relevant employer'', insert ``, other than a higher education institution,''.
(6) Page 9, after sub-clause 14, insert the following clause:
``Reports by subsidiaries

``14a. Notwithstanding sub-section 3 (2), where a corporation indicates in a report under section 13 or 14 that a corporation which is a subsidiary of that first-mentioned corporation is to lodge a separate report under that section, and the subsidiary corporation lodges such a separate report relating to employees of the subsidiary corporation, the first-mentioned corporation is not required in a report under that section to provide any information relating to the employees of the subsidiary corporation.''.
(7) Page 10, clause 18, after ``provide'', insert ``, within such reasonable time as is specified in the notice,''.
(8) Page 10, sub-clause 19 (1), after paragraph (b), insert:
``or (c) fails to meet forward estimates made in accordance with paragraph 8 (1) (g),''.
(9) Page 10, sub-clause 19 (1), leave out ``the Director may'', insert ``the Director shall''.
(10) Page 15, after clause 32, insert the following clause:
``Grants to States for higher education institutions

``32a. In exercising a discretion under the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1984 to make available to a State financial assistance in relation to a higher education institution, the Minister shall have regard to the extent to which that institution has complied with this Act.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. The point is that the matter to which Senator Peter Baume referred is only the first of some 10 amendments that have been circulated by the Australian Democrats. On the excuse that Senator Haines has just outlined, she has led the Democrats to abandon dealing with the legislation on its merits. The expediting of this Bill, even a Bill that has been described by Senator Haines as being reasonably close to what might be seen as the best legislation, is to be achieved by the abandonment of debating this legislation in this chamber on its merits, and the open and flagrant declaration that the Democrats are doing so. We have the time ahead of us to hear all of the arguments in favour of these amendments and Senator Peter Baume has, quite rightly, summarised substantially why we can support this amendment before us.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already asked the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) to address the question of delay and she chose not to make any comments whatsoever about that question. The question came up with regard to amendment No. 19 which the Opposition was moving, and whilst the Minister did address the necessity or otherwise of there being a declared purpose in the Bill-I acknowledge that-she did not in any way take up the other substantial matter that Senator Haines has mentioned and which I directly referred to and asked her to comment on; that is, whether there would be any loss at all as a result of the proclamation of this legislation being delayed by three or four weeks. If an amendment before us is passed tonight, of course it must go back to the House of Representatives and only after the House has agreed to that amendment would it go on for proclamation. So I ask the Minister to address directly the question of whether one, two, three or four weeks delay will make any difference to this legislation. For the life of me I cannot see how it could. Some dates have been mentioned in this Bill which have gone past us already. There is a reference to 1 August in the Bill and here it is, 22 August. If proclamation were delayed a few weeks more, I do not see that offence or embarrassment creates any particular problem.

I refer again to the consideration of legislation on its merit, something which the Democrats have abandoned despite the fact that this Bill talks about employment on merit. Will the Democrats abandon the principle of merit even in the Bill itself by saying that 80 per cent or 90 per cent of the opportunity is good enough for them? Will they adopt the principle of merit that they have tried to expound tonight as their definition of merit within the Bill? I have not completely given up on the other members of the Australian Democrats who are here; they have not spoken yet. Senator Siddons is sitting here and there are other Democrat senators about. I put to them this case: If they have in their Party discussions already seen merits in amendments to this legislation and we could have those amendments put, using the full capacity to see them adopted, why should they not support what they believe in? Why should they not be conscientious and responsible, for only the sake of a few weeks? I also ask the Minister about this question of delay.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is of utmost urgency to complete the legislation tonight. Three or four weeks may not seem a long delay to Senator Teague; it is certainly a long delay in terms of setting up appropriate administrative arrangements for the higher education institutions. We want the higher education institutions to start putting their programs into place as soon as possible. Another academic year will be coming up before very long and Senator Teague knows very well that institutions tend to work on a calendar year basis. They tend to employ staff at the beginning of an academic year. There are very good administrative reasons why a few weeks delay in the proclamation of the Act could mean many months delay, or even more than that, in terms of getting programs into place in institutions. The Democrats, I am very grateful to say, recognise this. Also, of course, the corporations are already approaching the interim affirmative action agency seeking advice and assistance in the preparation of their plans. We are in some difficulty in establishing the agency securely and permanently without the legislation in place. Senator Haines understands this very well and, for this reason, has co-operated with us. I just say that what might be a few weeks of unimportant delay to Senator Teague may make a very real difference in terms of the opportunity for the women who will be the beneficiaries of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sir Humphrey Appleby could not have given a better answer. In fact, in one of his books he lists `administrative reasons' as one of the reasons one gives when trying to snow a Minister. I do not know what administrative reasons there are, but I am not worried. The fact is that the Minister wants the legislation through and the Minister has taken certain steps. We are in a mood to be receptive, but the Minister has given no really convincing reason why three weeks matters. The date set down for higher education institutions, the Minister would be aware, is 1 August 1986 or such later date as is prescribed. That is no problem. The Minister is aware that the new academic year is some time away, and she and I are aware that what matters is to get the legislation in and to get it right. The Minister has given us a non-answer, but that was something we enjoyed hearing. It took us back to Yes, Minister all the way.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Haines's position gets stranger and stranger. I have never seen anything like this. I cannot ever recall in the Senate a political party circulating amendments, then indicating that it will not move them, and then indicating that it will vote against them. I think this is a first, and I believe it is a real statement of the morality of the Australian Democrats. It is absolutely pointless for Senator Haines to say that it will be all right because she is going to move a private senator's Bill in the next session. She knows, we know and everyone knows that her private senator's Bills are publicity stunts which have no possibility of success, even if they pass through this chamber and even if they have the support of the Opposition. She knows that. I ask Senator Haines to tell us how recently one of her Bills went through the Parliament and got royal assent, to tell us about the myriad of nonsense Bills that people like Senator Vigor put down to suit some single issue populist group that the Democrats are trying to buy off. Senator Haines has to answer this question from the electorate: Having the capacity here tonight to use her vote to improve the legislation, and not being willing to use it, does she really expect anyone to take her seriously when, having passed up that opportunity, she then says that she is going to introduce a private senator's Bill later on? That, of course, is merely a publicity stunt to salve what must be a quite bruised conscience.

Senator Haines was elected to the Senate to exercise review. She told us tonight that, for the reasons she set out, she chooses not to exercise review. I am going to tell the women in the Commonwealth Public Service that Senator Haines has the capacity tonight, with her vote, to help ensure that women in Commonwealth statutory authorities enjoy the same protection under this Bill as private employees, and if they do not have it, it is because the Australian Democrats-we have yet to see what happens-have indicated that they will not vote for it. They have a capacity to fix and improve this legislation but they tell us that they elect not to do so. I think it is the most pathetic demonstration I have ever seen of their incapacity and the greatest abdication of their responsibility as they have stated it. I think it is probably a sorry day that Senator Chipp resigned and left this rabble as they are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines may say that she is doing something for women tonight by not making them wait three weeks, but I can assure her that she has set back the cause of women considerably. She is the first woman leader of a Federal party and her very first action in the first few days of her leadership is to put down an amendment, then decide not to put it, and then when it does come up, decide to vote against it. I have never heard such logic. She leaves all women open to the abuse that so many men heap upon us. She leaves all women open to that comment we hear so regularly from men that women have no logic, and that, I think, is a disgrace.

SPEECH.PARA: Women are told so often by men that we can never make up our minds-that common old saying that it is a woman's privilege to change her mind. I object to that very strongly, and yet Senator Haines tonight has demonstrated to every man who voted for her as Leader of the Democrats that she is one of those women who have no logic, who do change their minds.

Senator Haines put down an amendment that the Democrats believe in strongly. They not only withdraw the amendment, but when the amendment is put up, with no reason, they indicate that they will vote against it. They still support the intention of the amendment because we are told that in another three weeks time they will raise it in a private senator's Bill, which as Senator Peter Baume has said will not see the light of day. They are not willing to put that amendment which they supposedly believe in so much; they are not willing to support it so that it can be passed into legislation. Senator Haines has done the greatest disservice to womanhood in the Federal Parliament that it is possible for any woman to do. On behalf of my sex, I take strong exception to the fact that she has disgraced women and their ability to act as leaders of Federal parties. I take great exception to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just make one more point and that is that Senator Peter Baume's quite correct description of the step by step progress of the Australian Democrats intra-contradiction makes their actions appear one more step curiouser. By the light of day tomorrow the Democrats will realise that, while they thought it was a good idea at the time to bring in a private member's Bill, they must reject it. I will be greatly surprised if, when we come back in three weeks time, there is anything at all to be heard of a private member's Bill from the Democrats. I will be greatly surprised if such a private member's Bill is introduced. We will see yet a further change of mind and a complete confusion in the Democrats' performance on this matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to place on the record my approach to handling this legislation. I am determined to take a totally responsible approach to it. I realise that to some extent it is an inconvenience to honourable senators, although in a very fine cause, that we are sitting tonight. Therefore, I do not intend to respond to every attack or below-the-belt criticism from the Opposition against me or, indeed, the Australian Democrats. I would like to place on the record that I have the greatest possible appreciation of the responsible role that the Democrats, under the leadership of Senator Haines, have taken in supporting this legislation. Senator Haines does understand the matter of urgency, as I do. Senator Haines, like me, is determined to act responsibly in this matter and not simply waste the time of the Senate in childish and unnecessary political attacks. We are both much more interested in the outcome of this legislation than in any political scuttlebutt that might occur on the way through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is worth while reminding the Committee that Senator Haines has indicated that she wishes to introduce a private senator's Bill later to include matters which are contained in her amendments. Senator Haines may recall that on 16 May 1985 she spoke in this Senate on another private senator's Bill, moved on that occasion by a Liberal Party senator. She made some comments then about private senators' Bills, and I am sure that she would like to hear them. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to support Senator Messner's Bill in the Parliament today if only to prove to these people--
that is the Liberals--

just how useless that action would be. There is no way that supporting Senator Messner's Bill in the Parliament today, or a month or so ago when he first introduced it, will have any effect at all on what is currently bothering the farmers . . .

Senator Haines got it right when she said that supporting a private senator's Bill, if we introduce it, would be a useless operation because it would not pass. Yet she dares to say that in abdicating her responsibility to review legislation tonight she may be able to salve her conscience or retrieve her reputation by introducing a private senator's Bill down the track. She is damned by the words she uttered in this chamber some 15 months ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was just wondering whether the excuse Senator Haines has given tonight concerning a private senator's Bill will indeed be supported by the Government. Will the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) tell us whether in three weeks time she will be supporting the private senator's Bill that Senator Haines is proposing to put up, bringing in her own amendment that she is voting against tonight? Will the Minister let us know whether she intends to support the private senator's Bill?
—The question is out of order.

—I do not think that the question is at all out of order. It really is quite pertinent to the matter. It is very important that we know whether the amendment that Senator Peter Baume has already put in this chamber tonight, that Senator Haines originally put and is now going to vote against, has a chance of getting through in three weeks time. I think the question is very pertinent to the amendment being put, and I would like the Minister to answer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that Senator Walters has made it clear that her interest is in the amendment before the Chair, my answer is also clear: No, we do not support this particular amendment now and we will not support it in three weeks time because we consider the number that we selected-80-does give the maximum certainty and flexibility while not imposing any appropriate requirement on small business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make one more appeal to Senator Haines not to let the side down. For heaven's sake, she should act as a leader. She is a woman and she is on trial here at the moment. She is the first woman leader of a Federal party. She should not let the side down and allow every man to say that women do not know what they are doing and they are not capable of carrying out leadership. For heaven's sake, she should let them realise that she is capable of carrying out leadership and that the first time she is put on trial she does not vote against her own amendment. For heaven's sake, the honourable senator, should not let the side down. Let us prove that we as women are as capable in this place as any man.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the figure proposed to be left out (Senator Peter Baume's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (21) Page 2, sub-clause 3 (1), definition of ``authority'', leave out the definition, insert the following definitions:
`` `authority of the Commonwealth' means-
(a) a body (whether incorporated or not) established for a public purpose by or under a law of the Commonwealth, other than a higher education institution;
(b) the holder of an office established for a public purpose by or under a law of the Commonwealth; and
(c) an incorporated company over which the Commonwealth or a body referred to in paragraph (a) is in a position to exercise control;
`` `authority of a State or Territory' means-
(a) a body (whether incorporated or not) established for a public purpose by or under a law of a State or Territory, other than a higher education institution;
(b) the holder of an office established for a public purpose by or under a law of a State or Territory; and
(c) an incorporated company over which a State or Territory or a body referred to in paragraph (a) is in a position to exercise control;''.
(22) Page 3, sub-clause 3 (1), definition of ``relevant employer'', leave out all words after paragraph (b), insert:
``and includes an authority of the Commonwealth, but does not include the Commonwealth, a State, a Territory, an authority of a State or a Territory, or a voluntary body;''.

I thought that moving amendments Nos 21 and 22 together might save a little of the time of the Committee. These amendments seek to apply the provisions of this Bill to Federal statutory authorities. If there is one thing about this Bill which is totally unsatisfactory, it is that a large group of women in the Australian work force employed by very large employers will not be covered by the legislation and will not enjoy the benefits which it confers. It is within the capacity of this Committee to give to those women the same protection as is being given to women in the private sector.

I will now explain to the Committee how this situation has come about. Honourable senators will be aware that the Public Service Reform Act, Act No. 63 of 1984, instituted new provisions for those employed under the Public Service Act. One of the parts of that Act, section 22b, laid down certain provisions which ensured that equal opportunity programs were put into effect throughout the Public Service. However, as honourable senators would all be aware, many employees of Commonwealth statutory authorities are not employed under the Public Service Act and are not covered by the equal employment opportunity provisions of the Public Service Reform Act. That Act actually provided a capacity for such employees to be included and to be covered. In section 22b (13), which appears at page 9 of the Public Service Reform Act 1984, it is stated:
. . . regulations may provide--
I emphasise the words `may provide'; it is not that they shall provide-
that this section shall apply to and in relation to a Commonwealth authority and, where the regulations so provide, this section applies to . . . the Commonwealth authority as if-
the Commonwealth authority were a Department;

In other words, the Labor Government built into its apparatus, through its regulation-making power, a mechanism for promulgating regulations to include the employees of Commonwealth statutory authorities and to give to them the same rights, entitlements and benefits as were given by this Act to officers of the Public Service. What could be fairer? What could be more admirable? I think the Commonwealth was quite right to provide for that regulation-making power. I say to the Committee: By their acts shall ye know them. The people who run the Commonwealth Public Service may have been lumbered with this Act, but those who run Commonwealth statutory authorities had no intention of having their employees caught by it. So while this section provided that regulations may be made, the test is: How many regulations were made? On the last occasion that I consulted with the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women, about six or eight weeks ago--

TALK.START.PARA: —Two weeks ago.

—No, on this matter. The last time I consulted with the Minister on this matter not one Commonwealth statutory authority had had regulations made to give to its employees the benefits given to officers of the Public Service by an Act to which royal assent was given on 25 June 1984.
—No, you pointed out the error of our ways.

—I certainly pointed out the error of the Government's ways. One could ask why this was the case. The answer is, of course, that some of the people in senior administrative positions within Commonwealth statutory authorities have no interest in equal opportunity, in employment equity. I would have thought that they would be at the forefront of seeking to have the regulations extended to their employees, but not one single authority has sought that. It is always within the capacity of the Government to move by regulation to include some Commonwealth statutory authorities. I would be interested to have the Minister tell us which authorities have been included so far.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn next to the final resolutions on the affirmative action legislation issued by the National Agenda for Women Conference, convened by Marian Sawer and Meredith Doig. Although it is not dated, I imagine they were passed within the last six months. One of the resolutions adopted by the National Agenda for Women Conference on the affirmative action legislation, resolution No. 7, reads:

That the Federal Government ensure that its statutory authorities are required by legislation to introduce affirmative action and that at least Telecom, Australia Post, the Commonwealth Bank, TAA, CSIRO, and Qantas be covered by 1987.

That was passed by consensus. As I understand it not one of those organisations is covered under the provisions of the Public Service Reform Act. If they are-I would be interested if the Minister could tell me-that will have occurred in the last two or three weeks. I point out to the Committee that at least some of those authorities are very large employers of women. Even if women make up only a minority of the work force of those authorities, why should they have less protection and less rights than women working anywhere else? The Commonwealth Bank of Australia employs a large number of women. If there is any section of the work force where equal employment opportunities and employment equity matters need to be raised, surely the banking industry is it. The airlines are very large employers of women, in terms of both their ground staff and their aircrew-though not on the flight deck, I hasten to add, where women have had a tremendous fight to be employed. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is a large employer of women.

Does the Bill we are discussing tonight remedy a problem that has been apparent since 1984? I refer to the fact that the Government has had a capacity, which it has not used, to give to women appointed within its own statutory authorities the rights it has given to officers of the Public Service. The way in which the Government has drawn up the definitions in clause 3 of this Bill specifically excludes Commonwealth statutory authorities from the provisions of this Bill. Can anyone tell me why? What logical reason could there be for Commonwealth statutory authorities being excluded? Let me take the Committee through this. The Government has determined, properly, to exclude the Commonwealth Public Service because the Public Service has adequate provisions in this area contained within the Public Service Reform Act. We have no objection to the Commonwealth Public Service being excluded. As to State statutory authorities, whilst the Commonwealth is not noted for its federalist tendencies it might well argue that proper constitutional practice would indicate that the statutory authorities of a State are for that State to administer, and that State should be responsible.

But why should Senator Susan Ryan, who is known as a champion of employment equity, bring into this Parliament a Bill which, in its definitions, precludes its protection from being conveyed to large numbers of women employed within Commonwealth statutory authorities. What logical reason is there? I suggest that it happened because the senior people at Trans Australia Airlines, Qantas Airways Ltd, the CSIRO, the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, Telecom Australia and Australia Post, and particularly probably the last two, will do anything they can to weasel out of the employment equity provisions. Indeed, if there is any section of Australian employers that requires to be made part of the employment equity practice, it is those large employers. Yet Senator Ryan is asking the Committee tonight to agree to provisions in the Bill which exclude any possibility of women working in Commonwealth statutory authorities from enjoying the protection of the Bill.

The Minister has been gracious enough to indicate to me privately that it is her wish and intention that those women should be covered. The road to hell is paved with good intentions. The Minister may say that she intends to bring legislation in. I, too, have been a Minister and I, too, have intended to bring in legislation. The Minister may well wish to tell me that the Government has taken a decision. Well, that is wonderful. But I know the kind of delay that occurs between the taking of a decision in Cabinet and the drafting of legislation and that legislation hitting the Parliament and being enacted. It is not insignificant.

Large numbers of women will be disadvantaged specifically because of the definition that has been used. There will be chauvinists and people not in favour of employment equity within Commonwealth statutory authorities who will be able to say: `Well, we have won another round. We have avoided having ourselves made subject to equal employment opportunity. We have in fact built in a bit more delay'. It is entirely possible to overcome that defect. The Opposition has proposed an amendment which recognises that State authorities should be left alone. The Opposition does not intend to pursue the Public Service, which is covered adequately. In the two amendments that I have moved, we have pursued a new set of words that separate out Commonwealth statutory authorities and will prevent those Commonwealth statutory authorities from being exempted from the provisions of this Bill. Why should they be exempted? What earthly reason is there for the women in those authorities to have less protection than women anywhere else?

I say to the Minister that she may, with the very best of intentions, give us an assurance that she will introduce legislation. But I am sorry; we have been there before. She can fix it tonight. We can have it fixed in three weeks time. When she responds, I would like the Minister to tell us how she intends to protect those women in Telecom and Australia Post and to give us the names of all the other statutory authorities in respect of which regulations, as laid down in the Public Service Reform Act of 1984, have now provided that equal employment opportunity programs shall apply. If she has taken some action in the last few weeks I will be pleased, but it is not action that will help those other large bodies. Our amendments will allow them to be protected from the moment assent is given to this Bill. There is no earthly reason why these amendments should not be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Peter Baume will be very pleased to hear that the Government's response to his timely reminder that women in statutory authorities need to be covered by similar provisions to those in the Commonwealth Public Service has been more than good intentions. I will now set out in some detail what has been done. (Quorum formed) The implementation of Senator Baume's intention that there should be complete coverage of Commonwealth statutory authorities is almost complete, and will be completed by a further part of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Government approached the issue of affirmative action in all areas of employment for which the Commonwealth had responsibility, we decided to do it in two parts-to legislate immediately for the public sector, which we did in the Public Service reforms of 1984, and then to have a period of consultation with the private sector and higher education, which we did by the affirmative action working party of which Senator Baume was a member. From the time of the passage of the 1984 legislation, it was possible for Commonwealth statutory authorities to opt to come into that program. Senator Baume and Senator Haines both know that those authorities did not do that. So we found ourselves in the situation in which large areas of employment in the Commonwealth public sector were not covered. So we decided to take action, and not just to have good intentions as Senator Baume suggested.

In the second reading speech on this Bill, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) indicated that consideration was being given to the appropriate legislative mechanisms for the coverage of Commonwealth statutory authorities. The Prime Minister also said that the Government is of the view that there is a need for all employers, whether in the private or the public sector, to conform with the principle of equal employment opportunity. So the Prime Minister was of a mind with Senator Baume and Senator Haines on this matter. On 4 June the Government announced that the Commonwealth statutory authorities with 40 or more employees will be required to implement equal employment opportunity programs for women, Aboriginals, migrants of non-English speaking backgrounds and people with disabilities. The statutory authorities for which the Public Service Board has a role in relation to employment matters will be covered by regulation under the equal employment opportunity provisions of section 22b of the Public Service Act. I point out to Senator Baume that these regulations were tabled in this chamber on 11 June 1986 and cover all authorities in a statutory relationship with the Board, together with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. All of those authorities are named in the regulations that were tabled in this chamber on 11 June.

TALK.START.PARA: —I missed how many there are. Have you covered them all?

—I will get my officers to check those regulations and count them. But the regulations cover all those authorities in a statutory relationship with the Board, plus the ABC. Their programs will be monitored in the same way as Public Service departments.

SPEECH.PARA: The other statutory authorities about which Senator Baume and Senator Haines have both expressed concern will be covered by separate legislation. The Bill is being drafted and will be introduced as soon as government business permits. I know that Senator Baume has expressed scepticism as to the pace of action in this respect but I am advised by my officers that the drafting instructions have gone to parliamentary counsel, so the matter certainly is in hand.

There will be a slight variation in the form in which these remaining statutory authorities are covered. I will explain what this is. The four statutory marketing authorities, those involved in marketing wool, wheat, meat, livestock and dairy products, will be covered by similar provisions in their enabling Acts. The new legislation will cover approximately 25 statutory authorities including those about which Senator Baume has just been expressing concern, namely, Australian Airlines, Qantas Airways Ltd, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Australia Post and Telecom Australia. I have just recalled that Senator Baume referred to Trans Australia Airlines.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was quoting the agenda resolutions which came in before the name change.

—Of course, Senator Baume would never be anything other than up-to-date. I suggest that this legislation meets the concern of the Opposition and Senator Haines that all areas of government employment should be covered by some form of affirmative action legislation requirement. The legislation will enable the authority's annual report to be a special report or to be included in the ordinary annual report of the authority. The equal employment opportunity program of each authority will follow the eight-step program set out in the Bill before the Senate. The program will be able to be included in the corporate plan of the authority.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government considered the inclusion of statutory authorities under the affirmative action legislation but we rejected this course as it would mean that statutory authorities would not be required to meet the standards set for other areas of Commonwealth employment, namely, the other minority groups. This new legislation means that statutory authorities will implement EEO programs for women and disadvantaged groups. Consequently, and I am sure that this will be clear now to Senator Baume and Senator Haines, the Government cannot accept the Opposition's amendment as it would reduce the obligations that would be placed on all areas of government employment to eliminate discrimination against women and disadvantaged groups and promote equal employment opportunity through AA programs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some problems with what the Minister has told me. I am very grateful to her for what has been done since we drew to her attention the enormous deficiency in the Bill and for what she intends to do. First, the passage of this amendment would in no way affect any subsequent legislation. The legislation which the Minister intends to bring in would have effect whether or not this amendment is passed because the Minister suggests that the provisions in the legislation which she intends to introduce will be more onerous than would be required under this legislation. Obviously, the authorities would respond to that.

SPEECH.PARA: There is absolutely no reason why, in the interests of the women employed in statutory authorities, this amendment should not be accepted tonight. Then the Government can introduce its legislation and do one of two things: It can either have within the legislation a repeal of this provision tonight if the Government does not wish to leave it there or the new legislation could simply override it. We are offering coverage now to the women employees in the statutory authorities. The Government is offering coverage at some time or other. The Government's record over two years since the introduction of the Public Service Reform Act has been pretty slack. The Minister now tells me in response not that there will be one piece of legislation to correct the problem that we have identified but, if I heard her correctly, there will be one piece of legislation plus four amending Bills. There will be five pieces of legislation. I suggest to the Minister in relation to the four marketing authorities-because I simply do not believe that she will get priority in the program-that the provisions be included in the statute law reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—All right. That statutory law revision is the first point. If the Minister has the other legislation introduced and passed through the Parliament by the end of the year I would be very surprised. I would offer her warm congratulations. I believe that the timetable will be later. The number of weeks provided for the sitting is quite limited. The Budget session is always busy and a group of women could be protected if this definition were altered and Commonwealth authorities were required to be included which otherwise will not be included until the legislation comes through.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not in any way criticise the Minister's intention to introduce legislation but I have also been involved in drafting legislation, seeing it through the processes of government and through the Parliament. At this stage the legislative program for the Budget session is probably almost closed off. We are probably looking at the Minister's legislation coming through in the autumn session. However satisfactory that may be there will be six months when a whole group of women could have been protected. But the Minister is seeking explicitly to exclude them. There is no inconsistency between having them included under this Bill and coming back later with the legislation which she proposes and which will impose upon them more onerous conditions. It is not an either/or situation. That is simply wrong in logic. We can pass this legislation, the Government can require the programs to be started now and when the succeeding legislation comes through the Minister can make whatever administrative arrangements seem appropriate. While I am grateful to the Minister, very little credit reflects upon the Government for its failure to act over two years. There is credit in the fact that the Government responded quickly once we drew to its attention the fact that a large number of women were not getting a fair go. But there is not much credit in the response on the problem of the 25 statutory authorities.

We told the Government about this problem three months ago-maybe longer. Three months down the track all we have in support of the Government's contention that the Bill should not be amended is that the Government has the authority to have a Bill drafted. The Government could have had it drafted. The Government could have brought it in and introduced it. That would have been a better demonstration of its bona fides. I am in support of what this Bill is about. I am concerned that a large number of women employed by the Commonwealth will not get the benefit of its provisions until some time, as yet unknown, down the track. The amendment which I have proposed is still the right way to go. The Minister has advanced no logical reason to suggest that it is not. I ask the Committee to support the amendment.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, sub-clause 3 (1), definition of `employer', leave out the definition, insert the following definition:
` ``employer'' means a person who employs a natural person under a contract of service;'.

I have moved this amendment because the Opposition is unhappy about the inclusion of independent sub-contractors as employees under the legislation as it is drafted. The definition of `employer' in clause 3 (1) includes the words `a person who employs a natural person under a contract of service . . . or under a contract for services'. We wish to leave out the second part of that definition because it brings into the definition of employee certain people who are, in fact, independent sub-contractors. This battle has been going on in some of the States and at the Commonwealth level. We are of the view that independent sub-contractors are not employees and that they should not be so classified. We want to take our part of the Government's definition which includes sub-contractors. I think I can understand that the Government is keen to prevent people finding some way to avoid the obligations which this Bill will impose. Someone might say that an employer with 150 employees might keep five employees and put on 145 sub-contractors.

I took advice on this matter before proposing the amendment. I was advised that there is quite a deal of case law relating to this point because it has been a matter of some interest to the Commissioner of Taxation over some years as to who is a sub-contractor, an independent self-employed person, and who is an employee. I actually have in front of me some of the cases in which these matters have been dealt with and some of the case law which has emerged. It appears that the courts are quite prepared to go behind agreements which might purport to create independent sub-contractors, agreements which have not been entered into on a bona fide or genuine basis.
