If that happens, the courts would rule that someone was not in fact an independent sub-contractor and was in fact an employee. If that is the case and if there is adequate case law which will stop people cheating, what is the purpose of trying to include sub-contractors on the list of employees?

Some of the companies which took part in the pilot program have indicated that this will provide real difficulties for them. For one thing, they do not keep account of the number of employees which their sub-contractors have. They do not try to look behind the various sub-contractors they may employ. They may have a large number on site. Various tradesmen and others who work for a company are of the view that they may well be picked up because the self-employed contractor is, in fact, a natural person employed under a contract for services. The Opposition feels that that is unnecessary. We want people in a bona fide way to apply the provisions of this Bill when it becomes an Act. This definition has been slipped in to make a different and rather ideological point about what is going on in society. We think that in the interests of amity and of dealing with this legislation properly the amendment I have moved is appropriate and should be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the arguments put forward by Senator Peter Baume. The Bill is designed to cover individual sub-contractors, but not sub-contractors who are legally structured as partnerships or registered companies. The effect of Senator Baume's amendment would be to exclude employees such as art workers who are individual sub-contractors. We are not prepared to accept that exclusion and so the amendment is not accepted.
—I ask the Minister a question relating to job sharing. Are the definitions `full time', `part time', et cetera, in clause 3 (1) clearly intended by the Government to include job sharing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we count all employees, full time and part time.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 3, after sub-clause 3 (2), insert the following sub-clause:

`(2a) In this Act, a reference to an employer being an employer of a number of employees is a reference to an employer making available that number of places for full-time employees, whether those places are filled on a full-time, part-time or casual basis, or are filled by more than one employee on a job-sharing basis.'

This amendment relates to the matter which has just been raised by my colleague Senator Teague. We are concerned that this Bill may unintentionally provide an incentive for employers not to go down the track of job sharing-of providing flexible employment. A construction can be placed on the Bill as it is drafted which may lead to that conclusion. I put the proposition that there may be a company that is willing to allow two people to occupy a position which otherwise was occupied by one person. If it is occupied by one person and that counts as one for the purposes of building up employment numbers to 100 to trigger the operation of this legislation, that is fair enough. However, if an employer who moves down the road of appropriate flexible employment in order to give women more flexibility in work and employment offers that one job to two people who are then counted as two employees for the purposes of bringing the employer's numbers up to 100, then that employer may well say that it is not in his interests to meet the needs of women in regard to job sharing and all the other variations which relate to the job sharing concept. That employer may say: `I am sorry, I have 80 employees and if I offer 20 of my jobs to job sharing I immediately become subject to the affirmative action legislation.'.

We do not want employers to avoid their obligations. What we want to do is to make sure that every full time equivalent employee counts towards the 100 cut-off point. An employer then may well say: `Of course, I will discuss flexible work arrangements'. If a couple of people want to take advantage of flexible work arrangements because it suits them to be employed under job sharing, they can say to the employer that there is no disadvantage that will accrue to the employer, because each of those employees can take half a week each while still being counted, as it were, as one nominal employee for the purposes of the legislation. That seems a perfectly reasonable proposition.

The amendment, which is designed to be helpful, is designed to put beyond doubt that proposition. It is designed to ensure that if employers take that kind of action there will not be any adverse consequences. If our amendment is not agreed to, there will be employers in Australia who will think twice about taking what is otherwise a socially very desirable course of action. I say to the Minister that in fact as a result of our amendment she can have legislation with extra flexibility in regard to employment. None of the spirit of her legislation will be breached but the opportunities for women may in fact be enhanced. She will get the kind of flexible employment that she and many other people often talk about and about which I am happy to agree.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (25) Page 2, sub-clause 3 (1), definition of ``discrimination'', leave out the definition, insert the following definition after the definition of ``trade union'':
` ``unjustified discrimination'' means discrimination that is unlawful under the Sex Discrimination Act 1984;''.
(26) Page 6, clause 8, sub-paragraph (1) (f) (i), leave out `discrimination', insert: `unjustified discrimination'.

These amendments, again relating to the definitions section in the Bill, are merely in the interests of ensuring that the words in this Bill are consistent with the words in the Public Service Reform Act. That Act uses certain words in relation to the word `discrimination'. However, this Bill uses different words. We are seeking consistency in regard to the use of words in the Public Service Reform Act and the words that used are in this Bill. It seems to us that it could be construed that the words used in this affirmative action legislation require more than is required in the Public Service Reform Act. That is one construction. It could be construed that the words required in the Public Service Reform Act do not outlaw discrimination but simply make it improper for there to be unjustified discrimination. They are the words contained in the Government's own Public Service Reform Act of 1984. They refer to unjustified discrimination. In regard to the Public Service Reform Act, the Government must have had some reason for using the words `unjustified discrimination'. I would like to hear from the Minister what the reason was. I am sure that there is a logical explanation. That might be a good place to start discussion of these amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Peter Baume's proposal would have the effect of introducing a definition of `unjustified discrimination' into the Bill. However, no similar term is used in the Sex Discrimination Act. We reject the proposal because we think it is more coherent for the beneficiaries of the Bill to have the terminology in this Bill in conformity with the Sex Discrimination Act.

—I thank the Minister for her reply, but it did not answer the point about which I was asking. I ask the Minister the same question again, because the affirmative action legislation and the Public Service Reform Act are dealing with the same matter in different forms. Therefore, why have the words `unjustified discrimination' being used in the Public Service Reform Act if the Minister is unwilling to use them in this legislation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Public Service Reform Act 1984 contained a different definition because it was covering wider groups, for example, racial groups, people with disability and so forth. The forms discrimination could take in those cases would be different

—The Minister's explanation goes only part of the way. She talked about our introducing a definition of `unjustified discrimination'. What she did not say is that the definition we have used simply says that `unjustified discrimination' means discrimination that is unlawful under the Sex Discrimination Act. We have used the Minister's own legislation to identify what is meant by unjustified discrimination. We have not tried to narrow the definition in any way. We are trying to get some consistency. We have already seen that there is to be unequal treatment between different classes of women, depending on whether their employment is in the private sector or certain areas of Commonwealth employment. We really cannot see how the Minister can justify, in addition to that, a different set of definitions for what essentially is the same set of problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The private sector is covered by the Sex Discrimination Act and this Bill. It is not required to have programs in respect of the minority groups. Such groups require a different legal definition. Therefore, for consistency in terms of the private sector's response we have used the same definitions. They are the ones with which it is concerned. The Sex Discrimination Act and this legislation have the same wording.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (27) Page 5, sub-clause 5 (9), leave out the sub-clause.

Amendment No. 27 circulated by the Opposition seeks to leave out clause 5 (9). The Opposition has taken a consistent view in regard to a number of pieces of legislation that there should not be reliance on the external affairs power for some of the legislative proposals being introduced. A number of constitutional powers are available to the Government to underpin the measures it seeks to take in this legislation. I do not think I need to enumerate the very number of these for the Minister's benefit. Briefly, however, I refer to banking, corporation and postal powers. We can go through a whole lot of powers which the Commonwealth has available to it. Specific placita under section 51 of the Constitution enumerate the other powers which are available to the Commonwealth and which will in fact underpin most of this legislation. I understand that there is only one part of the legislation for which the Minister believes that the external affairs power is important, and that is to include the tertiary education sector. The response to that is simple. I remember that when I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs I was solemnly informed by my Department in a brief, real Sir Humphrey stuff-

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not like that with us.

—Not much! The first brief in the suitcase said `in relation to your question about the Central Land Council'-with which I was having some difficulty-`we have to inform you that you have no statutory power to stop' what were some very bad practices occurring at that time within a section of the secretariat of the Central Land Council. The very next brief, from a different part of my Department, said: `Would you please now approve the budget of the Central Land Council for the next three months?' It was a matter of pinning the two briefs together and saying to both sets of officers: `Please see me'. When they came to see me they said: `Of course, you wouldn't dare do this, would you?' It took about two days to get negotiations going.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the Commonwealth is the paymaster of the tertiary sector. I represent this place on the council of one of the universities. I know that the tertiary sector would not want to pick up the requirements in this legislation. I know that the university has a very active program for employment equity. The Government can achieve all it wants without relying on the external affairs power. I cannot believe that it would have to say that it imagines that some part of the tertiary sector would mount a constitutional challenge to this legislation and say that the other powers available do not cover the operation. Do honourable senators think that the South Australian College of Advanced Education would take such a course? I do not think so. I feel that authorities would have a very good regard for the requirements and obligations of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course they do.

—Of course they do, as my colleague says, and I know that he checked on the matter with the Principal five minutes ago. Because the tertiary sector seems to be the only area where the Commonwealth believes it needs this Part of the Bill, because we believe that is not so and because we believe that the Commonwealth has the power it needs in relation to the tertiary sector, both constitutional powers and the power of the purse which the Commonwealth has and exercises in other areas, we feel that it is not necessary to rely on the external affairs power. Having said that, we believe that it is wrong in principle to use the external affairs power in the way it is being used here. Since it is not necessary, we oppose its use and will press our amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clear that the Government and the Opposition take an absolutely different view on this matter. It has come up in debate on a number of pieces of legislation. We maintain our view and the amendment is not acceptable.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Peter Baume's) amendment be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 5, clause 6, leave out sub-clauses (1) and (2), insert the following sub-clauses:

`(1) An employer who, on the commencement of this Act, is a relevant employer shall commence the development of an equal opportunity program on the operative day and shall commence the implementation of that program within the period of 6 months after the operative day.

(2) Where, after the commencement of this Act, an employer becomes a relevant employer, the relevant employer shall commence the development of an equal opportunity program on the operative day and shall commence the implementation of that program within the period of 6 months after the operative day.'

This amendment seeks to alter sub-clauses 6 (1) and (2). The problem that is presented is that the clause as drafted requires relevant employers to do two things. It requires them to develop appropriate affirmative action programs or, as they in fact are, equal employment programs. It also requires them to implement equal employment programs. The Bill states that on a certain specified day, whatever the day is, they shall commence the development and implementation of an affirmative action program. It says that they shall commence the development of a program and the implementation of a program on the same day. A number of employers have said to us that they are perfectly happy to be part of this program but they really cannot sit down on the relevant day to start working out what they have to do and then implement the program. They would be in trouble because they had not started implementing it from day one. The Bill clearly says that on one day they will commence the development of a program and that on that same day they will commence the implementation of the program. All we want to do in the interests of fairness is to say that we have this old-fashioned view that the development of a program comes first and the implementation comes afterwards-maybe a week or a fortnight later. It is very difficult to go back to people and say: `How dare you? You are not implementing a program.'.

I am only quoting what the Government has presented to the Committee. It is requiring people to conceive, develop, polish and settle a program and start implementing it on the same day. We think reason would say that there could well be a little time between the development and implementation of programs required under this legislation. The amendments we have proposed are simply to replace two existing sub-clauses, 6 (1) and 6 (2), with two new sub-clauses-magnificently drafted, I might say-in which it is proposed that the relevant employer on the operative day, the day laid down in the legislation, shall commence the development of a program and that not more than six months later that shall be implemented. In other words, we would say to the employer that he will have some time. If the Minister for Education says that six months is too long, that is fine. She may wish to propose three months; I would be interested in her response. What we are saying to the Minister is that it is clearly not possible to do both on the same day. The amendment proposes to separate the development and the implementation of the program. For goodness sake, what the legislation proposes clearly will be impossible for many employers of good will.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, I really find this a thoroughly objectionable evening. I just want to tell the Minister for Education, who is at the table, that from now on if there is not a quorum in this place I will call one. I am just giving notice that we will proceed no further without a quorum. I draw your attention to the state of the Committee. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (29) Page 5, clause 6, leave out sub-clause (3).

Earlier when we moved an Australian Democrats amendment which did not get the support of the Democrats-that extraordinary situation-we argued in relation to this sub-clause. The sub-clause provides that if the number of employees of an employer who has had 100 employees falls below that number such an employer does not cease to be bound by the legislation until the number falls below 80. We think that is unreasonable; we believe it is undesirable and unnecessary. We put the arguments earlier. We oppose the sub-clause and believe it should not be part of the Bill. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Peter Baume acknowledged, the matter was discussed before. I have already given the reasons why the Government will not accept the honourable senator's amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage some of our amendments are out of order on the list on which they have been circulated. In order to move through the Bill sequentially we now go to No. 35 of the circulated amendments I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (35) Page 6, sub-clause 8 (1), paragraph (c), leave out `each trade union having members', insert: `employees'.

I am aware that on the working party which considered affirmative action legislation the trade unions were represented as trade unions. That was fine, they played a role. Employer groups, of course, were represented as employer groups. Now, however, we are talking about what individual employers will do in relation to their own work places in implementing the provisions of this Bill. It is our belief that the appropriate people with whom consultations should be carried out are the employees. Any management with any sense will talk to the trade unions, but the requirement should be to consult the employees and not necessarily the trade unions. I ask the Government not to put that wording into the legislation. I cannot imagine that any employer, anxious to implement the provisions of this Bill adequately, would not talk to the trade unions. We cannot see why it should be put into the legislation and why the trade unions should be given a preferred and identified position within the legislation. (Quorum formed)
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is apparent that a number of these technical amendments will not be agreed to. Therefore I seek leave of the Committee to move amendments Nos 30, 31 and 40 together. Although they are unrelated, it might be convenient to consider them together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (30) Page 7, clause 10, paragraph (1) (e), leave out `, educational programs and other programs', insert: `and educational programs'.
(31) Page 8, after sub-clause 10 (2), add the following sub-clauses:
`(3) Guidelines issued under paragraph (1) (b) shall be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after such guidelines are issued.

`(4) Either House of the Parliament may, within 15 sitting days after guidelines have been laid before that House in accordance with sub-section (3), pass a resolution disapproving of any of those guidelines.

`(5) Any guidelines disapproved by either House of the Parliament under sub-section (4) shall be taken not to have been issued, and guidelines the same in substance as the disapproved guidelines shall not be issued within 6 months after that disapproval.'.
(40) Page 8, after sub-clause 11 (1), insert the following sub-clause:
`(1A) Directions given by the Minister under sub-section (1) shall not be directions in relation to particular relevant employers.'.
These technical amendments to the legislation are designed to improve it. The Opposition seeks to make the legislation as good as it can possibly be when it leaves this place.

Amendment No. 30 seeks to amend clause 10 by leaving out the words `educational programs and other programs' and inserting the words `and educational programs'. It seems to us that if the Director of Affirmative Action has a capacity to introduce `other programs' there is virtually no limit to what that Director might wish to introduce. Those other programs could be anything. If it is the Minister's intention that these programs should be research and educational, let us agree to that, but `other programs' could involve almost anything. They could be political, social or a whole lot of things. The Minister is not willing to specify them. I think the words `and other programs' go far too wide and give too much discretion to the Director. Earlier today we pointed out that one of the keys to the success of this legislation will be the way in which it is received by employers and whether they feel it involves fair play. One of the matters about which they have expressed concern is this provision.

The next amendment, amendment No. 31, seeks to insert after clause 10 (2) sub-clauses to provide that the guidelines issued under that clause shall be laid before the Parliament and shall be disallowable. We ask that the guidelines be laid before each House of Parliament within 15 sitting days, that either House may, within 15 sitting days after the guidelines have been laid, pass a resolution disapproving any of them. We also ask that any guidelines disapproved of shall be taken not to have been issued. We are merely trying to build upon the normal disallowance provisions which exist in subordinate legislation. We understand that guidelines need to be issued and that they will be issued under this legislation, but we feel that as a bona fide of good faith those guidelines should be disallowable.

Amendment No. 40 relates to clause 11 (1) after which we wish to add a further sub-clause to ensure that should the Minister give any directions under this Act to the Director of Affirmative Action those directions should not be in relation to a particular employer. We do not want the Minister saying to the Director: `I direct you to go and put the cleaners through Esso Australia or some other particular firm'. The guidelines issued by the Minister to the Director should be general guidelines, relating to the kind of general matters which the Minister may wish to have the Director consider. It may well be that the Minister has no intention of issuing directions to the Director in relation to a particular company, but we believe it should be written into the Act that they be general guidelines. It happens in certain other Acts of Parliament and it could be done with benefit here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is: That the amendments be agreed to.

—Madam Chair, I have dealt with these amendments together for the convenience of the Committee, I have spoken to them without undue length and I have spoken to them fairly calmly. I invite the Minister to make some kind of response to the substance of each amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not a great deal to say. Senator Baume is aware that we do not accept his argumentation on these cases and that we do not accept the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (37) Page 9, after clause 14, insert the following clause:
`Reports by subsidiaries

`14a. Notwithstanding sub-section 3 (2), where a corporation indicates in a report under section 13 or 14 that a corporation which is a subsidiary of that first-mentioned corporation is to lodge a separate report under that section, and the subsidiary corporation lodges such a separate report relating to employees of the subsidiary corporation, the first-mentioned corporation is not required in a report under that section to provide any information relating to the employee of the subsidiary corporation.'.

There is some confusion about the position which might apply to a conglomerate which may have a number of associate companies. Exactly where do the Broken Hill Proprietary Company Ltd and the companies associated with it-Australian Iron and Steel Pty Ltd, John Lysaght (Australia) Ltd and a few other companies-fit in? Who has to report in relation to a particular employee? Obviously they would all qualify independently because they all have more than 100 employees. All we are trying to ensure is that only one report has to be made in relation to any employee, so that if a conglomerate reports, the individual bits of it are deemed to have reported. We have tried to draw up an amendment to incorporate this principle, to try to make sure that we can deal with cases where there are a number of linked companies. I understand that the Bond Corporation Pty Ltd may well not come within the ambit of this legislation although many of the companies associated with it will. We have tried to determine the position that will apply within such a conglomerate between its different components. The amendment has been drawn carefully to try to ensure that a report-but only one report-is made in relation to each employee. I noticed earlier that Senator Haines said that she found some merit in this amendment. It is again designed to try to clarify the operation of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume is correct in saying that there is some confusion surrounding this area. Perhaps there is some confusion on Senator Baume's part. Our overall intentions are the same, that is, we do not want corporations to be able to avoid their overall responsibilities through the use of their subsidiaries. However, the effect of Senator Baume's amendment would be to destroy the concept of corporate responsibility which is incorporated in sub-section 3 (2). The aim of that provision is for corporations to treat their work force as a whole. That would include the Bond example that Senator Baume gave. This is particularly important in assessing the total number of employees of a corporation, which determines the applicability of clause 7, relating to the date of implementation. The Bill is designed to make corporations responsible for their subsidiaries, both in determining the number of employees and in reporting. (Quorum formed) Sub-section 3 (2) is drafted to ensure that holding companies do not avoid an overall responsibility to meet the terms of legislation by passing their duties on to their operating subsidiaries. The impact of the proposed amendment is that holding companies could avoid this responsibility by stating that individual subsidiaries will report separately. The amendment would diminish the role that major Australian corporations would play under the legislation by enabling them to devolve all management and affirmative action programs on to smaller subsidiaries and to sidestep their public accountability.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (32) Page 10, clause 18, after `further information', insert: `in accordance with those sub-sections'.
Clause 18 permits the Director of Affirmative Action to do the following things:

Where a . . . report . . . has been lodged . . . and, in the opinion of the Director, the information provided in the report by the employer fails to comply with sub-section 13 (3) or 14 (2) . . . the Director may, by notice in writing request the employer to provide further information . . .

That clause does not state that the further information must be relevant to the matters which are in question between the Director and the company. The company may have provided a report and the Director may be of a view that the company has failed to comply with certain earlier provisions. We accept that the Director might then wish to require the company to provide further information but it should only be further information in regard to those sub-sections which information is said not to be provided. As the clause is drafted now a construction could be put on it that the Director in those circumstances could require any information.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—I am sorry; when one reads that clause one sees that that is what it says. People may tell me that there is a legal interpretation of legislation such as this. Obviously, we say to the Minister: We read what is written. We simply want to clarify it so that the information which may be sought should be information relevant to the matters which were in dispute. This amendment will achieve that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite clear from clause 18 that the further information relates solely to sub-section 13 (3) or 14 (2) which deal with the contents of a public report and a confidential report respectively. The proposal is redundant and we reject it.

—It is not clear and the proposal clearly does not relate to further information to those earlier sub-sections. The Minister has been perfectly reasonable but this is the silliest thing she has said. It clearly does not do so. That may have been the advice she has been given but it does not clearly do so. Would the Minister please tell me how it does?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Peter Baume would be very well aware of the fact that when one is seeking legal opinions one can get more than one piece of advice on the same topic. Our advice, by the legal drafter and the parliamentary draftspeople, is that the proposal clearly does relate solely to sub-section 13 (3) or 14 (2).

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage I draw attention to the fact that when we first proposed our amendments the Government picked up one of them and in the other place an Opposition amendment was moved by the Government. It amended clause 19 to which certain words were added. There was a defect in the Bill at that stage. Those employers who were to be named should at least be given warning that they were to be named. I am further advised that once they are named they have certain rights under, I think, the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act to mount a challenge if they believe that they have been unfairly treated. As it is the Minister's understanding that such people have the right of appeal, the purpose which we were seeking to achieve by our amendment has certainly been picked up by the Government. We thank the Government because this will prevent the Director reporting to Parliament without first advising the company and will prevent capricious action being taken which may be contrary to the facts. For example, this measure will prevent a Director from asserting that an employer has not complied with the legislation when in fact he has done so.

SPEECH.PARA: Our next amendment is amendment No. 36 which amends clause 30 (1) on page 13 of the Bill. We have merely asked that certain action which the Director of Affirmative Action should take be taken only with the approval of the Minister. It relates to the appointment of consultants. The Bill as it is now written states:
The Director may . . . engage as consultants . . .

We are merely asking that the Director be required to have the approval of the Minister for the appointment of such consultants. We are not trying to limit the kind of consultants, the number of consultants, the gender of qualifications of the consultants. All we are asking is that the Director, in line with responsibility, should have ministerial approval for such appointments so that the Minister can be questioned and be responsible for them. I can recall in departments of which I was the Minister that there were other situations where I had to approve the appointment of consultants. Other people made the recommendations but I had to approve them. We have sought here to have in clause 30 sub-clause (1) the words `with the approval of the Minister' added. In clause 30 sub-clause (2) we have sought that the terms and conditions should be determined by the Director with the approval of the Minister. In each case we are merely trying to ensure that proper ministerial scrutiny is made of appointments. We are not trying to seek any other steps as to what the appointments should be or who they should be. I seek leave to move together amendments 36 and 37.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 13, sub-clause 30 (1), line 14, after ``The Director may,''. insert with the approval of the Minister.
Page 13, sub-clause 30 (2), at end of sub-clause, add ``with the approval of the Minister''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand Senator Peter Baume's concern, but I point out that clause 30 has been drafted in accordance with current Public Service Board procedures for the engagement of consultants, as implemented after the passage of the Public Service Reform Act 1984. We regard that as adequate protection of the public interest in the appointment of consultants and we will be in a position to provide adequate information to any queries about consultants.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move together amendments 38 and 39.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (38) Page 13, sub-clause 31 (1), leave out ``the Minister may'', insert: ``the Minister shall''.
(39) Page 13, after sub-clause 31 (1), insert the following sub-clauses:
``(1a) The Director shall consult each advisory committee in relation to any guidelines proposed to be issued under paragraph 10 (1) (b).
``(1b) The Minister and the Director shall consult regularly with each advisory committee established under sub-section (1) in relation to the matters referred to in that sub-section.''.

These amendments relate to advisory committees covered in clause 31 of the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill. The purpose of the Opposition in moving these amendments is to ensure that these advisory committees shall be appointed and shall be consulted. The Bill as drafted contains clauses which are permissive. They state that the Minister may do certain things; may appoint certain advisory committees. The Opposition is of the view that that should be a requirement of the Minister; that the Minister shall, in consultation with the Director, establish such advisory committees. We believe that the advisory committees are desirable and that the word `may' admits of a possibility that the Minister may not appoint them. Whether or not the Minister intends to appoint them, if she intends to appoint them she should have no objection to the inclusion of the word `shall'.

The second amendment, moved concurrently, requires that, having been appointed, the Director shall consult with the advisory committees. There is no requirement in the Bill, as we read it now, that the Director has to do anything. If an advisory committee is to be appointed, we think it should be consulted. We have moved in very moderate terms that the Director shall consult each advisory committee in relation to any guidelines proposed to be issued and the Minister and the Director shall consult regularly with each advisory committee. We have not attempted to say how often this should be done, but we have suggested that there shall be consultation and there shall be advisory committees. The benefit that would flow from this is the acceptance from within the people who will be affected by the legislation that the legislation is fair dinkum and everything is above board.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government believes it is important to retain flexibility in the appointment of advisory committees. Certainly, the intention to consult is implicit in this whole area and the consultation would take place, but at this stage we think it is undesirable to restrict the flexibility by the proposal of Senator Peter Baume, so we reject it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (33) Page 14, sub-clause 32 (1), leave out `Penalty: $2,500 or imprisonment for 3 months, or both', insert:
`Penalty: $50,000 or imprisonment for 12 months, or both'.

This clause relates to penalties. One of the concerns many employers have is that information which they make available to the Director of Affirmative Action may not be secure and if the penalties for its release are merely token or small there would be an incentive for release to occur. People are worried that those practising industrial espionage may well determine that, with fairly small penalties, they could afford to take the risk of a penalty of $2,500 if some of the information about employment patterns and practices could be obtained. The most they stood to lose might be $2,500.

We have looked at the secrecy provisions in a whole range of legislation. We have looked at the penalties in the Human Rights Commission Act, the Sex Discrimination Act, the Ombudsman Act and a whole range of Acts. Some Acts contain quite substantial penalties where information released may be damaging to business. The Customs Administration Act 1985 provides a penalty of two years gaol or $5,000; the Export Market Development Grants Act provides a penalty of $2,000 or one year's gaol, and so on. I have a whole series of Acts where I am advised that the general relativity is that a $1,000 fine often is equated with six months gaol as the maximum figure. The figures which have been offered here are insignificant. We are out to protect confidential information. The amendment I have moved seeks to provide more realistic penalties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Government's view, the penalty of $2,500 or three months imprisonment will prove adequate to dissuade people from disclosing confidential information.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (34) Page 15, after sub-clause 32 (3), insert the following sub-clause:

`(3a) For the purposes of sub-section (3), the Freedom of Information Act 1982 shall not be taken to be an Act which permits information to be divulged or communicated, or a document to be produced, contrary to this section.'.

Amendment No. 34 which has been circulated in my name is one of some consequence. It seeks to add after clause 32 (3) a new sub-clause which is to ensure that confidential information which has been provided to the Director shall not be taken to be a document which can be released under the Freedom of Information Act. Clearly, anyone providing confidential information will do so with an expectation that it will not be released, that it goes to the Director on a confidential basis. I think the Minister has made it clear in some of her comments that that is her intention. But if one reads the relevant legislation, it is quite clear that the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act and this legislation provide a loophole. The legislation as it stands is open to the interpretation that the FOI Act is an Act which actually permits the relevant information to be disclosed. I do not know whether the Minister is aware of this, so I will read to her the provisions of the legislation. I quote from page 15, clause 32 (3) of the Bill that is before us:
(3) Nothing in this section prohibits a person from-
(b) divulging or communicating information, or producing a document, that is . . . permitted by an Act to be divulged, communicated or produced . . .

So that clause provides that nothing in this legislation stops a person-say, the Director of Affirmative Action-from divulging or com- municating a document which is permitted by an Act to be divulged. The question then is whether it is possible to divulge the confidential information which has been made available by corporations. If it is, that is a very serious matter. Let us look at the Freedom of Information Act 1982. I draw the attention of the Committee to section 14 of that Act, which states:

Nothing in this Act is intended to prevent or discourage Ministers and agencies from publishing or giving access to documents (including exempt documents), otherwise than as required by this Act, where they can properly do so . . .

I advise the Committee that it is competent for an officer-say, the Director of Affirmative Action-to claim an exemption in relation to this confidential material. An officer can say: `This material was provided by a corporation in confidence and I will therefore say that it is exempt'. But there is no requirement for the Director to say it is exempt. It is possible that the Director may say: `This was given to me confidentially. I do not claim it to be an exempt document. Relying upon section 14 of the Freedom of Information Act, I intend to disclose it, and I rely further upon the provisions of section 32 (3) of the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Act'-as this Bill will then be. In general, it is the officers of agencies to whom freedom of information requests are directed and it is those people who claim exemptions under the relevant provisions of the Freedom of Information Act. But the claiming of an exemption is a discretionary act. It is not something which is necessary for officers to do.

I now turn to the annual report of the Attorney-General to the Parliament on the operation of the FOI Act for 1984-85. The document is headed `Freedom of Information Act 1982'. In that document the Attorney-General's Department makes some remarks in relation to this matter. First, the report says:

The exceptions set out in Part III of the Act and the exemptions in Part IV are `permissive' in the sense that, even though the right of access does not extend to documents falling within exception or exemption provisions, an agency or Minister may still give access to those documents where `they can properly do so or are required by law to do so'.

I will also refer to an FOI memorandum issued by the Attorney-General's Department. (Quorum formed) An FOI memorandum, No. 35, issued by the Attorney-General's Department, bears upon the point I am making that the confidential documents which will be supplied by corporations and employers are not protected adequately. At page 9 of that document, under the heading `Obligation to respect a confidence', the Attorney-General's Department says:
An agency may, of course, release confidential information even though it would be exempt under section 45.

I put it to the Minister that unless she can reassure employers that, under the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act as I have identified them to her, their confidential reports will not be made public, there will be enormous concern and distress and reluctance to provide confidential information, if they cannot be certain that it will remain confidential.

I have indicated to the Minister that under the FOI Act, taken in conjunction with this Bill and in light of advice from the Attorney-General's Department, I believe that there is a possibility, first, for the Director not to claim an exemption where she or he should properly do so, and also for the Director to release information which is confidential, bearing upon the various powers which the Director will have in relation to freedom of information. It is my belief that the confidential information should remain confidential, and it is for that reason we move the amendment, which seeks to make it quite clear that, for the purposes of this section, the Freedom of Information Act 1982 shall not be taken to be an Act which permits information to be divulged or communicated or a document to be produced contrary to this section. It merely dots the i's and crosses the t's, but I would like the Minister to give us the reason, if she is not willing to agree to this amendment, which is perfectly reasonable, why it is not necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand Senator Peter Baume's concern about this very important aspect of the legislation. Because we were aware of this concern during the debate in the House of Representatives, we took specific advice in some detail from Parliamentary Counsel. As a result of that advice I am able to assure Senator Peter Baume that his concerns are met in the way the Bill is currently drafted. The current provisions of clause 32 are designed to ensure that confidential reports and information provided by an employer to the Director cannot be obtained through an application under the Freedom of Information Act 1982. However, Senator Peter Baume's proposal would prevent any information being made available under the FOI Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is of the opinion that non-confidential reports and information should be available under the Freedom of Information Act and clause 32 is drafted to achieve this effect. I just conclude that this is very firmly the advice from Parliamentary Counsel, after detailed consultation, so I can assure Senator Peter Baume on this very important aspect.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is really quite inadequate. We raised a number of specific reasons why this was not covered. I remind the Minister that this Committee and the Senate on many occasions have had to deal with legislation which has been proved to be defective or which has required subsequent amendment in this place, and every piece of that legislation was prepared by Parliamentary Counsel. Of course they are going to tell the Minister it is all right. They prepare all the legislation that comes here which subsequently proves to be not all right. I can remember consideration of various pieces of legislation by committees of the Senate leading on almost every occasion to a need to amend the legislation. Of course they are going to tell the Minister it is all right. I have great respect for the Minister's adviser, but it is no answer to say that it is all right because she is going to appeal to authority. The Minister would fail logic one at any university.
—I actually passed it.

—That is marvellous. I am glad they did not ask the Minister this question because an appeal to authority is not in any way an appropriate intellectual response to the argument. If my argument is wrong, demolish it. I have advanced a coherent argument about why there is a loophole in the FOI legislation. If there is not a loophole, tell me why not?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that what Senator Peter Baume has advanced is not so much an argument but his interpretation of a possible loophole. As I said, we have made considerable attempts to explore that possibility because we were alerted to it by the Opposition during the debate in the House of Representatives. It is not only Parliamentary Counsel-I would not claim that the Parliamentary Counsel is infallible. We have gone further in our legal advice, and I can assure Senator Peter Baume that although his concerns are very serious indeed, they are met in the way the legislation is currently drafted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will press the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be inserted (Senator Peter Baume's amendment) be inserted.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (41) Page 16, after clause 34, add the following clause:
`35. This Act, unless sooner repealed, shall cease to have effect at the expiration of 5 years after the day fixed under section 2.'.
There remains only this one clause, amendment No. 41, which has been circulated to honourable senators. The Opposition seeks to insert a sunset clause after clause 34, which merely provides:
This Act, unless sooner repealed, shall cease to have effect at the expiration of 5 years after the day fixed under section 2.

This amendment provides that the Act should come up for re-examination after it has been in operation for a reasonable time. I hope and expect that it would operate well during that time. Certain other Acts of the Parliament come up for scrutiny by way of sunset clauses. That is regarded as an appropriate form of parliamentary scrutiny, and there is a feeling that it should be present in more legislation than it is as it means that we then have to re-examine the legislation. I understand that some Bills with sunset clauses are coming up for re-examination this session. The Opposition believes that the five-year period is a reasonable period and we are anxious that this amendment be added to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The concept of this legislation, as Senator Peter Baume appreciates, is based on long term structural change in the work force. In our view the five-year period for review would be premature and could undermine the long term effectiveness of the program, so the Government does not accept the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the proposed new clause (Senator Peter Baume's amendment) be inserted.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion by (Senator Ryan) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time of the Senate has been taken up, at an expense to the people of Australia, in debating the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill which has passed through this chamber with the support of all the parties represented in this chamber. Nevertheless, the way in which the Government has decided to manage the affairs of this chamber has brought us to the situation where, because of the Government's indifference and incompetence in the matter, and despite the Government at the beginning of this week preaching the doctrine of financial restraint and responsibility, the chamber has had to go through this charade. One can understand that in terms of the commitment which Senator Ryan and her colleagues in the Australian Labor Party have had to this legislation. Nevertheless the prime responsibility for this fiasco rests entirely in the hands of Senator Haines and her colleagues in the Australian Democrats. Nobody is more responsible for betraying the principle of parliamentary scrutiny of legislation than is Senator Haines. It ought to be clearly noted that of the allegedly six members of the Australian Democrats currently serving in the Parliament two are here to see the passage of this legislation. The others simply have shot through as a result either of boredom or their failure to be committed in any sense to the processes of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are seeing at the moment is a clear indication of what the Australian Democrats have become. Senator Chipp, Mr Chipp as he is now, is alive and well but if he were dead he would be spinning in his grave. He would be spitting chips at the situation to which his Party has been reduced because quite clearly the Democrats with their alleged commitment to the scrutiny of legislation as it passes through the Parliament have come into the Parliament this evening and said: `We are no longer interested in judging legislation on its merits. We are prepared even to forgo putting forward for public scrutiny our own amendments. We are prepared even to forgo our own matters of principle'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest to Senator Puplick that he should be advancing arguments as to why the Bill should or should not be read a third time. He is getting a little outside that ambit. I ask him to come back to order.

—I am putting the proposition that the reason that the third reading of this legislation should not be regarded as mere formality is that clearly a number of amendments should have been made to it. They were amendments of two characters. The first was those sensible amendments advanced by my colleague, Senator Peter Baume, who is leading for the Opposition on this matter. A couple of weeks ago we had clear assurances that the Democrats would support those amendments.

—I take a point of order. Mr President, you correctly pointed out to Senator Puplick that he should be debating whether the Bill should be read a third time not, as he stated, whether amendments should have been passed during the second reading stage of this legislation. I do not mind how long he goes on. I just wish that he would follow the President's ruling.

—Mr President, on the point of order: The processes that the Bill has already gone through are clearly relevant to the third reading. The fact that some of those processes have been rendered a charade by earlier events is a matter on which I think honourable senators should be allowed to comment. It has been a charade because of the antics of the Australian Democrats. That is being expanded upon at the moment I think in a most proper way and it is certainly a fit subject for debate on the third reading.
—Order! At present Senator Puplick is in order. He was outside the ambit in the first instance. He has now come back within the ambit. I will continue to hear him while he keeps within it.

—Mr President, I am always prepared to operate within the ambit claim that you lay down for any honourable senator. I was saying that the reason the Senate should decline to give this Bill a third reading in its current form is that it is defective because of the absence of two sets of amendments which ought to have been moved and ought to have been accepted by the Senate. As I was saying, the first of those amendments relates to propositions which my friend and colleague Senator Peter Baume put forward. I remind the Senate that they were of two essential characteristics. The first was that this Bill should properly have been re-entitled. It should have borne the title of a Bill relating to equal opportunity in employment. It is not an affirmative action Bill in the sense in which that term is usually and properly understood. It should have borne a title more directly related to the purposes for which the Bill has allegedly been drawn-that is to say, to provide for equality of opportunity for women in both the work force and, as my colleague Senator Teague said, in academic and other institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point made by Senator Peter Baume related to the extension of this legislation as far as bodies such as Qantas Airways Ltd, Telecom Australia and other statutory authorities under the control of the Commonwealth are concerned. Because the Democrats have decided not to pursue sensible, proper and legitimate amendments to this legislation, it will stand as flawed legislation when it could have been a decent piece of legislation. The reason it is flawed is the determination of Senator Ryan and her colleagues in the Australian Labor Party to have this legislation through this day, this week, regardless of the fact that by taking a little more time and being a little more sensible they could have had a better piece of legislation. They had to get it through this day, this week, because of the sheer, simple incompetence of Senator Grimes and his colleagues in not being able to manage the program of the Parliament in a way which would have allowed this legislation to be in proper form and to take effect from the beginning of September.

I appreciate the extent to which Senator Grimes is aggrieved, hurt and upset by the fact that he is clearly, by his actions in the Senate, admitting to his own failure in this matter. It is to his credit that he is prepared to admit publicly and in that fashion his incompetence in this matter.

The Senate also needs to dwell on a far more serious point-that is, the attempt of the Australian Democrats, under the new dynamic leadership provided by Senator Haines with the permanently absent Senator Siddons, to deal with amendments to this legislation on their merits.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is money to be made.

—As my colleague Senator Alston said, there is no doubt that Senator Siddons is absent on this occasion because somewhere else there is money to be made. Undoubtedly, he is attending to his financial and company commitments in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Haines had proposed a series of amendments to this legislation. We know that on a number of occasions this evening she has come forward and said: `We are not going to pursue the amendments which the Australian Democrats would have sought to make to this legislation to make it better legislation, more effective legislation; and more responsible legislation, because we do not believe that it should be held up for a couple of weeks'. Indeed, not only has she been prepared to vote against the amendments which she had previously signalled she would support, but she has been prepared to have circulated on behalf of the Australian Democrats a series of amendments which she was then not prepared even to move for debate in the Senate. As Senator Peter Baume indicated in his remarks, some of those amendments may well have been amendments which the Opposition parties would have supported and would have carried into legislative effect.

However, in order to get this legislation forced through the chamber, under these circumstances and at this time, Senator Haines is prepared to stand back and say: `This is despite the commitments which are contained in the policy documents of the Australian Democrats which deal with the way in which parliamentary legislation ought to be scrutinised'. In fact, the Australian Democrats documents deal with the way in which parliamentary legislation ought to be looked at. Those policy statement documents say in part:
While a Bill is before Parliament it will be scrutinised clause by clause including any delegation of power by the relevant standing committee.

Therefore, we have here the Australian Democrats with their alleged commitment to parliamentary scrutiny of legislation being prepared to say: `We now abandon that as a matter of principle. As far as we are concerned, anything that the Australian Labor Party wants to put into effect, anything that the Government wants to put into effect, anything that happens to conform to our appeal to a reducing constituency, is going to be given effect; our own policy statements and our own commitment to look at legislation and to take legislation on its merits will no longer apply'. Senator Haines is duly embarrassed by this matter. Senator Vigor is reduced to a state unknown in this chamber of absolute silence on the matter. We find ourselves now confronted with the Australian Democrats preparedness to abandon that principle--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this where we clap?

—I see that we have now managed to breathe life into the form of Senator Vigor, after so many hours of debate on this matter. The Australian Democrats are prepared on this particular occasion to see this legislation go through in its unamended form-a form which by no means achieves the objectives and the principles which the Government, the Liberal Party, the National Party and the Australian Democrats believe in. These are objectives and principles which could have been clearly stated in both the title and the purposes of this Bill. They are not to be stated. The simple reason they are not to be stated is that it is no longer convenient for the Australian Democrats to do so on this occasion. It is very sad that this Bill will therefore be read for a third time in this rather flawed, inadequate fashion.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Senator Ryan) has this legislation as a great monument to the way in which she sees the reshaping of Australian society in line with her particular vision and that of the Labor Party sisterhood who have supported her consistently throughout this. The men in the Australian Labor Party, by and large, have fled from this debate in terror for their lives and their physical safety. Even those members of the Australian Labor Party, those bold and brave old troopers such as Senator Cooney, Senator Robert Ray, Senator Aulich and Senator McKiernan, who are brave enough to be in here this evening to witness this ignominious Bill being pushed through under these circumstances, are, each one of them, being carefully attended by one of the sisterhood. Senator McKiernan is flanked by Senator Giles on one side and Senator Zakharov on the other, and he dare not move from his place. Senator Cooney and Senator Robert Ray know that if they are to leave the chamber they will have to run the gauntlet of Senator Crowley, who undoubtedly will manage to tackle them in the aisle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I would ask the honourable senator to retain his jealousy to himself and to stick to the legislation.

—I appreciate your stricture, Mr President. I conclude by saying that Senator Maguire would never get out of the place without Senator Coleman managing to deal with him. Senator Grimes, who is confined to the table, undoubtedly has his particular problems.
—Shirley is going to look after me.

—I did not think that Senator Grimes's real concern was with Senator Walters. I thought that he was effectively nailed the other day by the description given him by Senator Gareth Evans. In regard to this piece of legislation, I think two things need to be remarked upon. The first is the disorder and disarray which the Government demonstrates at the end of what is only the first sitting week of this parliamentary session. Its incompetence and inability to manage its parliamentary program in a way that will allow it to get its legislation dealt with successfully are appalling.

SPEECH.PARA: The second thing is clearly the extent to which the Australian Democrats have abandoned any claim to be a force in this chamber looking at legislation on its merits and forcing amendments to legislation where they are truly needed in the interests of the citizens and the people of Australia. In those circumstances it is quite clear that the role that this parliamentary chamber has been forced to play this evening is a clear indication that an amalgamation of the incompetence of the Government in managing its program and the willingness of the Australian Democrats to concede and to be willing partners in that incompetence clearly indicate the extent to which neither of those parties is prepared to take either this chamber or the legislative pro- cess in its correct and proper fashion. It indicates clearly why this Bill in its defective form should not be given a third reading.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.
Senate adjourned at 9.13 p.m. until 2 p.m. on Tuesday, 16 September 1986, unless previously called together in accordance with the resolution passed earlier this day.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are nearly 10 per cent of prisoners in Cessnock and Maitland Gaols receiving unemployment benefits as indicated in recent media reports.
(2) Have another one-third of prisoners in the 2 gaols received or are still receiving other social security benefits such as sickness and invalid pensions.
(3) Could these practices extend to other gaols in New South Wales and in other states.
(4) When did the Minister for Social Security originally become aware of these allegations.
(5) How widespread are such practices amongst prisoners in Australian gaols.
(6) What was the total cost of all such benefits paid to prisoners.
(7) What action, if any will be taken to recover the money and to ensure that such practices do not continue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) No.

(3) My department has made arrangements with Authorities in all States and the Northern Territory for the regular supply of details of admissions to prison to prevent improper payment of social security pensions or benefits to persons in gaol. Persons admitted to gaol from the Australian Capital Territory are listed in NSW prison records.
(4) The matter of alleged payments to prisoners at Cessnock Prison was drawn to my attention on 4 February 1986.
(5) See (3) above.
(6) This information is not available.
(7) Normal recovery practices would apply in re- lation to amounts of social security assistance incorrectly paid to prisoners.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the qualifications, experience, minimum and maximum ages for appointment to command of-
(a) a ship or submarine of the Royal Australian Navy;
(b) an armoured regiment, an artillery regiment and an infantry battalion in the Australian Regular Army; and
(c) a flying unit in the Royal Australian Air Force.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Qualifications-all officers in command of seagoing ships and submarines must hold a Bridge Watchkeeping Certificate. Additionally, all officers must complete designated Commanding Officers preparatory courses, and submarine Commanding Officers must have passed the Commanding Officers qualifying Courses conducted by the Royal Navy.
Experience-Experience for command is linked to seniority and rank and for the following ship types are:
Fremantle Class Patrol Boats, Lieutenant Commander.
Oberon Class Submarine, Lieutenant Commander or Commander.
Major Warships, Commander.
Major Warships with Task Group responsibilities HMA Ships Stalwart and Success, Captain.

Minimum and Maximum Ages-There are no minimum or maximum ages for sea command of HMA Ships or Submarines other than those associated with the respective rank levels for command of the different ship types.

(b) There are no formal written selection criteria to be met for appointment to command an armoured regiment, artillery regiment or infantry battalion in the Australian Regular Army. However, there are commonly acknowledged pre-requisites which are considered essential or desirable before an individual is selected; these pre-requisites include qualifications and experience. The common pre-requisites are:
Above average record of performance in all respects;
assessed as having demonstrated the necessary leadership ability;
preferably have demonstrated an above average performance as a sub-unit commander in the armoured or artillery regiment or infantry battalion as appropriate;
desirably to be his second or more appointment as a lieutenant colonel;
be considered to have potential for pro- motion to higher ranks;
As there is no set minimum or maximum age, by virtue of time in rank provisions and promotion potential the age bracket is approximately 37 to 43 years of age.
Particular qualifications and experience-Armoured Regiment. Previous proven performance in 1st Armoured Regiment appointments is considered essential.

Artillery regiment. Previous proven performance in artillery regimental appointments is considered essential; furthermore this should have been in the appropriate regiment, i.e., air-defence, field artillery or medium artillery.
Infantry Battalion. Previous proven performance infantry battalion appointments is considered essential; furthermore this should have been in the appropriate battalion, e.g. mechanised or parachute.

(c) To be appointed to a command of a flying unit in the Royal Australian Air Force the incumbent is normally of Wing Commander rank or higher to meet the command and disciplinary requirements of the Defence Force Disciplinary Code. There is no minimum or maximum age laid down; however, the incumbent must meet the medical employment standard to fly the aircraft type. The incumbent must have the reported ability and experience to successfully complete the aircraft type conversion, and then subsequently complete that conversion. Finally, the incumbent will be selected in competition with the pool of officers meeting the selection requirements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was a statement made by the then Prime Minister, Mr Menzies, on 15 September 1939 about age limits for officers and soldiers for the divisional force then to be sent overseas; if so-
(a) what were those age limits;
(b) have they been changed since then and if so when; and
(c) what age limits apply now for:
(i) operational service,
(ii) wartime service in base areas, and
(iii) peace time service.
(2) Are there similar age limits applicable now to the Royal Australian Navy and Royal Australian Air Force; if so what are they.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(a) The ages at which enlistment for the divisional force to be sent overseas was accepted, were Private and Non Commissioned Officer from 20 to 35 years (with exceptions up to 40 years for Warrant Officer and specially qualified Non Commissioned Officer); Subaltern-under 30; Captain-under 35; Major-under 40; Lieutenant Colonel-under 45.

(b) In 1942 enlistment in the Australian Imperial Force was restricted to between the age of 19 and 40 and in 1943 soldiers under the age of 19 were not permitted to serve in the Northern Territory or outside of Australia.
(c) The current age requirements are:
(i) for operational service; at least 18 years of age.
(ii) for wartime service in base areas; at least 18 years of age; and
(iii) for enlistment as an other rank, minimum age 17 years and for apprentices, minimum age 15.
The maximum age of enlistment is dependent upon the enlistee's avenue of entry.
(2) Yes. Age limits for operational service, wartime service in base areas and peace time service for Navy and Air Force are in alignment with those for Army.
